Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; community development, ch. 34; fire prevention and protection, ch. 50; planning, ch. 62; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78; subdivisions, ch. 82; utilities, ch. 94; zoning, app. A. 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt technical codes by reference, MCL 117.3(k); state construction code act, MCL 125.1501 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Assignation or change of property addresses. 
    The city manager is hereby designated as the official responsible to assign or change property addresses for properties located within the city. 
(Ord. No. 117, § 1, 5-2-88) 
Secs. 18-2-18-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION CODE 

Sec. 18-26. - Adoption of code. 
    Pursuant to Public Act 1972, No. 239 (MCL 125.1501, et seq.), the state construction code of the State of Michigan is hereby adopted and shall be enforced within the city by the city as authorized by section 9 of the Act. The city hereby assumes responsibility for administration of the state construction code throughout its corporate limits. The state construction code, including the building code, plumbing code, mechanical code, and electrical code, adopted thereunder, as amended, pursuant to section 4 of the Act shall hereafter be enforced within the city. 
(Ord. No. 135, art. 1, 5-15-95; Ord. No. 135-1, art. 1, 5-7-01) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt technical codes by reference, MCL 117.3(k). 
Sec. 18-27. - [Creation of board of appeals; terms; duties.] 
    Pursuant to section 14(l) of the state construction code Act 230 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1972, MCL 125.1509, and 1514, a construction code board of appeals is hereby established, consisting of five regular members and two alternate members appointed by the council. Alternate members shall sit on the board in the absence of regular members. Appointments to the board shall be for a term of four years. Members serving at the time of amendment to this section shall continue to serve for the remainder of their terms, absent resignation or removal by council. The construction board of appeals shall have the powers and duties set forth in sections 14 and 15 of the state construction code. 
(Ord. No. 135, art. 1, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 18-28. - [Enforcement.] 
    The provisions of this article shall be enforced by the city building official or by such other person or agency as the city manager may appoint with the consent of the council. 
(Ord. No. 135, art. 1, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 18-29. - Violations penalties. 
    A violation of this article shall constitute a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not more than $500.00 and costs of prosecution or by imprisonment for not more than 90 days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 135, art. 1, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 18-30. - [Fees.] 
    Fees assessed pursuant to this article shall be established by the city council by resolution and may be amended hereafter by resolution. Upon the adoption of this article, the fees that were in effect under the previous building, mechanical, and plumbing codes shall remain in effect until amended by subsequent resolution. 
(Ord. No. 135, art. 1, 5-15-95) 
Secs. 18-31-18-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RESERVED 

Secs. 18-51-18-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - RESERVED 

Secs. 18-76-18-100. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VI. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE 

Sec. 18-216. - Adoption of property maintenance code. 
    A certain document, three copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk of the city, being marked and designated as the BOCA National Property Maintenance Code, Fourth Edition, 1993, as published by the Building Officials and Code Administrators International, Inc., be and is hereby adopted by reference as the property maintenance code of the city for the control of buildings and structures as provided in this article; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of the BOCA National Property Maintenance Code are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this article, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 18-217. 
(Ord. No. 133, § 1, 10-4-93) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt technical codes by reference, MCL 117.3 k). 
Sec. 18-217. - Additions, insertions and changes. 
    The BOCA National Property Maintenance Code is amended and revised in the following respects: 
(1)  Section PM-101.1 (page 1, second line). Insert: City of Richmond. 
(2)  Section PM-106.2 (page 3, third line). Insert: $25.00 and $500.00, respectively. 
(3)  Section PM-106.2 (page 3, fourth line). Insert: 90. 
(4)  Section PM-304.12 (page 11, first line). Insert: May 1 and September 30, respectively. 
(5)  Section PM-602.2.1 (page 17, fifth line). Insert: (Dates in two locations) September 1 and May 31, respectively. 
(6)  Section PM-602.3 (page 17, third line). Insert: (Dates in two locations) September 1 and May 31, respectively. 
(Ord. No. 133, § 2, 10-4-93) 
Chapter 22 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Power to regulate trades, occupations, § 3.2(2). 
Cross reference- Alcoholic liquors, ch. 6; amusements and entertainments, ch. 10; environment, ch. 46; secondhand goods, ch. 66; zoning, app. A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Police chief's certification; investigation of applicant's character. 
(a)  In all cases where the certification of the police chief is required prior to the issuance of any license by the city clerk, such certification shall be based upon a finding that the person making application for such license is of good moral character. 
(b)  The phrase "good moral character," when used in this Code for the purpose of licensing, shall be construed to mean the propensity on the part of the person to serve the public in the licensed area in a fair, honest and open manner. 
(c)  A judgment of guilt in a criminal prosecution or a judgment in a civil action shall not be used, in and of itself, as proof of a person's lack of good moral character. It may be used as evidence in the determination, and when so used the person shall be notified and shall be permitted to rebut the evidence by showing that at the current time he has the ability and is likely to serve the public in a fair, honest and open manner, that he is rehabilitated, or that the substance of the former offense is not reasonably related to the occupation or profession for which he seeks to be licensed. 
(d)  The following criminal records shall not be used, examined or requested by the city in a determination of good moral character: 
(1)  Records of an arrest not followed by a conviction; 
(2)  Records of a conviction which has been reversed or vacated, including the arrest records relevant to that conviction; 
(3)  Records of an arrest or conviction for a misdemeanor or a felony unrelated to the person's likelihood to serve the public in a fair, honest and open manner; 
(4)  Records of an arrest or conviction for a misdemeanor for the conviction of which a person may not be incarcerated in a jail or prison. 
(e)  When a person is found to be unqualified for a license because of a lack of good moral character, or similar criteria, the person shall be furnished by the city clerk with a statement to that effect. The statement shall contain a complete record of the evidence upon which the determination was based. The person shall be entitled, as of right, to a rehearing on the issue before the council if he has relevant evidence not previously considered regarding his qualifications. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 338.41 et seq. 
Secs. 22-2-22-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Home solicitation sales, MCL 445.111 et seq.; transient merchants, MCL 445.371 et seq.; exemption for veteran's license, MCL 35.441. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Hawker means any person offering goods, wares or merchandise for sale from a fixed place not within a building or a part thereof except such goods, wares or merchandise including vegetables, fruits or produce raised, produced or manufactured by the seller on the premises where offered for sale. 
    Peddler means any person who goes about from place to place, traveling by foot, wagon, automotive vehicle or other type of conveyance selling or offering for sale any goods, wares or merchandise including vegetables, fruits or produce as may have been raised, produced or manufactured by the seller. 
    Solicitor means any person offering goods, wares or merchandise for sale by sample or description for delivery at a future time going from door to door or place to place not including solicitors offering such goods, wares or merchandise for wholesale to retailers for resale or manufacturers for use in their processes. 
    Vendor means any person offering goods, wares or merchandise for sale from a fixed place in a temporary structure or shelter except such goods, wares or merchandise including vegetables, fruits or produce raised, produced or manufactured by the seller on the premises where offered for sale. 
(Ord. No. 94, § I, 5-14-73) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-27. - Regulations. 
(a)  No person shall hawk, vend, peddle or solicit upon the premises of any other person if requested by anyone thereon not to do so, if there is displayed on the premises in a conspicuous place near the entrance thereof a sign bearing the words: "No handbills," or "No peddlers or agents," "No advertisement" or any other notice of similar import indicating in any such manner that the occupants of the premises do not desire to have their right of privacy disturbed, or to have any handbills or other materials left upon such premises. 
(b)  No person shall hawk, vend, peddle or solicit at any place within the city before the hour of 8:30 a.m. Eastern Standard Time, or peddle, solicit, vend or hawk after the hour of 8:30 p.m. Eastern Standard Time or on the premises of any other person at any time on Sundays and the following legal holidays: New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Fourth of July, Labor Day, Thanksgiving, Christmas. 
(Ord. No. 94, § III, 5-14-73) 
Secs. 22-28-22-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 22-41. - Required; procedures for obtaining. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person either as principal agent or representative to engage in the business or otherwise act as a hawker, vendor, peddler or solicitor within the city without first having obtained a license therefor in the manner provided in this division. 
(b)  Any person desiring to engage in such activities shall file an application therefor with the city clerk on forms to be provided by the clerk. Such application shall contain among other things the following information: 
(1)  Name, description and address of applicant. 
(2)  A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods, wares or merchandise to be sold. 
(3)  If the applicant is employed, the name and address of his employer together with credentials establishing such relationship. 
(4)  Length of time for which license is desired. 
(5)  If a vehicle is to be used, description of such vehicle together with license number and vehicle number. 
(6)  Photograph of applicant taken within 60 days immediately prior to date of filing application in the approximate size of two inches by two inches, depicting the head and shoulders of applicant in a clear and distinguishable manner. 
(7)  Location and zoning of property and also the name of the property owner, if not owned by the applicant. 
(8)  If the property is being leased, a copy of the lease must be attached to application. 
(9)  The state sales tax number or proof of application for same, if applicable. 
(Ord. No. 94, § II(A), (B), 5-14-73) 
Sec. 22-42. - License fee and cash bond. 
    If the application for license is approved by the city clerk, that applicant shall pay a license fee in such amount as may be established by resolution of the city council and deposit a cash bond with the city clerk to be retained by the city treasurer in the amount of $100.00, and the bond shall be held by the city treasurer, subject to the following requirements: 
(1)  Such bond shall be subject to claims in all cases where a suit has been brought against the applicant in garnishment proceedings instituted against the deposit. 
(2)  Such deposit or the remainder thereof in the event of garnishment proceedings as the case may be shall be returned by the city treasurer to the applicant six months after expiration of the license or renewal thereof for which the bond was deposited. 
(3)  Applicant will comply with all city ordinances and state laws. 
(Ord. No. 94, § II(C) 5-14-73) 
Sec. 22-43. - Issuance; terms. 
    If the city clerk is satisfied from the application that the activities of the applicant are not intended to cheat or defraud the public or otherwise be contrary to the public health, safety and welfare, he shall issue the license upon filing of the necessary license fee and bond as prescribed in section 22-42. Such license shall be for a term not exceeding one year from the date of issuance, provided that it may be for a lesser term upon the request of the applicant with the approval of the city clerk. Any application of a nonprofit or benevolent nature shall not be subject to the provisions in reference to the cash bond and license fee structure, but such license shall not be issued for more than 30 days. 
(Ord. No. 94, § II(D), 5-14-73) 
Sec. 22-44. - Renewal. 
    Upon expiration of any license issued under this article, the city clerk may renew such license for a period not exceeding one year from the date of renewal upon application thereof on forms to be provided by the clerk and payment of the license fee as may be established by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 94, § II(E), 5-14-73) 
Sec. 22-45. - Appeal on denial. 
    If the city clerk shall refuse to issue any license or renewal thereof as provided in this division, the applicant may appeal to the city council upon filing written notice thereof with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 94, § II(F), 5-14-73) 
Sec. 22-46. - Revocation. 
    Any license issued pursuant to this article shall be automatically revoked if the cash bond provided for in section 22-42 shall be reduced by garnishment suits to an amount less than the amount required under this article unless the applicant shall post an additional cash deposit to cover such garnishment claims. The city council may revoke any license for good cause after providing the licensee with reasonable notice thereof and an opportunity for hearing on such revocation before the council. 
(Ord. No. 94, § II(G), 5-14-73) 
Sec. 22-47. - Revocation of cash bond. 
    The city council may revoke the cash bond of any applicant who is found guilty of violation of any of the provisions of this article or any other city ordinances or state laws. The cash bond may also be revoked for falsifying an application. If the clerk in his discretion determines that an application is false, then he may revoke the bond and permit, provided that the matter is brought to the attention of the city council at the next regular meeting and such action is upheld by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 94, § II(H), 5-14-73) 
Secs. 22-48-22-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - AUCTIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-71. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Auction sale means a sale at which a price is submitted by the auctioneer and a bid requested, either above or below the asking price. 
    Public auction house means any lot, building, or store where the sole business conducted is that of auctioning articles of merchandise and in a zone permitting such business under the zoning ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. No. 44, §§ 1, 2, 12-13-54) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-72. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to sheriffs, constables or other public or court officers or to any person acting under the license, direction or authority of any court, state or federal, selling property in the course of their official duties or to any person selling property under and by virtue of any statute, state or federal; or to public auctions of household effects and personal belongings at the residence of the owner or under the direction of an administrator of an estate, provided that an affidavit of such fact shall be filed with the city clerk, showing such to be the case. 
(Ord. No. 44, § 12, 12-13-54) 
Sec. 22-73. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any auctioneer who shall violate the provisions of this article may have his license and permit revoked, and any owner, auctioneer or other person, who shall violate the provisions of this article, in addition to the revocation of any license or permit, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 44, § 13, 12-13-54) 
Secs. 22-74-22-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 22-86. - Required. 
    No person shall sell, dispose of, advertise for sale, or offer for sale at public auction in the city any property of any kind without being licensed, or without a permit to conduct such sale. 
(Ord. No. 44, § 5, 12-13-54) 
Sec. 22-87. - Eligibility. 
    No auctioneer's license shall be granted to any minor or to any person not of good reputation and moral character. Any person desiring to be licensed as an auctioneer shall file with the city clerk his application therefor, and shall furnish the chief of police with such information as shall be necessary to determine whether the applicant is of good reputation and sound moral character. Before granting any such application of the city council may require such further information as it may deem necessary in order to pass upon the reputation and character of the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 44, § 3, 12-13-54) 
Sec. 22-88. - Fee. 
    After such application shall have been filed with the city clerk and before the issuance of such license, the applicant shall pay to the city clerk a license fee of $5.00 for an auctioneer's license, which shall expire April 30 of each year. 
(Ord. No. 44, § 4, 12-13-54) 
Sec. 22-89. - Sales conducted by licensed auctioneers; bond requirement. 
    Auction sales may be conducted in the city by regularly licensed auctioneers, whenever a permit has been issued therefor, and upon filing a bond as provided in this section where merchandise to be auctioned consists of items of jewelry, gold, silver, plated ware, precious or semiprecious stones or watches. No permit shall be issued unless all taxes on the property sought to be sold have been paid, or security satisfactory to the city treasurer given for such payment, and unless the property sought to be sold has been within the city for one year, or is part (or all) of the stock of goods of a merchant who has regularly done business in the city for one year prior to the date of the application, and no stock has been added thereto in anticipation of such sale within 30 days prior to the date of the application; provided, however, that the limitations of this section shall not apply to public auctions of household effects and personal belongings at the residence of the owner or under the direction of an administrator of an estate, and provided an affidavit shall be filed showing such to be the case. No permit shall be issued where merchandise to be auctioned consists of items of jewelry, gold, silver, plated ware, precious or semiprecious stones or watches, unless the owner of such merchandise described in this section shall file with the city clerk a bond in the penal sum of $2,000.00, running to the people of the state, and conditioned upon the faithful performance by the owner of all of the provisions of this article, and the payment of all judgments recovered against the owner for fraud, misrepresentation or deceit, practiced by the owner's agent or auctioneer in the sale of such merchandise. 
(Ord. No. 44, § 6, 12-13-54) 
Sec. 22-90. - Contents of application; application fee; inspector's fee. 
    The application to conduct an auction sale shall be made by the owner of the property to be auctioned on blanks to be furnished by the city clerk. The application shall be sworn to by the owner, or by someone in the owner's behalf, who knows the facts. It shall state the name of the auctioneer who is to conduct the sale; the location of the property; the place where the sale is to be held; that the property has been in the city for a period of one year, or, that it is a part or all of the stock of a merchant who had regularly done business in this city for one year; that all taxes which have become a lien on such property have been paid; that no property other than that listed will be sold, or offered for sale, at such auction sale; the number of days the sale is to continue and the hours of sale each day and a completely itemized statement of the property, in duplicate, including, if it is personal property, the identifying number from each and every article, a brief description of its quality and character, and its cost price to the owner. A permit fee of $5.00 shall accompany such application. In addition to such permit fee, the auctioneer or owner shall cause to be paid to the city treasurer before a permit shall be issued an inspector's fee of $10.00 for each calendar day during which an auction sale is to be held for sale of jewelry, watches and similar items, and the permit shall be operative only on the days for which such fee has been paid. New permits, however, may be issued by the clerk from time to time upon the payment of additional inspector's fees. 
(Ord. No. 44, § 8, 12-13-54) 
Sec. 22-91. - Application; issuance; posting. 
    The application for an auction sale shall be filed with the city clerk, under oath, where it may be examined by the public at any time before or during the sale. Not less than five full days after a proper application has been filed, the clerk shall issue a permit to the auctioneer named in the application, which shall authorize the auctioneer to conduct an auction sale of the property listed in the application at the place named therein, for the number of days for which an inspector's fee has been paid as provided in section 22-90. Such permit, with the number of days plainly stated on its face, shall be posted by the auctioneer in a conspicuous place on the premises where the auction sale is being conducted and shall remain posted throughout such sale; provided, however, that if the application is for an auction sale where the principal merchandise auctioned is platinum, gold, silver, plated ware, precious or semiprecious stones, watches or other jewelry, that all persons interested may examine the same, 30 full days prior to the issuance of a permit. A permit shall not be required for a public auction of household effects and the personal belongings to be auctioned at the bona fide residence of the owner or under the direction of a court administrator, provided the sworn application filed with the city clerk shows such to be the case. 
(Ord. No. 44, § 7, 12-13-54) 
Secs. 22-92-22-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CONDUCT OF SALES 

Sec. 22-101. - Appointment of inspector; record of articles. 
    The chief of police may appoint an inspector, who shall be at all times on the premises where jewelry, watches and similar items are to be auctioned. He shall be given one copy of the inventory by the city clerk upon which he shall keep a record of each article that is offered for sale and whether or not such article is struck off to the highest bidder. If any article is offered for sale by the auctioneer which does not appear on the inspector's inventory, or if an article is offered for sale which had been previously struck off to a bidder at such sale, the inspector may forbid the sale of such article and take such other steps as appear to be necessary to protect the interests of the public. 
(Ord. No. 44, § 9, 12-13-54) 
Sec. 22-102. - Forbidden acts and practices. 
    The following acts, omissions, and practices in connection with auction sales are prohibited: 
(1)  The use of deceit, fraud or misrepresentation in the sale of any property. 
(2)  The substitution of another article for that bid upon by the prospective purchaser. 
(3)  The use of false bidders, cappers or puffers. 
(4)  The use of bells, buzzers, ballyhoo, loudspeakers or any variety of mechanical or excessive vocal sound to attract attention. 
(5)  The use of any false or misleading advertising matter. 
(6)  A sale by a person other than the licensed auctioneer named in the application. 
(7)  Failure to exhibit an auctioneer's license to a police officer on demand at the place where the auction is being conducted. 
(8)  Failure to completely post the auction sale permit. 
(9)  Sale of property not listed on the inventory filed with the city clerk. 
(10)  Adding property to the stock sought to be sold after the inventory is filed or within 30 days prior thereto in anticipation of such sale. 
(11)  Offering property for sale which has once been struck off to the highest bidder. 
(12)  The carrying on of so-called auction sales without obtaining a license as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 44, § 10, 12-13-54) 
Sec. 22-103. - Tagging or labeling of articles; hours and duration of sale. 
    If the auction sale is of platinum, gold, silver, plated ware, precious or semiprecious stones, watches or other jewelry, each article sold shall have securely attached to it a tag or label upon which shall be plainly written or printed in English, a true and correct statement of the kind and quality of the metal of which such article is made or with which it is plated, and or the true name or names, weight, quality and color of any precious or semiprecious stones, together with the name of the manufacturers of such article. No such auction sale shall be conducted between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. nor shall any such sale continue longer than 30 days. 
(Ord. No. 44, § 11, 12-13-54) 
Secs. 22-104-22-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MARIHUANA ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 22-121. - Marihuana establishments prohibited. 
    Pursuant to the Michigan Regulation and Taxation of Marihuana Act, Section 6.1, of Ballot Proposal 1 of 2018, Initiated Law 1 of 2018, MCL 333.27951-MCL 333.27967, marihuana establishments are prohibited within the boundaries of the City of Richmond, Macomb County, Michigan. This article shall have the regulatory effect to prohibit marihuana establishments in all geographic areas of the City of Richmond to the fullest extent allowed by law. 
( Ord. No. 164 , 12-17-18) 
Sec. 22-122. - Penalty. 
    A violation of this article is a City of Richmond Municipal Civil Infraction. A violation of this article shall result in a civil fine of $500.00 for each day on which the violation occurs, plus all the costs incurred in connection with the enforcement of this article. A violation of this article is deemed to be a nuisance per se. The City of Richmond may seek injunctive relief against persons alleged to be in violation of this article, and pursues such other remedies as are permitted by law. 
( Ord. No. 164 , 12-17-18) 
Chapter 26 - CABLE COMMUNICATIONS[1] 
Footnotes:

No. 112-3 (1-21-85), pertaining to cable communications and to cable communications systems, although not printed in this Code, are saved from repeal and shall remain in full force and effect. Such ordinances are available for inspection in the office of the city clerk. 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 26-1-26-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RATE REGULATION 

Sec. 26-26. - Purpose of article. 
    The purpose of this article is to implement a system of rate regulations on basic service consistent with the provisions of the Cable Consumer Television Protection Act of 1992, as amended, together with the rules or regulations adopted by the Federal Communications Commission in compliance with that Act. These rate regulations shall remain in effect as long as the cable television system is without effective competition as defined by federal law. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 1, 10-4-93) 
Sec. 26-27. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Basic cable service or basic service means the lowest level of service provided by the grantee. This shall include all broadcast channels, public, educational and governmental access channels, together with any additional channels or services the grantee provides on this service level. 
    Cable television commission means the body duly constituted and appointed by virtue of the cable TV ordinance, being Ordinance No. 112, adopted July 21, 1982, as amended, and referred to therein as the cable television committee. 
    Cable television system means the equipment, materials and programming used by the grantee to deliver television and similar signals to persons. The term "television and similar signals" shall include broadcast and satellite signals, as well as all public, educational and governmental access channel signals, whether such transmissions are provided in analog or digital form, together with any other signals transmitted along the same wiring by the grantee as the television signals. 
    Expanded basic service or expanded basic means that level of service offered by the grantee that includes the basic service and all other satellite or other channels offered by the grantee as part of a basic package of service as of April 1, 1993, and not available on that date on a per channel, i.e., a la carte basis. 
    Federal Communications Commission or FCC means that agency duly constituted by the laws of the United States to supervise regulatory implementation of legislation affecting delivery of cable television service. Benchmark rates shall mean those rates as established by the FCC. 
    Grantee means the party granted and/or assigned a franchise to operate a cable television system within the city. 
    Premium cable service or premium service means those channels or services the grantee had offered on April 1, 1993, on a per channel, i.e., a la carte basis. Premium service shall also include channels or services offered to persons for single events, feature films, or similar limited viewing, i.e., pay-per view. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 2, 10-4-93) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-28. - Coordination and compliance with Federal Communications Commission rules and regulations. 
    The city and the grantee shall adhere to all regulations as adopted by the FCC, pursuant to its obligations under the Cable Act. The enforcement of this article shall be coordinated in compliance with FCC's rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 3, 10-4-93) 
Sec. 26-29. - Procedures for the submission of rates schedules to the city; form of submission; rate decisions. 
(a)  Submission of proposed rates. In order to modify its regulated rates, grantee shall submit to the city clerk a schedule of proposed rates for basic service, equipment and other charges for customer services. Such schedules shall include the following information: 
(1)  The dates requested for the implementation of such charges. 
(2)  A schedule of channels and channel placement being made available to subscribing households, including all levels of available service. 
(3)  The grantee's designation of each such channel and whether it is defined in the grantee's offering as its basic service. 
(4)  The proposed monthly charges requested for the basic service including any discounts available to subscribers. 
(5)  The proposed charges for installation, sale and/or rental of any equipment, including, but not limited to, the following items: 
a.  The cost of installation of cable television services and any surcharges or discounts applicable to such installation charges and the reason for such surcharges or discounts. 
b.  Where the grantee is requesting that its rates be set according to its cost of service as defined by federal law, the items of equipment to be used for the delivery of such services including coaxial cable, fiber optic lines, modulators, satellite receivers and descramblers, microwave transmission equipment, converter/descrambler boxes, filter traps, remote control devices and similar equipment. In outlining the proposed charges for the installation, sale or rental of this equipment, the grantee shall identify the manufacturer(s) and model number(s) of the equipment to be utilized as well as the unit cost to the grantee to purchase or lease such equipment. The grantee shall specify what consumer options are available with respect to each item of equipment to be placed in or adjacent to the household, including, but not limited to, the availability of two-way transmission, remote control ability, premium channel descrambling ability, digital descrambling ability and volume control; 
c.  The late charges or penalties proposed to be charged subscribers and the conditions under which those charges are to be imposed or may be waived. 
d.  The cost for the installation and maintenance of additional or modified outlets. 
e.  The cost for sale or rental of remote control devices. 
f.  The cost for cable guides or other similar publications made available to subscribers. 
g.  The cost of any other equipment or material the grantee seeks to be considered in the setting of rates. 
(6)  The grantee shall supply a list of the charges to subscribers for the items specified within subsection (a)(5)a-g of this section or comparable equipment/materials used by the grantee in prior years for the five years preceding the date of submission of the rate schedule, including the percentage increase in cost for such items, or, if the grantee's franchise has been in effect for less than five years, then for all years the grantee has held such franchise. The grantee need only supply the items specified within subsection (5)(b) if grantee is seeking a rate modification based upon its cost of service as defined by federal law. 
(7)  Concurrent with supplying the documentation described in subsection (6) of this section, the grantee shall supply the city clerk with copies of all documents submitted to the FCC with respect to the grantee's cost of equipment. 
(8)  The grantee shall clearly designate what information it considers proprietary in nature and the circumstances under which the grantee will not object to the public release of such proprietary information. The grantee may request that the identified materials be treated as confidential and not subject to public disclosure. Such request must be submitted with a statement as to why such information should be considered proprietary and the factual basis for such statement. The city commission shall grant such request to maintain the confidentiality of the materials if it finds such request consistent with the purposes of the federal Freedom of Information Act and FCC regulation pertaining to the procedures for requesting public disclosure. 
(b)  Receipt and forwarding of information; publication; proprietary information. Upon receipt of the information set forth within subsection (a) of this section, the city clerk shall within 14 days of receipt of the grantee's submission: 
(1)  Cause the proposed rate schedule for basic and regulated equipment to be published in conformance with the city Charter or as otherwise provided by applicable law. 
(2)  Provide the city council, city manager, city attorney and cable television commission chairperson with copies of all information supplied to the city clerk's office by the grantee. 
(3)  Take all reasonable measures to secure any proprietary information supplied to the city clerk and advise the grantee in writing of the measures taken to secure these materials. Such materials shall not be disclosed except as provided in this subsection or as otherwise provided by law. 
(c)  Consideration of proposal. Following receipt of such submission from the grantee, the city clerk shall transmit to the grantee, via first class mail, to the address provided by the grantee, a notification containing the following information: 
(1)  The proposed schedule of rates shall become effective 30 days after the date of the submission unless such schedule is tolled pursuant to and in conformity with the applicable FCC rules and this article. 
(2)  The grantee has the burden of proof in demonstrating that the proposed rate schedules comport with the applicable FCC rules and are appropriate in terms of the grantee's costs. 
(3)  A tolling order for the implementation of the rate schedule shall be made by the city manager, upon request by either the city council or the cable television commission or such tolling order may be issued by the city manager in his discretion. 
(4)  The city attorney shall advise the city manager if any additional information is necessary from the grantee. 
(d)  Obligation of the city manager. The city manager shall request from the members of the city council and cable television commission their determination as to whether a public hearing should be conducted to evaluate the grantee's proposed rate schedule. If the city manager is notified by two or more members of either the city council or the cable commission that a public hearing should be held, or the city manager believes that such a public hearing is warranted, the city manager shall issue a tolling order to the grantee, delaying the implementation of the rate schedule for a period not to exceed 120 days from the date of the tolling order. If the city manager issues a tolling order, he shall promptly notify the grantee in writing, via first class mail, of the tolling order and setting forth the length of the tolling period. The city manager shall also advise the grantee that a public hearing before the cable television commission will occur within 30 days of the date of the tolling order. 
(e)  Public hearing. Following the issuance of the tolling order, the city manager shall forthwith schedule a public hearing before the cable television commission, to be held within 30 days of the date of the tolling order. Notification of the hearing date, time and location shall be transmitted to the grantee via first class mail. The following provisions are made for public hearings as to a cable rate regulation: 
(1)  The notice of such public hearing shall be in writing and posted as required under the city Charter or as otherwise provided by applicable law. 
(2)  At such public hearing, the grantee shall have the opportunity to present arguments and documentation in person and/or in writing supporting its proposed rate schedule. Following this presentation, the cable television commission shall hear arguments and consider documentation as presented by the city attorney, other city officials and members of the general public as to the proposed rate schedule. The grantee may then be allowed to present arguments and documentation in rebuttal. 
(3)  If the cable television commission needs additional information, documentation, or materials from the grantee or any other person, it shall direct that the same be supplied to the cable television commission within 14 days of the date of the public hearing. Items submitted after the 14-day period shall not be considered. The grantee or other person shall supply these materials to the city clerk, and the city clerk shall process these materials in comportment with subsection (b) of this section. Concurrently, the cable television commission shall schedule a second public hearing to be held 28 days after the initial hearing date. 
(4)  Upon receipt of the additional materials, the cable television commission chairperson shall distribute such materials to the members of the cable television commission. The cable television commission chairperson shall then prepare a written recommendation as to the proposed rate schedule. In evaluating the rates to be set for services, the cable television commission chairperson shall consider the federal benchmark standards as may be established by the Federal Communications Commission, if grantee seeks a rate modification based upon these standards, or, if grantee seeks a modification based upon its cost of service, the cable television commission chairperson shall allow a fair return on investment, taking into account appropriate costs including, but not limited to, the grantee's capital costs, basic cable programming, customer service, labor and ancillary costs attributable to obtaining and transmitting signals carried on the basic service. Also considered shall be increases in the grantee's costs as to any franchise-imposed requirements not directly related to the provision of cable television service as well as a reasonable profit to the grantee. The cable television commission chairperson shall presume the reasonableness of documented increases and those basic cable costs factors itemized in this "fair return on investment" standard. 
(5)  At the adjourned hearing, the cable television commission shall review all information and materials together with the written recommendation of its chairperson. The commission may adopt such recommendation or, after setting forth a basis for adopting a modification to that recommendation, and considering all factors outlined within subsection (e)(4) of this section, may make and adopt a modified recommendation. Any modification, and the basis for the recommendation, shall be promptly reduced to writing and supplied to the city manager and sent promptly to the grantee via first class mail. 
(6)  The recommendation of the cable television commission shall become final and binding upon the grantee within seven days after the date that the recommendation is placed in writing and executed by the chairperson of the cable commission. The grantee, prior to the expiration of the seven-day effective date, may file objections with the city clerk requesting a hearing before the city council. If no objections are filed within this period, the city clerk shall cause the rate schedule to be published in conformance with the city Charter or as otherwise provided by law. 
(f)  Hearing before the city council. 
(1)  If the city clerk receives objections to the proposed recommendation of the cable television commission, he shall transmit to the city council the recommendation of the executive director, any modified recommendation as made by the cable television commission, as well as written objections of the grantee. 
(2)  At the next available city council meeting, the above listed recommendations as well as the objections, shall be reviewed. Additional written materials may be submitted to the city council for its review up to seven days prior to the scheduled public hearing. 
(3)  At the public hearing, the city council, after hearing comments from the public and the grantee, may adopt the initial schedule of rates as proposed, the recommendation of the cable television commission chairperson, the modified recommendation made by the cable television commission, or direct the implementation of a schedule of rates that the city council believes appropriate. The rate schedule as adopted by the city council shall be put in the form of a resolution and executed by the city clerk and attested to by the mayor. The rate schedule shall be final and binding upon the grantee upon execution of the resolution. 
(4)  Included within the resolution shall be a full listing of charges, together with the effective dates of such charges. The resolution shall be mailed to the grantee via first class mail and published in conformance with the city Charter or as otherwise provided by applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 4, 10-4-93; Ord. No. 131-1, § A, 2-7-94) 
Sec. 26-30. - Rules of procedure. 
    The cable television commission shall adopt and implement such rules of procedure in the conducting of public hearings as is consistent with the FCC regulations and due process of law. At all times, the grantee, at its election, may choose to be represented by counsel. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 5, 10-4-93) 
Sec. 26-31. - Refunds. 
    The city council and the cable television commission may direct the payment of refunds to subscribers retroactive to the date as may be allowable by federal and/or state law. The city council or cable television commission shall direct what means the grantee will undertake in order to pay any such refunds in accordance with the procedures set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 6, 10-4-93; Ord. No. 131-1, § B, 2-7-94) 
Sec. 26-32. - Failure to give notice. 
    Any failure to give notice as provided for in this section shall not invalidate any orders, recommendations or decisions as set forth under this rule. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 7, 10-4-93) 
Sec. 26-33. - Additional hearings. 
    Upon reasonable notice, the city council or the cable television commission may schedule such additional hearings as may be necessary in the exercise of their regulatory functions as set forth within this article or as otherwise provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 8, 10-4-93) 
Sec. 26-34. - Grantee's failure to comply; remedies. 
(a)  Failure to submit proposed rate schedule. In the event the grantee fails to submit a proposed rate schedule and modifies regulated rates in violation of this ordinance, it may be ordered to reduce its basic rates to 75 percent of the FCC benchmark of rates and its services/rental charges to those specified within the initial franchise agreement or proposal to provide a franchise agreement or, if no specific charges are listed for the particular service/rental charges, to such amounts as may be adopted by the cable television commission as set forth in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Cable commission; authority to set rates. 
(1)  If the grantee fails to submit a proposed rate schedule as set forth in subsection (a) of this section, within 60 days, the cable television commission shall meet to review the FCC benchmark of rates as well as the charges for services/rentals within the original franchise agreement and the FCC materials regarding the service/rental expenses and issue a rate schedule binding upon the grantee. 
(2)  In evaluating these rates, the cable television commission shall consider that the grantee is entitled to a fair return on its investment and shall take into account the appropriate costs including, but not limited to, the grantee's capital costs, basic cable programming, customer service, labor and ancillary costs attributable to obtaining and transmitting signals carried on the basic service. Increases in such costs, and the costs of any franchise imposed requirements not directly related to the provision of cable television service, as well as a reasonable profit to the grantee shall also be considered. The grantee may submit written documentation to the cable television commission prior to the meeting date as to any aspects of its costs. The cable television commission shall presume the reasonableness of any documented increases supplied by the grantee in those basic cable cost factors itemized in this fair return on investment standard. 
(3)  The cable television commission shall adopt the effective dates that the rate schedule shall be in effect, with the beginning date being the date grantee modified its rate schedule in violation of this ordinance or as otherwise allowed by law and the ending date being the date arrived at by subsequent implementation of this ordinance. 
(4)  The rate schedule shall be mailed to the grantee and published in conformance with the city Charter or as otherwise provided by applicable law. The rate schedule shall be effective upon its being reduced to writing and executed by the chairperson of the cable television commission. 
(c)  Grantee's failure to comply with request for information. If the grantee fails to respond to any request by the city council, cable commission or city manager for additional material or information, the city council may direct the immediate reduction of the grantee's basic rates to 75 percent of the FCC benchmark for cable subscribers for a period up to 90 days for each violation. The city council may also direct the imposition of additional penalties of up to $100.00 per day for each day that a violation occurs. The grantee shall be entitled to demand a public hearing before the city council to contest the assessment of any penalties imposed under this section. 
(d)  Failure to set rates in comportment with the schedule as adopted. If the grantee fails to adhere to the rate schedule as established by this article, the city council may impose penalties including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Termination of the franchise and/or filing suit within the circuit court for placement of such franchise in receivership; 
(2)  Imposition of fines not to exceed $100.00 per day for each scheduled item that the grantee fails to comply with; 
(3)  An order directing the immediate roll-back of basic service rates to 75 percent of the FCC benchmark; and/or 
(4)  An order directing that the appropriate refunds be made to subscribers and the means the grantee is to employ in making such refunds. 
The grantee shall be entitled to a public hearing before the city council to contest the assessment of the penalties imposed in this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 9, 10-4-93) 
Sec. 26-35. - Requests for disclosure of asserted proprietary information. 
    Requests for disclosure of any documents the grantee asserts are proprietary may be submitted to the city clerk by any person. The city council shall be the sole authority to authorize public disclosure of alleged proprietary materials. In determining whether any such materials shall be disclosed, the city council shall grant the grantee's request to maintain the confidentiality of the materials only if such request is consistent with the purposes of the federal Freedom of Information Act and applicable FCC regulation. If a request for disclosure is submitted to the city clerk, such submission shall be in writing specifying what materials are sought to be disclosed to the public and the basis for requesting such public disclosure. The city clerk shall mail a copy of the request to the grantee. The grantee shall have 14 days from the date of mailing to respond to the request. At its next available city council meeting, the city council shall review the request for disclosure as well as the response submitted by the grantee. Any decision of the city council as to such disclosure shall become final 14 days after the city council meeting. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 10, 10-4-93) 
Sec. 26-36. - Additional powers. 
    The city council and cable television commission's powers as set forth in this article should be in addition to all other powers afforded franchising authorities by applicable law or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 11, 10-4-93) 
Secs. 26-37-26-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CUSTOMER SERVICE STANDARDS 

Sec. 26-56. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cable television committee means the body authorized to act for and on behalf of the city in matters relating to the day-to-day operation of the cable television system and otherwise authorized by this article. 
    Cablecasting means programming, exclusive of broadcast signals, carried on a cable television system, including programming of local origination, exclusive of broadcast signals carried on a cable television system over one or more channels. 
    Cable television system, cable TV system or CATV system means a system of antennas, cables, wires, lines, towers, wave guides or other conductors, convertors, equipment or facilities located within the city, designed and constructed for the purpose of producing, originating, receiving, transmitting, amplifying and distributing audio, video and other forms of electronic or electrical signals broadcast by one or more television stations to subscribing members of the public for a fixed or periodic fee, employing wires or cables passing along, over, under, across and/or upon streets, highways, alleys or other public places, including property over which the city has an easement or right-of-way, subject to the scope and limitations of such easement and rights-of-way. 
    Company means Harron Cablevision, a corporation qualified to do business in the state and/or its duly authorized assignees. 
    Customer service standards or customer service obligations mean those obligations specified by the Federal Communications Commission that the city may impose upon the company. Such imposition of customer service standards upon the grantee may be accomplished by the city through the passage of an appropriate resolution to that effect, enforcement provisions for these standards as shall be further set forth within this article. The terms "customer service standards" and "customer service obligations" shall be interchangeable when used within this article. 
    Federal Communications Commission or FCC means the federal agency constituted by the Communications Act of 1934, as amended. 
    Pre-existing franchise ordinance or franchise ordinance means the ordinances as adopted by the city setting forth the terms and conditions for obtaining a franchise to provide cable television service to the city including, but not limited to, Ordinance No. 112, adopted June 21, 1982, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 132, § 2, 10-4-93) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-57. - Adoption of customer service standards. 
    The city hereby adopts by reference those customer service standards promulgated by the Federal Communications Commission under that agency's obligation to regulate the delivery of cable television service, together with all definitions, specifications and regulations included in such customer service standards, except where such standards are exceeded in the favor of the city by the terms and conditions set forth within this chapter or within agreements between the city and any company granted a franchise, or within future modifications or agreements as may occur. The city reserves the right to unilaterally modify the terms and conditions of this franchise agreement or to clarify any customer service standards as may otherwise be allowed by law. 
(Ord. No. 132, § 3, 10-4-93) 
Sec. 26-58. - Renewal of franchise agreement. 
    In addition to all other obligations as have been set forth within the franchise ordinance for renewal of the franchise term, the company shall supply to the city a certification, in writing and signed by the person authorized by the company to execute such documentation, that the company has been in compliance with the customer service standards as adopted by the city. This certification shall be supplied to the city not less than 36 months prior to the expiration of the original franchise term. 
(Ord. No. 132, § 4, 10-4-93) 
Sec. 26-59. - Required services and facilities. 
    In addition to the services required within the franchise ordinance, the company shall supply all services required by the customer service standards as promulgated by the Federal Communications Commission and adopted by the city through resolution or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 132, § 5, 10-4-93) 
Sec. 26-60. - Failure to comply with customer service standards. 
    Notwithstanding any provisions to the contrary within the cable ordinance, the company's failure to fully comply with the customer service standards for a period in excess of 30 days during the terms of this franchise shall constitute a material breach of the franchise ordinance, and the city shall have just cause to commence revocation proceedings as set forth within section 9.10 of the franchise ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 132, § 6, 10-4-93) 
Sec. 26-61. - Consumer complaints as to violation of customer service standards. 
    The city council, through its cable television committee, shall have the authority to receive and evaluate complaints from all persons relative to any asserted violations of customer service standards and to utilize all procedures adopted within the context of the cable ordinance for purposes of implementation of these customer service standards including, but not limited to, the revocation of the franchise and/or the imposition of any penalties allowed by the cable ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 132, § 7, 10-4-93) 
Chapter 30 - CEMETERIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance number 4 adopted on January 24, 1908, pertaining to the municipal cemetery, although not printed in this Code, is saved from repeal and shall remain in full force and effect. Such ordinance is available for inspection in the office of the city clerk. 
State Law reference- Authority to acquire and maintain, MCL 128.1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 30-1-30-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OPERATION AND ADMINISTRATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 138, adopted Jan. 3, 1996, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ I-XXVI as a new art. II, §§ 30-26-30-51, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 30-26. - Title. 
    This article shall be known and cited as the "Cemetery Ordinance". 
(Ord. No. 138, § I, 1-3-96) 
Sec. 30-27. - Scope. 
    All cemeteries now owned, or which may hereafter be acquired by the city, wherever situated, are hereby declared to be public burying grounds, subject to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 138, § II, 1-3-96) 
Sec. 30-28. - Lots restricted for human bodies. 
    There shall be no interment of anything other than the remains of human bodies in cemeteries, and no interment of any deceased human shall be made in any other place than within cemeteries devoted to that purpose. 
(Ord. No. 138, § III, 1-3-96) 
Sec. 30-29. - Interment-Permit required. 
(a)  No interment shall be made in any cemetery belonging to the city except as hereby provided. 
(b)  The person desiring to make an interment in the cemetery shall provide a burial transmit permit, in writing, signed by him, to the city clerk, which shall contain, if obtainable, the full name of the deceased, his or her age, sex and residence at the time of death, the place of death, whether within the city or elsewhere, and the cause of death as certified by the medical attendant or coroner, and shall pay to the city clerk the amount(s) required for interment. 
(Ord. No. 138, § IV, 1-3-96) 
Sec. 30-30. - Council approval required for new cemeteries or expansion of existing nonpublic cemeteries. 
(a)  Effective with the adoption of this article, creation of a new cemetery or expansion of an existing, nonpublic cemetery beyond its current property lines shall require city council approval. Any person, persons, corporation or society intending to expand an existing, nonpublic cemetery shall submit plans for review by the city planning commission. The planning commission shall forward a recommendation of approval or disapproval for expansion to the city council. 
(b)  The opening and development of new sections of a city cemetery shall be approved by council resolution. The city council may set apart or reserve lots for the interment of strangers and indigents. 
(Ord. No. 138, § V, 1-3-96) 
Sec. 30-31. - Administration. 
(a)  The city manager shall be responsible to the city council for the efficient and proper management and control of all city-owned cemeteries. The city manager may delegate the responsibility for immediate supervision of operations, maintenance and administration to one or more designated supervisors. 
(b)  The city may contract with a private contractor to operate and maintain the cemetery after obtaining competitive bids. The private contractor shall be under the immediate jurisdiction of the city manager or his designate. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the city manager to advise and make recommendations to the city council for the purpose of improving cemetery management and operation. 
(Ord. No. 138, § VI, 1-3-96) 
Sec. 30-32. - Rules and regulations. 
(a)  The city manager may recommend rules and regulations for council adoption whenever, in his judgment, the best interests and safety of the public and the cemetery would be served. 
(b)  Every lot or grave sold is subject to the rules and regulations now in force or that may be hereafter adopted and to such changes of the present rules and regulations as are found necessary for the protection of lot owners and the remains of the dead. All rules and regulations currently in effect shall remain in effect until or unless amended by council resolution. 
(c)  Any violation of any rule or regulation governing city cemeteries shall be a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 138, § VII, 1-3-96) 
Sec. 30-33. - Cemetery fees and charges. 
(a)  Cemetery fees and charges shall be set by council by resolution. 
(b)  Council may set some or all cemetery fees and charges for nonresidents at a higher amount than those for residents. 
(c)  All cemetery fees and charges currently in effect shall remain in effect until or unless amended by council resolution. 
(Ord. No. 138, § VIII, 1-3-96) 
Sec. 30-34. - Purchase of lots. 
    Purchases of lots in the cemetery shall be made from the city clerk, and the purchasers shall acquire only the privilege of burial rights in the lot so purchased. The cost of any lot shall be paid in full at the time of purchase. No sale will be made of less than a complete lot according to the cemetery plans. 
(Ord. No. 138, § IX, 1-3-96) 
Sec. 30-35. - Certificates of ownership. 
    Ownership of a lot shall be evidenced by a certificate. Ownership certificates shall bear the name of the owner, lot number, number of graves, name of cemetery, and such other information as may be necessary, and shall be signed by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 138, § X, 1-3-96) 
Sec. 30-36. - Recording power to act. 
    Power to act for the owner of any lot shall be filed for record with the city clerk to become operative. 
(Ord. No. 138, § XI, 1-3-96) 
Sec. 30-37. - Burial designations. 
    The lot owner, or his legal representative, may at any time designate in writing whom he wishes buried in his lot or grave, forbid the burial of certain persons, and have a record made of such desire with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 138, § XII, 1-3-96) 
Sec. 30-38. - Transfer of ownership. 
(a)  Transfers shall be made upon application only. 
(b)  No transfer shall take place without proof of ownership which shall be evidenced by a certificate which shall be surrendered and a new certificate issued in the event of a transfer. 
(c)  The ownership of any lot shall not be fully effective until the records of the cemetery have been changed to show the new owner. 
(d)  In the absence of a written order to the contrary, the city shall, after the owner's death, honor a transfer of ownership by court order when presented for record with the city clerk. 
(e)  In cases where the owner is deceased and there is no estate to be probated, the heirs of the deceased may make application for transfer to the city clerk, and upon submission of satisfactory evidence approved by the city manager, the clerk shall issue a new certificate to the heirs entitled thereto. 
(Ord. No. 138, § XIII, 1-3-96) 
Sec. 30-39. - Lost or destroyed certificates. 
    In case of loss or destruction of a certificate of ownership, no new certificate shall be issued in lieu thereof except upon satisfactory proof to the city manager of such loss or destruction, and upon the giving of satisfactory security by bond or otherwise, against loss to the city, as may be required by the city manager. Any new such certificate shall be plainly marked "duplicate" upon its face. 
(Ord. No. 138, § XIV, 1-3-96) 
Sec. 30-40. - Perpetual care. 
(a)  Perpetual care is the general maintenance and care of burial units in the cemetery. 
(1)  The term "perpetual care" used in reference to burial units shall be held to mean the cutting of grass upon said burial unit at reasonable intervals, the raking and cleaning of the burial units at reasonable intervals, the pruning of shrubs and trees, and maintaining roadways, walkways, boundaries and maintenance buildings. 
(2)  The term "perpetual care" shall in no case be construed as meaning the maintenance, repair or replacement of any grave stones, monumental structures or memorials placed or erected on burial units; nor the planting or cost of flowers or ornamental plants; nor sprinkling said burial units with water; nor the maintenance or doing of any special or unusual work in the cemetery, such as filling depressions; nor does it mean the reconstruction of any marble, granite, bronze or concrete work on any burial unit in the cemetery, or other buildings or structures, made necessary by injuries caused by the elements, an act of God, common enemy, thieves, vandals, strikers, malicious mischief makers, explosives, unavoidable accidents, invasions, riots, resurrection, or by the order of any military or civil authority, whether the damage be direct or collateral, other than herein provided for. 
(b)  The City of Richmond does hereby bind itself, as a general obligation of the city, for the perpetual care of all existing and future burial plots and mausoleums located in the cemetery. 
(c)  The council resolution adopted May 11, 1964, creating the perpetual and annual care fund is hereby rescinded and the perpetual care fund is hereby dissolved. All monies in the perpetual care fund collected from the sale of burial plots shall be transferred to the cemetery fund and all monies collected from the sale of burial crypts and cremain niches shall be transferred to the mausoleum fund. Earned interest shall be transferred in the amounts as a percentage based on the principal amounts transferred to the cemetery fund and the mausoleum fund. Respectively, the money so transferred shall be used for directly related expenses for operation, maintenance, administration and improvements of the cemetery and mausoleum. 
(Ord. No. 138, § XV, 1-3-96; Ord. No. 138-1, § 1, 3-1-04) 
Sec. 30-41. - Performance of work. 
    The city reserves the right to have all foundations for monuments, headstones, markers, and plaques, and to have all excavations, the digging of graves, the grading and seeding of lots, and all other improvements and maintenance made upon the ground performed by city personnel or a private contractor under the direct control of the city. 
(Ord. No. 138, § XVI, 1-3-96; Ord. No. 138-1, § 1, 3-1-04) 
Sec. 30-42. - Orders and responsibilities. 
    Under no circumstances will the city assume responsibility for errors in opening graves when orders are given by telephone, and orders from undertakers for the opening of graves will be considered as orders from the lot owners. 
(Ord. No. 138, § XVII, 1-3-96) 
Sec. 30-43. - Protection to flowers, trees, markers, vases, etc. 
(a)  No person shall cut, remove, injure or carry away flowers, shrubs, trees, plants, vines, or any growing thing in or from any cemetery. 
(b)  The city reserves the right to trim or remove shrubs, trees or vines that become unsightly or become a nuisance to the safe passage of vehicles or equipment. 
(c)  No person shall deface, injure, disturb or write upon any marker, monument, headstone, fence or structure in any cemetery. 
(d)  No person shall injure, or destroy, take or carry away, any vase, flower pot, or other container or ornament that may have been placed in the cemetery, except such as were originally brought in by the person so removing them. 
(Ord. No. 138, § XVIII, 1-3-96) 
Sec. 30-44. - Entrances. 
    No person shall enter nor shall any vehicle be propelled or driven into any cemetery except through the established entrances thereof. 
(Ord. No. 138, § XIX, 1-3-96) 
Sec. 30-45. - Vehicle traffic. 
(a)  No vehicle of any description, city vehicles excluded, shall be driven or propelled in any cemetery except upon the portions of the roadways set aside for vehicular traffic. 
(b)  No vehicle shall be driven in any cemetery at any time at a speed greater than is reasonable and proper under all circumstances, and in no event in excess of 15 miles per hour. 
(Ord. No. 138, § XX, 1-3-96) 
Sec. 30-46. - Noise, disorderly conduct. 
    No person shall make any improper noise or disturbance or conduct himself in a disorderly manner within the limits of any cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 138, § XXI, 1-3-96) 
Sec. 30-47. - Refreshments, etc. 
    No person shall take any refreshment, food or intoxicating beverage of any kind within the boundary of any cemetery, except such food and temperate beverages as may be required by workers engaged therein. 
(Ord. No. 138, § XXII, 1-3-96) 
Sec. 30-48. - Firearms, explosives. 
    No person shall take any explosives within the boundary of any cemetery and no person shall discharge any firearms or explosives within the boundary of any cemetery, unless he or she is a police or peace officer on official duty, except that military or other organizations may carry arms therein for the purpose of firing a salute at the chapel burial service of a member of their organization or upon observance of memorial services. 
(Ord. No. 138, § XXIII, 1-3-96) 
Sec. 30-49. - Trespassing. 
    Walking or driving through any cemetery grounds to property or land outside of any cemetery for the purpose of saving time or distance is strictly prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 138, § XXIV, 1-3-96) 
Sec. 30-50. - Rubbish. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to leave or scatter rubbish within the confines of any cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 138, § XXV, 1-3-96) 
Sec. 30-51. - Violations. 
    Any person or customer found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof may be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00 for each violation and may be imprisoned in the county jail for a period of up to 90 days in the discretion of the court. Each day upon which a violation of the provisions of this article shall occur shall be deemed a separate and additional violation for the purpose of this article. 
(Ord. No. 138, § XXVI, 1-3-96) 
Chapter 34 - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 46; planning, ch. 62; taxation, ch. 86; zoning, app. A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. - TAX INCREMENT FINANCING PLAN[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Tax increment finance authority act, MCL 825.1801 et seq. 

Sec. 34-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. All other defined terms, unless the context of this article specifically requires otherwise, shall have the meanings given in the tax increment financing plan. 
    Act 450 means the tax increment finance authority act, Act No. 450 of Public Acts of Michigan of 1980 (MCL 125.1801 et seq.), as amended. 
    Captured assessed value means the amount in any year by which the current assessed value as finally equalized of all taxable property in the development area exceeds the initial assessed value, as more fully described in the tax increment financing plan. 
    Development area means the area described in exhibit A to the tax increment financing plan. 
    Development plan means the city development plan #1, as incorporated in exhibit B to the tax increment financing plan. 
    Initial assessed value means the most recently assessed value, as finally equalized by the state board of equalization, of all taxable property within the boundaries of the development area at the time of adoption of the ordinance from which this article has been derived, as more fully described in the tax increment financing plan. 
    Tax increment means that portion of the tax levy of all taxing jurisdictions paid each year on real and personal property in the development area on the captured assessed value, as more fully described in the tax increment finance plan. 
    Tax increment finance authority means the city tax increment finance authority. 
    Tax increment financing plan means the tax increment financing plan, including the development plan, as transmitted by the city council by the tax increment finance authority for public hearing, and as modified and confirmed by this article, copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk. 
    Taxing jurisdiction means each unit of government levying an ad valorem property tax on property in the development area. 
(Ord. No. 114, § I, 12-17-84) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 34-27. - Boundaries of development area. 
    The boundaries of the development area, as contained in the tax increment financing plan on file in the office of the city clerk, are hereby adopted and confirmed. 
(Ord. No. 114, § II, 12-17-84) 
Sec. 34-28. - Preparation of base year assessment roll. 
(a)  Within 60 days of the effective date of the ordinance from which this article has been derived, the city assessor shall prepare the base year assessment roll. The base year assessment roll shall list each taxing jurisdiction in which the development area is located, the initial assessed value of the development area on the effective date of the ordinance from which this article has been derived and the amount of tax revenue derived by each taxing jurisdiction from ad valorem taxes on the property in the development area. 
(b)  The city assessor shall transmit copies of the base year assessment roll to the city treasurer, the county treasurer, the tax increment finance authority, and each taxing jurisdiction together with a notice that the assessment roll has been prepared in accordance with this article and the tax increment financing plan approved by this article. 
(Ord. No. 114, § III, 12-17-84) 
Sec. 34-29. - Preparation of annual assessment roll. 
    Each year within 15 days following the final equalization of property in the development area, the city assessor shall prepare an updated annual assessment roll. The annual assessment roll shall show the information required in the base year assessment roll and, in addition, the captured assessed value for that year. Copies of the annual assessment roll shall be transmitted by the assessor to the same persons as the base year assessment roll, together with a notice that it has been prepared in accordance with this article and the tax increment financing plan. 
(Ord. No. 114, § IV, 12-17-84) 
Sec. 34-30. - Implementation. 
    All tax increments shall be transmitted by the city treasurer and the county treasurer to the city treasurer for the account of tax increment finance authority at the earliest practicable date. All tax increments so received by the tax increment finance authority shall be disbursed in accordance with the provisions of the development plan and the requisitions of the tax increment finance authority. For the purposes of segregation and transfer of such funds, the city treasurer shall maintain a separate fund which shall be kept in a depository bank account to be designated the city TIFA fund. All amounts payable to the tax increment finance authority shall, subject to the provisions of this section, be deposited directly in the project fund. 
(Ord. No. 114, § V, 12-17-84) 
Sec. 34-31. - Duration of tax increment financing plan. 
    The tax increment financing plan will continue in effect until all purposes of the development plan have been fulfilled. 
(Ord. No. 114, § VI, 12-17-84) 
Chapter 38 - ELECTIONS[1] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 38-1. - Election precincts; boundaries. 
    The city shall consist of one ward, and the ward shall contain two election precincts, the geographical boundaries of which are as follows: 
(1)  Precinct No. 1. All areas of the city north of the centerline of Division Street (32 Mile Road). 
(2)  Precinct No. 2. All areas of the city south of the centerline of Division Street (32 Mile Road). 
(Ord. No. 130, § I, 8-16-93) 
Charter reference- Wards and precincts, § 5.3. 
Sec. 38-2. - Odd-numbered year elections.

(b)  Date of city office election. The date of the general election for city offices shall be held on the Tuesday succeeding the first Monday in November in every odd-numbered year. 
(c)  Nominations. Nomination for the election to city office shall be as prescribed in the city charter. 
(d)  Terms; organizational meeting: 
(1)  The term of office of all councilmen elected in the city shall be for two years. 
(2)  All councilmembers shall be elected at the November general election defined herein, for two years. 
(3)  An organizational meeting shall be held on the Monday following each regular city election. 
(Ord. No. 91, §§ 1, 2, 3, 5, 3-29-71) 
Chapter 42 - EMERGENCY SERVICES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 50; snow and storm emergencies, § 90-76 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 42-1-42-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ALARM SYSTEMS 

Sec. 42-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm system means any mechanical or electrical device which activates, emits a sound or transmits a signal or message to which the police may be summoned directly or indirectly to respond. An alarm system is designed for use for one or any combination of the following: the detection of an unlawful entry, or attempted unlawful entry into a building, structure or facility and the alerting of others of the commission of an unlawful act within a building, structure or facility. 
    Alarm user means any owner or occupant who has physical control over the premises where an alarm system is installed within the city, except for alarm systems on a motor vehicle. However, if an alarm system on a motor vehicle is connected to an alarm system at a premises, the person using and/or operating such vehicle is an alarm user. Excluded from this definition and coverage of this article are persons who use self-contained alarm systems (i.e., a system which signals or alerts other authorized persons who are on the premises of an attempted unauthorized intrusion, or holdup attempt).
