However, if such a system employs an audible signal emitting sounds, flashing light or beacon designed to signal persons outside the premises, such system shall be within the definition of an alarm system and shall be subject to this article. 
    False alarm means a bell, mechanical, electrical or telephone apparatus, or combination thereof, which is activated for the purpose of summoning the city police department to respond to a holdup, break-in, burglary, unauthorized entry, destruction of property or other event requiring police response when in fact the service called for is not needed shall be deemed a false alarm within the meaning of this article. 
    Twelve-month period means the period commencing on June 20 and the same date of each following calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 126, § 1, 5-20-91) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 42-27. - Payment of fee required for false alarms; amounts set by council resolution. 
    To defray the cost of responding to false alarms and to discourage the continuation of repeat false alarms, the alarm user shall be assessed a false alarm fee by the city for each false alarm. The amount to be charged for each false alarm shall be set by resolution of the city council and may provide that there be no charge for the first and second false alarms within any 12-month period. 
(Ord. No. 126, § 2, 5-20-91) 
Sec. 42-28. - Exceptions to false alarm charge. 
    Each of the following circumstances shall not constitute a false alarm and no fee shall be assessed: 
(1)  Alarm system malfunctions, provided that corrective measures have been instituted within 72 hours after the alarm and notification and proof of such corrective measures is immediately provided to the city police department. 
(2)  Alarm conditions activated by a person working on the system (i.e., system testing), provided that prior notification to the city police department has been given. 
(3)  Alarms which the alarm user can substantiate as being activated by disruption or disturbance of utility company facilities, by a motor vehicle or by storm conditions; and such disruption or disturbance is outside the control of the alarm user. 
(Ord. No. 126, § 3, 5-20-91) 
Sec. 42-29. - Appeal of false alarm charge. 
    Any alarm user may appeal the charging of a false alarm fee to the city council. Such appeal shall be in writing, and served upon the city clerk within ten calendar days after notification of assessment. 
(Ord. No. 126, § 4, 5-20-91) 
Sec. 42-30. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Beginning with the third and any subsequent false alarms in a 12-month period, the police officer responding to such alarm may issue an appearance ticket to the alarm user in the amount set forth by the city council resolution, as provided in section 42-27. 
(Ord. No. 126, § 5, 5-20-91) 
Sec. 42-31. - Failure to pay fee for false alarm. 
    Failure of an alarm user to remit payment of a false alarm fee may, at the option of the city, result in the commencement of a civil action for collection of the fee. 
(Ord. No. 126, § 6, 5-20-91) 
Sec. 42-32. - Monitoring services. 
(a)  The city council may assess the alarm user a fee to provide monitoring services. The amount to be charged for monitoring services shall be set by resolution of the city council. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any provision hereof, nothing in this section shall be construed as requiring the city to maintain monitoring services or to enter into any agreement to monitor any alarm system. Monitoring services existing on June 20, 1991, may be discontinued upon reasonable notice from the city to the alarm user. 
(Ord. No. 126, § 7, 5-20-91) 
Chapter 46 - ENVIRONMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22; community development, ch. 34; zoning, app. A. 
State Law reference- Air pollution act, MCL 336.11 et seq.; environmental protection act, MCL 691.1201 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 46-1-46-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AIR POLLUTION 

Sec. 46-26. - Open burning of grass clippings and leaves prohibited. 
    The open burning of grass clippings and leaves is prohibited within the city. 
(Ord. No. 123, § I, 9-24-90) 
Sec. 46-27. - Open burning of other materials. 
    Only the burning of grass clippings and leaves is prohibited under the provisions of this article. Burning of all other materials and substances within the city is hereby expressly stated to be under the control of other applicable ordinances of the city, or under applicable laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 123, § II, 9-24-90) 
Secs. 46-28-46-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NOISE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 46-51. - Noise-producing devices declared nuisance. 
    The operating or maintaining of noise-making, noise-amplifying or noise-producing instrument or device by which the peace or good order of the neighborhood is disturbed is hereby declared a nuisance. No person shall operate or maintain any radio, phonograph, noise-making, noise-amplifying or noise-producing instrument or device in any public or private place in any manner by which the peace and good order of the neighborhood is disturbed or persons occupying property in the neighborhood are disturbed or annoyed, except by special permit from the city council. 
(Ord. No. 92, § 20, 10-25-71) 
Secs. 46-52-46-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONSTRUCTION NOISE 

Sec. 46-61. - Construction noises declared nuisance. 
    The erection, construction, demolition, alteration, or repair of any building, lands, or rights-of-way located within 300 feet at the closest point of the property or right-of-way line of the subject site from any residentially zoned property shall be prohibited between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:30 a.m. unless a permit to conduct such activities during nighttime hours is granted by the city manager or, in the case of work performed by the city or its agents, the work is determined by the city manager or a department director to be necessary. 
(Ord. No. 152, § 1, 1-6-03) 
Sec. 46-62. - Violations. 
    Any person, firm, or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject for each offense to a fine of not more than $500.00 or imprisonment in the county jail for a period not to exceed 90 days, or both such fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the court, together with the costs of such prosecution. 
(Ord. No. 152, § 1, 1-6-03) 
Sec. 46-63. - Public nuisance per se. 
    Any noise created in violation of this article is hereby declared to be a public nuisance per se and may be abated by order of any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 152, § 1, 1-6-03) 
Sec. 46-64. - Separate offenses. 
    Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of a separate offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be liable for the fines and imprisonment herein provided. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during which, or when, a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 152, § 1, 1-6-03) 
Sec. 46-65. - Rights and remedies cumulative. 
    The rights and remedies provided herein are cumulative and in addition to any other remedies provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 152, § 1, 1-6-03) 
Secs. 46-66-46-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - NUISANCES 

Sec. 46-71. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Nuisance means any person doing an unlawful act or omitting to perform a duty, or suffering or permitting any condition or thing to be or exist, which act, omission, condition or thing either: 
(1)  Injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health or safety of others; 
(2)  Offends decency; 
(3)  Is offensive to the senses; 
(4)  Unlawfully interferes with, obstructs or tends to obstruct or renders dangerous for passage any public or private street, highway, sidewalk, stream, ditch or drainage; 
(5)  In any way renders other persons insecure in life or the use of property; or 
(6)  Essentially interferes with the comfortable enjoyment of life and property, or tends to depreciate the value of the property of others. 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 46-72. - Prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, permit, maintain or allow the creation or maintenance of a nuisance. 
Sec. 46-73. - Illustrative enumeration. 
    The maintaining, using, placing, depositing, leaving or permitting to be or remain on any public or private property of any of the following items, conditions or actions are hereby declared to be and constitute a nuisance; provided, however, that this enumeration shall not be deemed or construed to be conclusive, limiting or restrictive: 
(1)  Noxious weeds and other rank vegetation. 
(2)  The storage upon any property of building materials unless there is in force a valid building permit issued by the city for construction upon such property and such building materials are intended for use in connection with such construction. Building materials shall include but shall not be limited to lumber, bricks, concrete or cinder blocks, plumbing materials, electrical wiring or equipment, shingles, mortar, concrete or cement, nails, screws, or any other materials used in constructing any structure. All unused building materials shall be removed from the premises by the contractor prior to issuance of any occupancy permit or final acceptance by the building inspector. 
(3)  The storage or accumulation of junk, trash, rubbish or refuse of any kind, except domestic refuse stored in such a manner as not to create a nuisance. The term "junk" shall include parts of machinery or motor vehicles, unused stoves or other appliances stored in the open, remnants of wood, metal or any other material or other cast-off material of any kind whether or not the same could be put to any reasonable use. 
(4)  Storage on any property of junk vehicles except in a completely enclosed building. For the purposes of this article the term "junk vehicles" shall include any motor vehicle which is inoperative for any reason such as being in a state of disassembly, disrepair, stripped, dismantled, unregistered or unlicensed. 
(5)  The existence of any structure or damaged partial structure which because of fire, wind or other natural disaster, or physical deterioration is no longer habitable if a dwelling, nor useful for any other purpose for which it may have been intended. 
(6)  The existence of any vacant building, garage or other outbuilding unless such buildings are kept securely locked, windows kept glazed or neatly boarded up and otherwise protected to prevent entrance thereto by vandals. 
(7)  The existence of any incomplete structures unless such structure is in the course of construction in accordance with a valid and subsisting building permit issued by the city and unless such construction is completed within a reasonable time. 
(8)  Any condition which provides harborage for rats, mice, snakes and other vermin. 
(9)  All unnecessary or unauthorized noises and annoying vibrations, including animal noises. 
(10)  All disagreeable or obnoxious odors and stenches, as well as the conditions, substances or other causes which give rise to the emission or generation of such odors and stenches. 
(11)  The carcasses of animals or fowl not disposed of within a reasonable time after death. 
(12)  The pollution of any public well or cistern, stream, lake, canal or body of water by sewage, dead animals, creamery, industrial wastes or other substances. 
(13)  Any building, structure or other place or location where any activity which is in violation of local, state or federal law is conducted, performed or maintained. 
(14)  Any accumulation of stagnant water permitted or maintained on any lot or piece of ground. 
(15)  Dense smoke, noxious fumes, gas, soot or cinders, in unreasonable quantities. 
Sec. 46-74. - Notice to abate. 
    Whenever a nuisance is found to exist within the city, the city manager shall give ten days' written notice to the owner or occupant of the property upon which the nuisance exists or upon the person causing or maintaining the nuisance. 
Sec. 46-75. - Contents of notice. 
    The notice to abate a nuisance issued under the provisions of this article shall contain: 
(1)  An order to abate the nuisance or to request a hearing within a stated time, which shall be reasonable under the circumstances. 
(2)  The location of the nuisance, if the nuisance is stationary. 
(3)  A description of what constitutes the nuisance. 
(4)  A statement of acts necessary to abate the nuisance. 
(5)  A statement that if the nuisance is not abated as directed and no request for hearing is made within the prescribed time, the city will abate such nuisance and assess the cost thereof against such person. 
Sec. 46-76. - Service of notice. 
    The notice to abate a nuisance shall be served as any other legal process may be served pursuant to law. 
Sec. 46-77. - Abatement by city. 
    Upon the failure of the person upon whom notice to abate a nuisance was served pursuant to the provisions of this article to abate the nuisance, the city shall proceed to abate such nuisance and shall prepare a statement of costs incurred in the abatement thereof. 
Sec. 46-78. - Emergency abatement by city. 
    When, in the opinion of the city manager there is actual and immediate danger to the public or occupants of a particular premises caused by a nuisance on such premises, the city manager is hereby authorized and empowered, without any notice or hearing to order and require such premises to be vacated. The city manager shall immediately post the premises warning of the dangerous condition, and shall then abate such nuisance and prepare a statement of costs incurred in the abatement thereof. 
Sec. 46-79. - City's costs. 
    Any and all costs incurred by the city in the abatement of a nuisance under the provisions of this article shall constitute a lien against the property upon which such nuisance existed, which costs shall be collected as ad valorem taxes. 
Sec. 46-80. - Violation and penalties. 
    The violation of any provision of this article by any firm, corporation, person or persons, or anyone acting on behalf of said person, persons, firm or corporation, is a municipal civil infraction, for which the fine shall be not less than $75.00 for the first offense, not less than $100.00 for any offense which is a first repeat offense, and not less than $250.00 for any offense for which is a second repeat offense or any subsequent repeat offense, plus, in all cases, the costs and other sanctions allowed by law or ordinance. 
(1)  The imposition of any sentence shall not exempt the offender from compliance with the requirements of this article. 
(2)  Any violation of this article is a nuisance per say and may be abated by the circuit court through injunctive relief. 
(3)  For purposes of this section the term "subsequent offense" shall mean a violation of the provisions of this article committed by the same person, firm, corporation, or anyone acting on behalf of said person, firm or corporation within 365 calendar days of a previous violation of the same provision for which the person, firm, corporation, or anyone acting on behalf of said person, firm or corporation admitted responsibility or was found responsible by the court. 
(4)  Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. Offenses committed on subsequent days within a period of seven calendar days following the issuance of a citation for a first offense shall all be considered separate first offenses. 
(Ord. No. 106-1, 1-21-11) 
Secs. 46-81-46-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OIL AND GAS 

Sec. 46-101. - Business of oil and gas acquisition, production and storage deemed hazardous. 
(a)  The business and occupation of drilling and exploring for, producing, obtaining, transporting, gathering and storing of oil, gas, petroleum and hydrocarbons within the corporate limits of the city is hereby deemed a hazardous and dangerous business and occupation. It is deemed necessary that such business and occupation be regulated, controlled and limited for the purpose of providing protection for the lives, health, welfare and safety of the citizens of the city and of the public generally and for the protection of property from the danger of fire, explosion, gas, leaks, nuisances and other hazards injurious to the public peace, health, welfare and safety. 
(b)  The provisions of this article shall be deemed to be the minimum requirements for the preservation of the public peace, health, safety and welfare, and compliance with all terms thereof shall not be deemed to relieve any person from any duty imposed by law to use all necessary care and take all necessary precautions for the safeguarding of the public peace, health and safety and the rights of any individual or group of individuals. It shall be the duty of any person drilling, operating or maintaining any well to use all necessary care and take all precautions of whatsoever nature which shall be reasonably necessary under the circumstances to protect the public or the rights of any part thereof. 
(c)  Words used in this article, unless otherwise defined, shall have the common meaning of such words as generally understood in the oil and gas industry, unless the content in this article clearly implies otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 69, §§ I, VIII, 5-8-61) 
Sec. 46-102. - Permit-Required for drilling well. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drill, explore, or commence to drill any well for oil, gas, petroleum or other hydrocarbons in any area within the corporate limits of the city or for the secondary recovery thereof, or to extend to deepen one already drilled, without first having applied for and receiving a permit therefor by the authority of the common council in accordance with the terms of this article and the application having complied with the terms of this article and the applicant having complied with the following requirements. 
(Ord. No. 69, § II, 5-8-61) 
Sec. 46-103. - Same-Application; fee; contents of application. 
    The producer or owner of any proposed well shall fill out, sign and file an application in writing therefor to the city clerk, accompanied with a filing fee of $500.00. The application shall contain the information as to the location where the proposed well is to be drilled, and attached thereto shall be a map, plat or survey of the area to be drilled and the location of the well on the spacing and the exact location of tanks, flowlines, fences and details incident to the proposed location. The location of the well shall be stated in relation to established street or plat lines, or in lieu thereof quarter section lines. The application shall show the names of the owners of the oil and gas in all of the area to be drilled and the lease thereon. The application shall also be accompanied by the consent in writing of the owner of the site to be drilled consenting to the drilling of the well on his property. Attached to the application shall be duly certified, sworn or photostatic copies of all leases for the discovery and removal of oil and gas and ratifications thereof executed by the owners of the oil or gas in such area owned or controlled by the application, and also a statement of other leases insofar as are known, setting forth the names of the lessors and lessee of each such respective lease. If the lease shall by express terms and provisions provide for and consent to such drilling, the consent therein provided shall qualify for and be deemed sufficient compliance with the requirements for consent of lessor as provided in this section. Bond as set forth in section 46-106 shall also accompany and be filed with such application. 
(Ord. No. 69, § IIA, 5-8-61) 
Sec. 46-104. - Same-Proof of ownership or control of area to be drilled required. 
    It shall be made to appear, either upon the face of such application or by other satisfactory proof, that the applicant for permission to drill a well for oil and gas is the owner of or has under his control, either as owner or lessee, or both, all interests in the area to be drilled, and if the application shows compliance with the requirements set forth by this article the council may grant the permit without further notice. 
(Ord. No. 69, § IIB, 5-8-61) 
Sec. 46-105. - Same-Hearing procedure if applicant does not own or control area to be drilled. 
(a)  Hearing. If the application shows that the applicant to drill a well for oil or gas is not the owner or does not have under his control for drilling purposes as owner or lessee, or both, or assignee under a valid and recorded assignment of lease, all the interest in all the oil or gas in the area which it is proposed to drill, or in the event the council shall for other cause shown refuse an application for a permit, then the council shall fix a time and place for the hearing thereon and enter the same of record. The applicant shall thereupon cause notice of such hearing on forms to be furnished by the city clerk to be given by certified mail to all known owners of the lands containing oil and gas within the area to be drilled and the lessees thereof under valid oil and gas leases of record addressed to their last known place of residence, not less than seven days prior to the date of the hearing. In addition thereto, the applicant shall publish a notice in a public newspaper published and printed in the city at least five days prior to the hearing and shall post notices thereof in not less than five public places in the city at least five days prior to the hearing. 
(b)  Contents of notice; affidavit. Such notices shall be dated and contain a description of the property affected, and state the time, date, place and purpose of the hearing. An affidavit of the applicant or someone in his behalf shall be executed showing such mailing, posting and publishing and shall be prima facie evidence of the compliance with the requirements of this article for notice. The affidavit shall be filed with the city clerk at or prior to the time set for hearing. 
(c)  Conduct of hearing. The council shall at the time set and place designated in the notice, or to some later date to which the hearing may be adjourned, conduct the hearing upon the application to drill such well for oil, gas, petroleum or other hydrocarbons. At such hearing all persons interested may be heard. The council shall keep a record of its proceedings as regards the granting of the permits and the hearings thereon and may require the pooling of properties or parts thereof within the area or areas to be drilled and shall make any and all reasonable requirements necessary to protect and safeguard the rights of all parties affected by such order. The council shall have the power and reserves the authority to refuse any application for a permit whereby the reason for the location of the proposed well and the character and value of the permanent improvements already erected in or adjacent to the area in question and the use to which the land and surroundings are adapted for civic purposes or for sanitary reasons, the drilling of any oil or gas well will be serious disadvantage or hazard to the city and its inhabitants as a whole. It shall be discretionary with the council to grant or deny a permit in any industrial area or in any area in which residences or other buildings may have been erected when the granting of the permit shall be creative of fire hazards or otherwise destructive of property interests. 
(Ord. No. 69, § IIC, 5-8-61) 
Sec. 46-106. - Same-Bond required. 
(a)  The application shall also be accompanied by, and no permit for the drilling of any well shall be issued without, a duly executed bond given by the applicant as principal and executed by some bonding or indemnity company authorized to do business in the state as surety, running to the city for the benefit of the city and all persons concerned, conditioned that if the permit is granted, the applicant and his assigns will comply with the terms and conditions of this article in the drilling and operation of the proposed well and that the applicant will pay and discharge any liability imposed by law for damages on account of injury to property, either public or private, or bodily injury or death received or suffered by any person and resulting from the drilling operation or maintenance of any well or any structures, equipment, machinery, lines or appurtenances thereto used or allowed in the drilling or producing operation, and for clearing from the area to be drilled all litter, machinery, derricks, trenches, pits, debris, oil and other substances used thereon in the drilling or producing operations whenever the well shall be abandoned or the operation thereof discontinued. The maximum total liability under the bond for loss or damage either to person or property shall be in the amount of $200,000.00. The bond shall be made for a term of not less than one year, and a new bond shall be furnished at the expiration of any existing one if the operation of such well covered thereby is continued. 
(b)  If at the time of such renewal all drilling on such well has been completed, the amount of total liability under such bond may be reduced to $50,000.00. If any bond required in this section shall lapse or become void for any reason whatsoever, the permit issued under the terms of this article shall immediately become inoperative and void until a new bond shall have been provided and filed with the city clerk or the existing bond reinstated in full force, and such well and the drilling operations and production thereunder shall be shut down, suspended and discontinued until the filing of such new bond or reinstatement of such existing bond. Each and every bond, both original and renewal shall be approved by the council and shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 69, § IID, 5-8-61) 
Sec. 46-107. - Same-Application fees; refund; completion fee. 
(a)  All applicants for a permit to drill a well for oil or gas shall at the time of making such applications pay to the city clerk the sum of $500.00 as an application fee to apply on the cost and expenses of the administration of this article, of which amount $400.00 thereof shall be refunded if the application is not granted and the balance retained. 
(b)  On January 2, after the completion of any producing well and annually thereafter so long as production of oil or gas continues from such well, the owner of each of the wells shall pay to the city clerk the sum of $100.00 to apply on the cost and expense of the administration of this article. 
(Ord. No. 69, § IIE, 5-8-61) 
Sec. 46-108. - Same-Commencement of drilling period; termination. 
(a)  When a permit shall have been issued, the permit shall terminate and become inoperative without any action on the part of the council unless within 60 days from the date of the issue actual drilling of the well shall have been commenced, and after the drilling of a well shall be commenced the cessation of drilling for 60 days or the cessation of production of oil or gas from the well after production of oil or gas from the well shall have commenced, shall operate to terminate and cancel the permit, and the well shall be considered as abandoned for all purposes of this article. It shall be unlawful thereafter to continue the operation, reworking or drilling of such well without the issuance of another permit upon a new application as provided in this article. 
(b)  There may be granted additional periods of 60 days each, but not to exceed three in number, upon application by the permittee to the council requesting such extension and good and reasonable cause therein shown for the cessation of drilling or cessation of production as provided in subsection (a) of this section beyond the reasonable control of the permittee or his operator. 
(Ord. No. 69, § IIF, 5-8-61) 
Sec. 46-109. - Same-Copy sent to state supervisor of wells; posted. 
    A copy of the permit so granted shall be forwarded by the city clerk by certified mail to the state supervisor of wells, and a copy thereof posted at the location of such well. 
(Ord. No. 69, § IIG, 5-8-61) 
Sec. 46-110. - Same-Suspension. 
    The chief of the fire department, or the city manager or such other employee of the city who shall be designated city supervisor of wells, is hereby granted the authority to suspend the permit for the operation of any well where any of the provisions of this article, or any amendments thereto, are violated, which suspension of any such license shall be effective until such time as the licensee shall comply with the provisions of this article. Before suspending any such license, the city clerk shall cause written notice to be served upon the permittee advising such permittee that a hearing will be had at a time and place fixed in the notice to determine whether the permit held by such permittee shall be suspended. Five days' notice of the time of the hearing shall be given. It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to operate any well during any period in which the permit covering the operation of such well is so suspended. The provisions of this section shall in no way limit or interfere with the enforcement of the penalties for the violation of ordinances generally, but shall be cumulative and in addition to such penalties. 
(Ord. No. 69, § IIH, 5-8-61) 
Sec. 46-111. - Location and spacing of wells. 
(a)  The minimum drilling unit for the permittee to drill any well for the discovery or production of oil or gas shall be in accordance with spacing orders established by the state department of conservation for the area, subject to limitations set forth in this section. 
(b)  The drilling location of any well shall in no instance be nearer than 300 feet from any street line, alley line or railroad right-of-way line. 
(c)  The drilling location of any well shall in each instance be at least 300 feet from the location of any building of the value in excess of $500.00 existent at the time of commencement of actual drilling operations. 
(d)  No well shall be located within any of the streets, alleys, or rights-of-way of the city, or so located as to block or incumber or obstruct the use of any street, alley or right-of-way in any drilling or producing operations, except by previous consent having been given by order of the city supervisor of wells, and in such event for the limited period only. 
(e)  If it shall appear from the application on file and after notice and hearing thereon as in section 46-105, provided that the limitation and restrictions established in this section will preclude drilling and operating in an area which should reasonably be drilled and operated, the council shall be authorized and empowered to make exception from such limitations and restrictions. 
(Ord. No. 69, § III, 5-8-61) 
Sec. 46-112. - Production and operation. 
(a)  Precautions and standard equipment and procedures to be utilized. In drilling for oil and gas, petroleum or other hydrocarbons and the production thereof, the permittee shall use every precaution, equipment and materials in accordance with approved methods of operation, drilling, and production to stop and prevent waste of oil, gas, petroleum or hydrocarbons and to protect residents and properties of the city, and therein shall equip and operate the well and all allied equipment therewith of standard design and quality as are in common use in the petroleum industry. All such equipment shall be installed and maintained in accordance with standard drilling producing and operating practices. 
(b)  Fencing of drilling operation. From the time of placing any equipment, derricks, riggings, or other drilling equipment or supplies until the time of removal thereof upon final completion of the well, each location of the well shall be completely surrounded by fencing in order to completely surround and enclose the drilling operation. Such fence shall be supported by steel posts and shall be of woven wire of not less than 14-gauge wire with mesh of not less than two inches nor more than four inches and shall be at least six feet high. 
(c)  Erection and location of flares; fencing. All flares erected within the corporate limits of the city shall be at least 300 feet from any building or structure and shall extend at least 20 feet above the surface of the ground. All such flares shall be of approved construction and shall be installed in a pit of sufficient depth and area to provide adequate drainage and safety precautions. The location of all such flares shall be completely enclosed by steel fencing of the same type and dimensions as provided in subsection (b) of this section for enclosing the drilling operation. 
(d)  Use of portable slush pit required. In all cases where an oil and gas well is being drilled in a residentially zoned area, the drilling operator shall use a portable slush pit and all slush and waste shall be deposited therein and from time to time removed beyond the corporate limits of the city for disposal. No open pits for the disposal of slush, brine or salt water shall be permitted at any time after the completion of the drilling operation in any area of the city. 
(e)  Disposal of brine or salt water. All brine or salt water produced in the drilling for or production of oil shall, under the supervision of the state supervisor of wells, be returned to some underground formation or otherwise disposed of in order that such brine, salt water or refuse shall not do damage to any fresh water, wells, lakes, ponds or rivers. 
(f)  Well enclosure to be kept clean; free of inflammables. The person in charge of the producing operations of a well shall keep the fenced enclosure around such well free of all trash and inflammable substances not necessary in the operation of such well and shall keep the weeds cut and otherwise keep the location in a clean and orderly condition. Machinery and equipment not used in the operation of the well shall not be stored or left in such enclosure. All oil tanks shall be painted or galvanized. 
(g)  Removal of mud or fluid from well; notification of fire chief. Except in emergency, at least six hours before any mud or fluid in any well shall be removed, swabbed, baled or otherwise cleaned out, the chief of the fire department or other officer in charge shall be served with written notice of the hour that such cleaning, swabbing or bailing is done, and if in his opinion the cleaning, swabbing or bailing shall be hazardous to the safety of life or property, he is hereby authorized to stop or prevent such cleaning, swabbing or bailing until such time as conditions may become favorable to continue the same. It shall be unlawful to commence the testing of any well from sundown until sunrise, or during a period when gas may settle on the ground or during any electrical storm. Before bringing in a well, all of the control devices including master gates and safety valves shall be tested and shall be in good working order and shall comply with the provisions of this article. 
(h)  Drilling procedure for Salina-Niagara formation. Prior to entering the top of the Salina-Niagara formation, the drilling shall be done with mud-laden fluids of such weight and viscosity as shall be required by and under good drill practices in the area in which such drilling is being done. 
(Ord. No. 69, § IV, 5-8-61) 
Sec. 46-113. - Equipment. 
(a)  Separator. Each well shall have a separator capable of caring adequately for the production of the well, and both oil and gas without spraying oil through a separator vent line. No gas shall be produced, wasted or allowed to escape through a separator vent line from any well. When it shall appear that an explosive mixture of gas may be accumulating near the ground, the designated city officer in charge may require that the well be shut down until such gas is dissipated. 
(b)  Storage tanks within corporate limits. No tank or other facility for the storage of oil, gas, petroleum or hydrocarbons produced from any well within the corporate limits of the city shall be kept, erected or maintained within the corporate limits of the city except in areas zoned as industrial and agricultural areas where such storage tanks shall be allowed. Such storage tanks shall be erected without the corporate limits of the city, except for such installation in industrially and agriculturally zoned areas, and shall be connected to any well by pipes or pipelines by the nearest possible route. 
(c)  Storage tanks in industrial and agricultural zones. All tanks for the storage of oil permitted to be installed in industrially and agriculturally zoned areas shall be located in a pit and encircled by an embankment and fire wall with a capacity of 11/2 times the capacity of the tank. No tank shall be located nearer than 300 feet from any building or industrial structure. 
(d)  Pipes and pipelines. All pipes or pipelines leading to or from a well location shall be buried underground to a minimum depth of 24 inches below normal surface of the ground and before a pipe line is laid in, down or along a street, the person or company laying such line shall deposit with the city treasurer the sum of $0.30 per foot for the laying of such line, and in the construction of such lines the permittee shall pay to the city all damages sustained by it by reason of the construction of the lines and the repair of any streets crossed by or extending along such pipelines in an amount sufficient to place the city property in the same condition as prior to the laying of the lines and shall pay to the city any and all damage incident to the taking up or repairing of the lines thereafter. No concrete or asphalt paving shall be cut or disturbed unless absolutely necessary, and then only under the supervision of the city. The permittee shall be required to replace and repair the paving at his own expense and under the supervision of the city manager. 
(e)  Rigs and heavy machinery; moving permit required. No rigs or heavy machinery used in connection with the drilling or operation of wells in the city shall be moved over city streets from one location to another without obtaining a permit therefor, which permit shall set forth the streets which may be used for the purpose and the same shall be transported under the supervision of the city manager. 
(f)  Pumping units. All pumping units installed shall be electrically operated and properly housed and so enclosed as to protect the public therefrom. All electrical switches and electrical outlets shall be enclosed and shall be explosion proof. 
(Ord. No. 69, § V, 5-8-61) 
Sec. 46-114. - Restoration; abandonment. 
(a)  Plugging upon abandonment. Upon the discontinuance of the drilling operations or the production of any oil or gas from any working well, the well shall be abandoned and plugged under the supervision of the state supervisor of wells. 
(b)  Commencement of plugging. All plugging operations on all dry or abandoned wells shall commence within 60 days after drilling production operations shall have ceased and shall be carried through forthwith to completion. 
(c)  Filling pits and cellars. The permittee shall fill all pits and cellars with dirt and level off the surface and restore the pits and cellars as nearly as possible to its condition prior to the commencement of the drilling operation. All equipment shall be removed from the location promptly, and all machinery, tanks, pipes and tools shall be transported from the well site, embankments leveled, and the surface of the land restored to its former condition. 
(d)  Removal of substances contributing to fire or pollution hazard. The permittee shall not permit any undue accumulation of slush, salt water or oil or any other offensive or dangerous substances to accumulate and upon the completion of the well shall remove and eliminate all debris and eliminate all conditions and circumstances contributing to the hazard of fire or pollution. 
(Ord. No. 69, § VI, 5-8-61) 
Sec. 46-115. - Deepening, reworking of well. 
    If any person, owner, producer or operator shall desire to deepen or extend a well below the depth of its original objective, he shall make application to the council as if an original application for a permit were taken. In such deepening and reworking, the same precautions shall be complied with as set forth in this article. If such application for reworking or deepening shall be filed within 60 days from the date of the completion or abandonment of the original drilling operation, a fee of $200.00 rather than of $500.00 shall be required. 
(Ord. No. 69, § VII, 5-8-61) 
Sec. 46-116. - Compliance and abatement. 
(a)  The chief of the fire department or the city manager, city supervisor of wells or such other employee of the city as shall be designated for that purpose by the council shall have the right and privilege at any time to enter upon the premises covered by any permit issued under this article for the purpose of making inspections thereof to determine if the requirements of this article are complied with, or the requirements of any other ordinance of the city met relating to the health, welfare and safety of persons within the city. 
(b)  All drilling operations for the discovery of oil, gas, petroleum or other hydrocarbons, equipping of wells, producing and marketing of oil, gas, petroleum and hydrocarbons, plugging of wells and all material used and work done in connection with the exploring for, producing and marketing of petroleum products shall be in conformity with all state and federal laws and statutes and rules and regulations pertaining thereto and particularly with the state statutes and the regulations of the state supervisor of wells. 
Secs. 46-117-46-135. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - BLIGHT 

Sec. 46-136. - Purpose of article. 
    The purpose of this article is to preserve and protect the public health, safety and general welfare of persons and property within the city by preventing, reducing and/or eliminating blight and potential blight in the city by the prevention and elimination of certain environmental and other causes of blight or blighting factors which exist or which may in the future exist within the city. 
(Ord. No. 106, § 2, 4-10-80) 
Sec. 46-137. - Enabling authority. 
    This article is adopted in accordance with and pursuant to Act No. 344 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1945 (MCL 128.71 et seq.), as amended, and in accordance with and pursuant to the city Charter. 
(Ord. No. 106, § 3, 4-10-80) 
Sec. 46-138. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building materials means, but shall not be limited to, lumber, bricks, concrete or order blocks, plumbing materials, electrical wiring or equipment, heating ducts or equipment, shingles, mortar, concrete or cement, structural or miscellaneous steel, nails, screws, or any other materials used in building or constructing any structure and in any other manner of construction. 
    Inoperable means incapable of being operated or propelled under its own power by reason of dismantling, disrepair or other cause for a period in excess of ten days. 
    Junk means, but shall not be limited to, parts of machinery or motor vehicles, unused stoves, refrigerators or other appliances stored in the open, remnants of woods, metal or any other material or cast-off material of any kind, whether or not the same could be put to any reasonable use. 
    Junk automobile, junk motor-driven vehicle, trailer in disrepair, contractor's equipment in disrepair, or boat in disrepair means such automobile, vehicle, trailer, equipment or boat which is inoperable or partially dismantled. 
    Partially dismantled means that parts which are ordinarily components have been removed or are missing. 
    Unlicensed vehicle means any vehicle without a valid, current state motor vehicle license. 
(Ord. No. 106, § 4, 4-10-80) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 46-139. - Enforcement of article. 
    This article shall be enforced under the direction of the city manager, in coordination with his designated enforcement officer. 
(Ord. No. 106, § 6, 4-10-80) 
Sec. 46-140. - Causes; prohibitions. 
    It is hereby determined that the following uses, structures, conditions and activities constitute blight and/or are causes of blight or blighting factors which, if allowed to exist, will tend to result and/or actually result in blighted and undesirable neighborhoods and areas within the city. No person shall maintain, cause to be maintained or permit to be maintained any of these conditions and causes of blight or blighting factors upon any property or waters in the city, owned, leased, rented or occupied by such person: 
(1)  In any area, except where specifically permitted by law, the storage upon any property and/or waters of unlicensed vehicles, junk automobiles, junk motor-drive vehicles, trailers in disrepair, contractor's equipment in disrepair, or boats in disrepair, except in a completely enclosed building. 
(2)  In any area, except where specifically permitted by law, the storage upon any property of building materials unless there is in force a valid building permit issued by the city for construction upon the property, and such materials are intended for use in connection with such construction. 
(3)  In any area, except where specifically permitted by law, the storage or accumulation of junk, trash, rubbish, garbage, debris, paper, glass, dirt, cans, bottles, litter, waste material of any kind or refuse of any kind, except domestic refuse stored in a rodentproof receptacle, in such a manner so as not to create a public nuisance for a period not to exceed ten days. 
(4)  In any area the existence of any structure or part of any structure, which, because of fire, wind or other natural disaster, or because of physical deterioration is no longer habitable, if a dwelling, or useful for any other purpose for which it may have been intended. 
(5)  In any area, the existence of any vacant dwelling, garage or other outbuilding unless such buildings are kept securely locked, windows kept glazed or neatly boarded up and otherwise protected to prevent entrance thereto by vandals or trespassers. 
(6)  In any area the existence of any partially completed structure, unless such structure is in the course of construction in accordance with a valid building permit issued by the city and unless such construction is completed within the life of the building permit or a valid extension thereof. 
(Ord. No. 106, § 5, 4-10-80) 
Sec. 46-141. - Service of notice. 
    The owner, if possible, and the lessor, lessee or occupant of any property of which or upon which blight, the causes of blight, or blighting factors set forth in section 46-140, are found to exist, shall be notified in writing to remove or eliminate such blight, causes of blight, or blighting factors from such property within ten days after service of notice in one of the following ways: 
(1)  By delivering the notice to the owner, lessor, lessee or occupant personally or by leaving the notice at his residence, office or place of business with some person of suitable age and discretion; 
(2)  By mailing the notice by certified or registered mail to such owner, lessor, lessee or occupant at his last known address; or 
(3)  If the owner, lessor, lessee, or occupant is unknown, by posting the notice in some conspicuous place on the premises for five days. Failure by the owner, lessor, lessee or occupant to comply with such notice within the time allowed shall constitute a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 106, § 7, 4-10-80) 
Sec. 46-142. - Nuisance per se. 
    Any violation of this article shall constitute a nuisance per se. Upon application of the city to any court of competent jurisdiction, the court may order the nuisance abated and/or the violation of this article and continuation of the nuisance restrained and enjoined. 
(Ord. No. 106, § 8, 4-10-80) 
Sec. 46-143. - Violation and penalties. 
    The violation of any provision of this article by any firm, corporation, person or persons, or anyone acting on behalf of said person, persons, firm or corporation, is a municipal civil infraction, for which the fine shall be not less than $75.00 for the first offense, not less than $100.00 for any offense which is a first repeat offense, and not less than $250.00 for any offense for which is a second repeat offense or any subsequent repeat offense, plus, in all cases, the costs and other sanctions allowed by law or ordinance. 
(1)  The imposition of any sentence shall not exempt the offender from compliance with the requirements of this article. 
(2)  Any violation of this article is a nuisance per se and may be abated by the circuit court through injunctive relief. 
(3)  For purposes of this section the term "subsequent offense" shall mean a violation of the provisions of this article committed by the same person, firm, corporation, or anyone acting on behalf of said person, firm or corporation within 365 calendar days of a previous violation of the same provision for which the person, firm, corporation, or anyone acting on behalf of said person, firm or corporation admitted responsibility or was found responsible by the court. 
(4)  Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. Offenses committed on subsequent days within a period of seven calendar days following the issuance of a citation for a first offense shall all be considered separate first offenses. 
(Ord. No. 106-1, 1-21-11) 
Secs. 46-144-46-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - WELLHEAD PROTECTION AREA[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 150-2, §§ I-VII, adopted August 21, 2006, repealed the former Art. VII, §§ 46-151-46-157, and enacted a new Art. VII as set out herein. The former Art. VII pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 150, §§ I-VII, 1-21-02; Ord. No. 150-1, §§ I-VII, 7-1-02. 

Sec. 46-151. - Introduction. 
    The City of Richmond, Macomb County recognizes: (a) that residents of the City of Richmond rely exclusively on groundwater for a safe drinking water supply, and (b) that certain land uses (particularly those located within the wellhead protection area (WHPA) that use hazardous substances) can contaminate groundwater. 
    The purpose of the WHPA ordinance is to protect water quality, to keep pollutants from entering surface and groundwater, to reduce the danger of contamination, and to protect potable water supplies. It is the intent of the City of Richmond to protect the WHPA, as much as possible, through public education and securing public cooperation. Where new uses or modifications to existing uses are proposed, it is important that every precaution be taken to secure the city's future water supply. Consequently, appropriate land use regulations will be imposed in addition to those imposed in the zoning ordinance or in other city, county, state or federal regulations. 
(Ord. No. 150-2, § I, 8-21-06) 
Sec. 46-152. - Definitions. 
    Aquifer: A geological formation, group of formations, or part of a formation capable of storing and yielding groundwater to wells and springs. 
    Contamination: An impairment of water quality by chemicals, radio nuclides, biologic organisms, or other extraneous matter, whether or not it affects the potential or intended beneficial use of water. 
    Design and performance standards: Structural measures determined to be the most effective, practical means of preventing or reducing pollution inputs from point or non point sources. 
    Development: The carrying out of any construction, reconstruction, alteration of surface or structure, or change of land use or intensity of use. 
    Environment: Means (a) the navigable waters, the waters of the contiguous zone, and the ocean waters of which the natural resources are under the exclusive management authority of the United States under the Fishery Conservation and Management Act of 1976, and (b) any other surface water groundwater, drinking water supply, land surface or subsurface strata, or ambient air within the United States or under the jurisdiction of the United States. (40 CFR § 302.3) 
    Facility: Something built, installed, or established for a particular purpose. 
    Hazardous substances: Means one or more of the following: 1) Any substance that the MDEQ determines to pose an unacceptable risk to the public health, safety, welfare, or the environment, considering the fate of the material, dose-response, toxicity, or adverse impact on natural resources. 2) As defined in the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, Public Law 96-510, 94 Stat. 2767.3). This definition does not include: 1) gasoline, oil, or other vehicle fluids contained in vehicles traversing or parked at a property on a short-term basis. 2) Storage of hazardous substances for retail sale in packaging and in quantities consistent with use by occupants of residential dwellings. 
    Primary containment: A tank, pit, container, pipe, or vessel of first containment of a liquid or chemical. 
    Property owner: A person, public corporation, authority, or a political subdivision of the state or a combination of any of them, that holds an ownership interest in land, whether recorded or not. An ownership interest means ownership by one person or by different private entities, if the land is owned in joint interest or by members of the same immediate family. 
    Release: Any unplanned or improper discharge, leak, or spill of a potential contaminant, including a hazardous material. 
    Secondary containment: A second tank, catchment pit, pipe, or vessel that limits and contains liquid or chemical leaking or leaching from a primary containment area; monitoring and recovery are required. 
    Significant use: Means the use, storage, handling, or management, at any time, of hazardous substances in quantities that exceed those commonly used for typical residential or office purposes. 
    Underground storage tanks (USTs): An underground storage tank is one or any combination of tanks, including the underground pipes connected hereto, used to contain an accumulation of hazardous substances, the volume of which, including the volume of the underground pipes connected thereto, is ten percent or more beneath the surface of the ground. The term UST does not include any of the following: 
 Pipeline facilities, including gathering lines, regulated under the "Natural Gas Pipeline Safety Act of 1968, 82 Stat. 720, 49 U.S.C.A. 2001 3, as amended. 
 Surface impoundments, pits, ponds, or lagoons. 
 Storm or waste water collection systems. 
 Flow-through process tanks. 
 Storage tanks in underground areas where the tanks are on or above the surface of the floor and the integrity of the tank is periodically visually evaluated. 
 Septic tanks. 
 Tanks used for storing/heating fuel for consumptive use on the premises where stored, provided the premises are single- or two-family homes. 
    Wellhead protection area: The area which has been approved by the MDEQ in accordance with the State of Michigan Wellhead Protection Program, which represents the surface and subsurface area surrounding a water well, or well field, which supplies a public water system, and through which contaminants are reasonably likely to move toward and reach the water well or well field, within a ten-year time of travel. [Defined by reference on a map approved by the MDEQ.] 
(Ord. No. 150-2, § II, 8-21-06) 
Sec. 46-153. - General provisions. 
    Property owners and facility operators of all newly proposed projects within the wellhead protection area must comply with the design and performance standard requirements of this article and with the requirements of all state, federal, county, and other local regulations. 
    Wellhead protection area boundaries. Wellhead protection area boundaries are on the wellhead protection area map that is part of this article. This area may be periodically updated without modification to the ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 150-2, § III, 8-21-06) 
Sec. 46-154. - Design and performance standards. 
    The purpose of design and performance standards is to protect water quality, to keep pollutants from entering surface and groundwater, to reduce the danger of contamination, and to protect potable water supplies. Performance standards regulate development within the WHPA by enforcing specific standards for facility design and construction. They allow for aggressive protection of the WHPA by striving for quality development within the WHPA. 
    Performance standards can be complex to administer. They require considerable evaluation and analysis to determine the relative impact to the WHPA. All design and performance standards should be prepared by registered professional engineers. 
    The following standards will apply to uses in the WHPA. 
(1)  Cooling systems. Any cooling water from solvent recovery systems should be free of contamination from solvent, metals or other pollutants, and should not be discharged to the ground. Closed-loop cooling systems are encouraged to eliminate cooling water discharges. Cooling water may be discharged into a storm sewer, sanitary sewer, or stream, provided all federal, state, and local requirements are met. 
(2)  Construction activities. Appropriate maintenance and equipment storage areas must be identified on the site plan where possible, before any construction is done on the site. 
If construction equipment is to be stored in an open area (i.e., temporary storage): 
 The site should not be within the drip line of trees. 
 The site should not be within 100 feet of a watercourse or wetland. Runoff should be diverted away from watercourses and wetlands. 
 Special measures must be taken to prevent excess solids, suspended in storm water, from being discharged from the site. 
 All applicable state and local soil erosion requirements must be met. 
 The maintenance, repair, cleaning, and storage of construction machinery, vehicles, and equipment should be confined to areas specifically designed and designated for that purpose. This practice includes both open and covered equipment maintenance and storage areas, and emphasizes the importance of controlling runoff from both kinds of storage areas. This practice should be implemented at all equipment maintenance and storage areas, and whenever construction will be ongoing long enough that construction equipment will need to be stored, serviced, maintained, or repaired on a construction site. Appropriate equipment maintenance and storage sites should be identified before any actual construction begins. Heavy equipment should be well maintained to prevent leaks. 
 Make sure waste materials are properly disposed of. 
 Outside equipment/maintenance storage areas should be inspected daily to ensure equipment isn't being stored within the drip line of trees and to ensure the vehicles and equipment aren't leaking. Periodic checks of the equipment wash area should also be done to ensure it is not failing. Additional stone may be needed to maintain the wash area. 
 Construction sites must provide facilities for containing any accidental losses of oil or other polluting substances, and comply with the approved equipment maintenance and storage areas, as identified on the site plan. 
 At the conclusion of construction, stabilize the surrounding area. 
(3)  Cross-connections. Cross-connections, such as sanitary discharges to storm sewers, storm water discharges to sanitary sewers, or floor drain discharges to storm sewer systems, are prohibited. 
(4)  Debris. No potentially polluting material such as garbage, trash, refuse, junk vehicles, junk appliances, or toxic substances may be dumped or stored outside a protected structure or container within the WHPA. 
(5)  Floor drains. Floor drain discharges to the ground, septic systems (except in sanitary facilities), storm sewers, or any surface water body, from any location in the facility, is prohibited. 
Floor drains in bathrooms, kitchens, and other sanitary facilities must either discharge to a septic system, a municipal sanitary sewer, or a holding tank, which is periodically pumped out. 
Floor drains in work areas must be connected either to a holding tank with a gravity discharge pipe, or to a collection sump which discharges to a holding tank. 
Floor drains are prohibited in rooms where boilers or emergency generators are housed. 
(6)  Holding tanks. Interior hazardous substance storage tanks should have 110 percent secondary containment, double-walled construction, alarms, and overfill protection. Interior storage tanks should be installed in an enclosed area isolated from floor drains, storm water sewers, or other conduits which may cause a release into the environment. 
For flood control, all exterior aboveground tanks will include, but not be limited to, a monitoring system and secondary standpipe above the 100-year flood control level, for monitoring and recovery. All aboveground tanks must have an impervious dike, above the 100-year flood level, capable of containing 110 percent of the largest volume of storage and be provided with an overflow recovery catchment area or sump. 
Fill-pipe inlets should be above the elevation of the top of the storage tank. 
Tanks and associated appurtenances should be tested periodically for structural integrity. 
(7)  Liquid waste ponds. Open liquid waste ponds are prohibited. 
(8)  Loading and unloading areas. Areas where hazardous substances and waste materials are loaded and unloaded should be enclosed or roofed areas with secondary containment should be isolated from floor drains to prevent potential spills from contaminating storm water or discharging to the ground. Loading and unloading areas must have impervious surfaces and be designed to prevent releases from incidental handling. 
(9)  Material handling and storage areas. Material handling and storage areas for hazardous substances and waste materials should be permanently roofed, completely confined within secondary confinement berms, isolated from floor drains, have sealed surfaces, and should not be accessible to unauthorized personnel. 
Compatible drum and container storage areas should be located together for better control of hazardous substances and waste inventory. 
(10)  Parking lots. This design standard is intended to provide review criteria for parking areas, so that approved construction techniques will prevent solids and contaminates from reaching groundwater and is applicable for nearly all parking areas. The primary purpose for proper performance of parking lot design is to reduce peak runoff and provide some flood storage. This helps reduce surface flushing and subsequent contamination. 
Parking lots can essentially function as specialized detention basins. As such, they should comply with the design and performance standards described under storm water management. 
(11)  Secondary containment. Any facility involving the collection, handling, manufacture, use, storage, transfer, or disposal of any solid or liquid material or wastes, which has the potential to contaminate groundwater, must have a secondary containment system whose purpose is to intercept any leak or release from the primary containment vessel or structure. Containment systems must be accessible to allow for easy inspection. 
Secondary containment must be equivalent to 110 percent of the maximum amount of materials to be stored and be sufficient to retain the substance for the maximum anticipated time necessary for recovery and cleanup. 
Underground tanks or buried pipes, carrying such materials, must have double walls and inspectable sumps. 
(12)  Septic systems and dry wells. Leach fields must be sized according to soil characteristics and hydraulic and pollutant loadings. Excessively sized septic system leach fields may cause reduced effectiveness, if normal flows are inadequate to maintain a biologically active clogging layer throughout the leach field. 
Septic systems are not recommended in areas with karst, fractured, cavernous, volcanic, or any other highly permeable subsurface formation. 
Additional detention times for septic tanks, and larger buffer zones around leach fields should be considered in septic system design. 
All septic tank installations should be designed with provisions for sampling at the outlet baffle. Gas baffles should be installed at the outlet. 
Dry wells are prohibited, unless they are only clean water discharges that meet all established minimum contaminant levels promulgated under the Safe Drinking Water Act, and other state and federal standards for drinking water, and meets all other state and local requirements. 
Flow restrictions and low-flow faucets for sinks and spray nozzles should be installed to minimize hydraulic loading to subsurface disposal systems. 
(13)  Site design. The project and related improvements must be designed to protect the natural environment. There must be no impairment, pollution, and/or destruction of water, natural resources, and the public trust. 
Earthen berms should be used to limit contact with the ground in spill-prone areas. 
Specific areas should be designated and maintained for employee parking. 
If equipment is to be stored in an open area (i.e., temporary storage): 
 The site should not be within the drip line of trees. 
 The site should not be within 100 feet of a watercourse or wetland. Runoff should be diverted away from watercourses and wetlands. 
If equipment is to be maintained and stored in a permanent structure (i.e., building), the building should not be located within 100 feet of a watercourse or wetland. 
Under no circumstances should buildings or equipment be located in flood plains, stream beds, or the channel of any watercourse. 
Equipment wash areas should discharge into a holding tank or sanitary sewer line. Depending on the amount of oil, grease, and other pollutants, pretreatment of wastewater may be needed before it enters the sanitary sewer. 
Wash areas should be constructed of two- to three-inch stone or other approved material, with a minimum six-inch base. They should be underlain with geotextile materials, and protected using berms or diversions to prevent the runoff water from leaving the site. 
Secondary containment should be incorporated into the design of the maintenance/storage facility to contain spills from all hazardous materials. 
Buildings should be clustered, as much as possible, to retain open space, surrounding vegetation, tree cover, and to minimize changes in topography. 
Minimum setback distances should be established between limits of septic systems, dry wells, holding tanks, leach fields, and wellheads. Distances should be based on information such as percolation tests, zones of influence of leachate mounding, wellhead protection areas, and time of travel. 
(14)  Storm water management. Storm water management must comply with all applicable federal, state, and local requirements. 
Storm water management and drainage facilities require special design requirements for high-risk areas such as WHPAs. They must be designed to take advantage of existing natural retention and storage capacity of wetlands and water bodies or water courses, and not increase flooding, or the potential for environmental contamination. 
The preferred strategy for storm water management is storage, treatment, and controlled surface water discharge. Treatment and infiltration may be employed as a storm water strategy, if the site constraints prohibit the uses of the preferred strategy. Treatment refers to the planned use of natural and man made mechanisms to purify storm water through settling out of solids, separation and capture of oil and grease, absorption of particulates, and uptake of dissolved solids. Treatment of storm water is required prior to infiltration or controlled surface water discharge. A surface water outlet is recommended, when available. 
The preferred management strategy consisting of storage, treatment, and controlled surface water discharge includes dual cell onsite detention basins, extended dual cell detention basins, or wet dual-cell detention basins. 
The secondary management strategy consisting of treatment and infiltration includes discharge to storm sewers, catch basins, oil and grit separators, infiltration trenches, lined grass swales, or dual cell infiltration basins. 
Storm water contact with hazardous substances and waste materials must be avoided to the greatest extent possible. Storage of hazardous substances and waste materials should be isolated in roofed or enclosed areas to prevent contact with precipitation. If exposure of storage areas to the elements is allowed, uncovered storage areas should have a separate storm water collection system which discharges to a holding tank. 
Storm water from building roofs may be discharged to the ground. However, if solvent distillation equipment or vapor degreasing is used, with a vent that exhausts to the roof, then roof leaders may become cross contaminated with solvent. These potential sources of cross contamination must be avoided. 
Cross-connections, such as sanitary discharges to storm sewers, storm water discharges to sanitary sewers, or floor drain discharges to storm sewer systems, are prohibited. Water from floor sumps may not be discharged to a storm sewer or stream. 
Runoff from equipment maintenance/storage areas should be directed to stabilized outlets designed to assimilate the volume and type of pollutants discharged to them. 
(15)  Underground storage tanks. Underground storage tanks must comply with all applicable federal and state requirements. Underground storage tanks should not be used, unless explicitly required by fire codes or other federal, state, or local regulations. 
Where underground tanks are required, they should have double-walled construction or secondary containment, such as a concrete vault lined or sealed with an impermeable material and filled with sand. Both types of tanks should have appropriate secondary containment monitoring, high level and leak sensing audiovisual alarms, level indicators, and overfill protection. If a dip stick is used for level measurements, there should be a protective plate or basket where the stick may strike the tank bottom. 
For flood control, all underground facilities will include, but not be limited to, a monitoring system and secondary standpipe above the 100-year flood control level, for monitoring and recovery. 
(16)  Utilities. Where piping for utilities, conduits, ducts, etc., extend through the floor, of any floors at or below grade, the openings must be sealed with chemical resistant, non cracking caulk. 
(17)  Waste stream. Waste management techniques must comply with all applicable federal, state, and local requirements. 
Waste-generating operations should be physically segregated from other operations, and preferably be located within a confinement area with sealed floors and with no direct access outside the facility. This reduces the total work area exposed to solvents, facilitates waste stream segregation and efficient material and waste handling, and minimizes cross contamination with other operations and potential pathways for release into the environment. 
Waste collection stations should be provided throughout work areas for the accumulation of spent chemicals, soiled rags, etc. Each station should have labeled containers for each type of waste fluid. This provides safe interim storage of wastes, reduces frequent handling of small quantities of wastes to storage areas, and minimizes the overall risk of a release into the environment. 
(18)  Work areas. Sealed floors are easier to clean without the use of solvents. All floors should be constructed of cement or other impervious materials to prevent contaminants from leaching into the soils or groundwater. Floor surfaces in work areas and chemical storage areas should be sealed with an impermeable material resistant to acids, caustics, solvents, oils, or any other substance which may be used or generated at the facility. 
Work area floors should be pitched to appropriate floor drains. If floor drains are not used, or if they are located close to entrance ways, then entrances must be designed to prevent storm water runoff from entering the building. 
Curbing and internal floor berms should be used to isolate floor drains from spill-prone areas. 
(Ord. No. 150-2, § I, 8-21-06) 
Sec. 46-155. - Site plan review standards. 
    The public service director is hereby appointed the WHPA administrator to administer and implement the provisions of the City of Richmond WHPA ordinance. 
    The public service director is responsible for reviewing site plans within the WHPA for compliance with the provisions of the WHPA ordinance. The public service director will review the plans in regards to WHPA design and performance standards, and may request any information or revisions required to meet those standards. 
    Upon application for a site plan review for a use within the WHPA, the public service director may employ such technical expertise as needed to ensure compliance with the provisions of these regulations. All reasonable costs, as determined by the City of Richmond, incurred in the compliance review process shall be passed through to the applicant, and shall be in addition to those fees normally charged to review an application for site plan reviews required by the zoning ordinance. 
    In addition to existing site plan application forms, the applicants must complete and submit the site plan review environmental checklist as required by the city's wellhead protection plan. 
    In addition to the site plan requirements of the zoning ordinance, site plans for sites within the WHPA must also provide the following: 
(1)  Secondary containment is required in all site areas where businesses, industry, and government agencies store, handle, or use hazardous materials in operational processes. 
(2)  Floor drains are allowed only when connected to a publicly approved wastewater treatment system, on-site holding tanks, or other type of system approved by the municipality. 
(3)  Storm water management plans must incorporate effective containment measures. 
(4)  Special attention should be given to proper storm water and soil erosion control so that the removal of storm water will not increase off-site sedimentation or otherwise adversely impact neighboring properties, flood, or degrade water resources. 
(5)  Parking areas must be designed to reduce non-point discharge of runoff and contain sediment traps to prevent contaminants from reaching groundwater. 
(6)  All storage areas for chemicals, liquids, and underground facilities must be identified as such on the plans. 
    After site plan approval, no modifications can be made without review and approval, as though it were a new application. Modified review procedures may be considered for project amendments. It is equally important that projects be inspected regularly during construction to ensure that the project is being constructed as approved. Performance guarantees should be required in the amount of all required improvements. 
    Additional requirements. Best management practices are intended to provide a measure of operational integrity. These can be implemented in the form of an agreement at the beginning of a project or through an inspection program. Essentially, the owner is expected to maintain a high level of site maintenance and uphold certain operational requirements. 
(Ord. No. 150-2, § I, 8-21-06) 
Sec. 46-156. - Appeals. 
(a)  A WHPA appeals board is hereby established by the city council to hear and render judgment on allegations of an error in any requirement, decision, or determination by the WHPA administrator in the enforcement or administration of this ordinance. The WHPA appeals board shall not have the authority to grant variances to the requirements of this ordinance. 
(b)  The WHPA appeals board shall be appointed by the city council and shall be comprised of three members who shall serve for four-year terms, commencing on September 1 of each year. The members shall be: 
 One member of the city council. 
 One city resident-at-large. 
 One individual, city resident or nonresident, knowledgeable in groundwater protection methods, practices, procedures and requirements. 
(c)  The WHPA appeals board members shall formulate and adopt its own by-laws, rules of procedure and evidence subject to approval of the city council. 
(d)  The WHPA appeals board may meet on an as needed basis. All meetings of this board shall be held pursuant to the Open Meetings Act and the records maintained by the city clerk regarding appeals are public records, subject to the freedom of Information Act. 
(e)  There shall be a fee for a hearing before the WHPA appeals board. Said fee shall be set by the city council by resolution. 
(f)  Any request for a hearing before the WHPA appeals board must be submitted no later than 30 days following the decision of the WHPA administrator for which the request is being submitted. 
(g)  The WHPA appeals board shall render a decision on an appeal no later than 30 days following an appeals hearing. The decision shall state the board's finding of fact and the reason for the board's decision. 
(h)  Any person or persons aggrieved by the decision of WHPA appeals board may appeal such decision to a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 150-2, § I, 8-21-06) 
Sec. 46-157. - Liability and enforcement. 
(a)  Liability. Nothing in this article will be construed to imply that the City of Richmond has accepted any of an owner/developer's liability if a permitted facility or use contaminates groundwater in any aquifer. 
(b)  Civil enforcement. 
(1)  The public service director or authorized representative, bearing proper identification, shall be permitted to enter private property, at any reasonable time, with reasonable cause, or with prior notification, for such purposes as inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, and records examination pertaining to the requirements of this section. Upon request of the entity which is the object of the inspection, and if permitted by the state public records law, information obtained as a result shall be maintained as confidential. If the owner or tenant does not consent to the entry of the public service director, the public service director may apply to a court of competent jurisdiction of an appropriate warrant or other authority to enter said property, but no consent is necessary for entry into areas then open to the public or to customers. 
(2)  Any person may submit to this jurisdiction a verbal or written complaint alleging a violation of this article. 
(3)  Upon receipt of a complaint, the WHPA administrator will conduct a brief investigation of the substances of the complaint, including a meeting with the landowner involved.
