(4)  A citation for a municipal civil infraction signed by an authorized city official shall be treated as made under oath if the violation alleged in the citation occurred in the presence of the official signing the complaint and if the citation contains the following statement immediately above the date and signature of the official: "I declare under the penalties of perjury that the statements above are true to the best of my information, knowledge and belief." 
(5)  An authorized city official who witnesses a person commit a municipal civil infraction shall prepare and subscribe, as soon as possible and as completely as possible, an original and required copies of a citation. 
(6)  An authorized city official may issue a citation to a person if: 
a.  Based upon investigation, the official has reasonable course to believe that the person is responsible for a municipal civil infraction; or 
b.  Based upon investigation of a complaint by someone who allegedly witnessed the person commit a municipal civil infraction, the official has reasonable course to believe that the person is responsible for an infraction and if the prosecuting attorney or city attorney approves in writing the issuance of the citation. 
(7)  Municipal civil infraction citations shall be served by an authorized city official as follows: 
a.  Except as provided by subsection (6)b. of this section, an authorized city official shall personally serve a copy of the citation upon the alleged violator. 
b.  If the municipal civil infraction action involves the use or occupancy of land, a building, or other structure, a copy of the citation does not need to be personally served upon the alleged violator, but may be served upon an owner or occupant of the land, building, or structure, by posting a copy of the citation on the land or attaching the copy to the building or structure. In addition, a copy of the citation shall be sent by first class mail to the owner of the land, building, or structure at the owner's last known address. 
(Ord. No. 160, 1-17-11) 
Sec. 54-407. - Municipal civil infraction citations-Contents. 
(1)  A municipal ordinance citation shall contain the name and address of the alleged violator, the municipal civil infraction alleged, the place where the alleged violator shall appear in court, the telephone number of the court, and the time at or by which the appearance shall be made. 
(2)  Further, the citation shall inform the alleged violator that he may do one of the following: 
(a)  Admit responsibility for the municipal civil infraction by mail, in person, or by representation, at or by the time specified for appearance. 
(b)  Admit responsibility for the municipal civil infraction, with explanation, by mail, in person, or by representation, at or by the time specified for appearance. 
(c)  Deny responsibility for the municipal civil infraction by doing either of the following: 
(i)  Appearing in person for an informal hearing before a judge or district court magistrate, without the opportunity of being represented by an attorney, unless a formal hearing before a judge is requested by the city. 
(ii)  Appearing in court for a formal hearing before a judge, with the opportunity of being represented by an attorney. 
(3)  The citation shall also inform the alleged violator of all of the following: 
(a)  If the alleged violator desires to admit responsibility, with explanation, in person or by representation, the alleged violator must apply to the court in person, by mail, by telephone, or by representation within the time specified for appearance and obtain a scheduled date and time for an appearance. 
(b)  If the alleged violator desires to deny responsibility, the alleged violator must apply to the court in person, by mail, by telephone, or by representation within the time specified for appearance and obtain a scheduled date and time to appear for a hearing, unless a hearing date is specified on the citation. 
(c)  A hearing shall be an informal hearing unless a formal hearing is requested by the alleged violator or the city. 
(d)  At an informal hearing the alleged violator must appear in person before a judge or district court magistrate, without the opportunity of being represented by an attorney. 
(e)  At a formal hearing the alleged violator must appear in person before a judge with the opportunity of being represented by an attorney. 
(4)  The citation shall contain a notice in bold-faced type that the failure of the alleged violator to appear within the time specified in the citation or at the time scheduled for a hearing or appearance is a misdemeanor and will result in entry of a default judgment against the alleged violator on a municipal civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 160, 1-17-11) 
Sec. 54-408. - Schedule of civil fines established. 
(1)  A schedule of civil fines payable to the bureau for admissions of responsibility by persons served with municipal ordinance violation notices is hereby established. The fines for the violations listed in this subsection shall be as follows: 
(a) Section 46-71, et seq.: [Nuisance] A civil fine for a violation shall be not less than $75.00, plus costs and other sanctions allowed by law or ordinance for each infraction. (b) Section 46-136, et. seq.: [Blight] A civil fine for a violation shall be not less than $75.00, plus costs and other sanctions allowed by law or ordinance for each infraction. (c) Section 78-26, et. seq.: [Snow] A civil fine for a violation shall be not less than $25.00, plus costs and other sanctions allowed by law or ordinance for each infraction. (d) Section 98-56: [Weeds] A civil fine for a violation shall be not less than $25.00, plus costs and other sanctions allowed by law or ordinance for each infraction. (e) Appendix A to the Richmond City Code of Ordinances, Section 1.01, et. seq.: [Zoning Ordinance] The civil fine for a violation shall be not less than $100.00, nor more than $500.00, for the first offense, and not less than $500.00, nor more than $1,000.00, for subsequent offenses, plus costs and other sanctions allowed by law or ordinance for each infraction.  
Except as otherwise provided in this article or any other applicable ordinance, the fine for any offense for which is a first repeat offense shall be not less than $100.00, plus costs and other sanctions allowed by law or ordinance. 
Except as otherwise provided in this article or any other applicable ordinance, the fine for any offense for which is a second repeat offense, or any subsequent repeat offense, shall be not less than $250.00, plus costs and other sanctions allowed by law or ordinance. 
A copy of the schedule, as from time to time amended, shall be posted at the bureau. 
(Ord. No. 160, 1-17-11) 
Chapter 58 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
  

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to operate recreation areas and playgrounds, MCL 123.51 et seq. 

Sec. 58-1. - Enforcement of rules. 
    The responsibility for the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter and the rules and regulations shall be vested in the recreation director and his duly authorized assistants or agents, subject to the supervision and control of the recreation board. 
(Ord. No. 127, § V, 12-2-91) 
Sec. 58-2. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
    Any person convicted of a violation of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be subject to the penalties prescribed in section 1-13 of this Code. 
Sec. 58-3. - Recreation department-Administration by board; budget. 
    The recreation department shall be administered by the city recreation board, as set forth in section 7.15 of the city Charter. The recreation department shall submit its budget requests and budget information to the city manager in the same manner and at the same time as other departments of the city and shall be subject to the same accounting procedures in the administration of its annual budget as are other departments of the city. 
(Ord. No. 127, § II(a), 12-2-91) 
Sec. 58-4. - Same-Director; personnel. 
(a)  The recreation board may employ a recreation director, subject to the confirmation of the city manager, who shall be responsible to the board for the management of the recreation department. The recreation director shall perform such duties as may be prescribed for him by law, by the council, or by the recreation board. 
(b)  The recreation board may employ additional personnel for positions or classifications which have been authorized by the city council and for which budget appropriations have been made. 
(Ord. No. 127, § II(b), (c), 12-2-91) 
Sec. 58-5. - Jurisdiction of board; maintenance of facilities. 
(a)  The recreation board shall have jurisdiction over all areas and facilities under city control, except the Good Old Days facilities and grounds during the Good Old Days Festival, which are declared recreational areas in the recreation master plan, as adopted by the city council, and the design, construction and operations of public parks, the recreational facilities therein, the playgrounds and such other areas and/or facilities as may be designated by the city council. 
(b)  Maintenance is performed by personnel of the public works department who are subject to the direction of the public service director. 
(Ord. No. 127, § III, 12-2-91) 
Sec. 58-6. - Rules and regulations governing conduct in recreation facilities. 
(a)  The recreation director shall recommend to the recreation board necessary rules and regulations to carry out the purpose of this chapter to protect the public health, safety and welfare. The recreation board shall have the power to adopt or reject the rules as recommended by the director, adopt the recommended rules after it has made modifications it deems appropriate, or develop and adopt rules without the recommendation of the director. Copies of the rules and regulations promulgated pursuant to this chapter shall be kept on file at the office of the city clerk and office of the recreation director for distribution to interested parties. Any change or alteration in the existing rules and regulations and any new rule or regulation shall be submitted to the city council for approval. No such rule or regulation shall become effective until approved by the city council. 
(b)  Any violation of any duly adopted rule or regulation governing conduct in any city park shall be a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 127, § IV, 12-2-91) 
Sec. 58-7. - Modification of rules. 
    The recreation director is authorized to modify the strict letter of any rules or regulations promulgated under this chapter, where practical difficulties in carrying out the strict letter of such rules or regulations would result in hardship to a particular person or the public. Such modifications, however, must be those of a character which will not impair the purposes and intent of this chapter, or the rules and regulations promulgated under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 127, § VI, 12-2-91) 
Sec. 58-8. - Appeal from order of director. 
    If any person shall feel aggrieved by any order or decision of the recreation director, he may, within ten days after receipt of such order or decision, appeal in writing to the recreation board. The recreation board may make such decision as it deems in the public interest within the scope and intent of this chapter and such rules and regulations, and such decision shall be final unless an appeal in writing is filed within ten days thereafter with the city council at the office of the city clerk. The city council may take such action on such appeal as it deems just, and may vary the terms of such rules and regulations as it determines is in the public interest. 
(Ord. No. 127, § VII, 12-2-91) 
Sec. 58-9. - Damage of property prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deliberately injure, mar or damage in any manner any monument, ornament, fence, sign, seat, tree, fountain, shrub, flower, playground equipment, fireplaces or any other public property within or pertaining to parks and playgrounds or any other public area. 
(Ord. No. 127, § VIII, 12-2-91) 
Sec. 58-10. - Traffic in parks. 
    No person in a park shall fail to comply with all applicable provisions of the motor vehicle traffic laws, ordinances or duly adopted rules and regulations in regards to the operation of vehicles and equipment in a city park. 
(Ord. No. 127, § IX, 12-2-91) 
Sec. 58-11. - Permit and user fees. 
    The amount charged for permit and user fees for use of recreational facilities or recreational activities and events shall be set by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 127, § X, 12-2-91) 
Chapter 62 - PLANNING[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 161, adopted August 15, 2011, repealed the former Ch. 62, §§ 62-1, 62-26-62-40, 62-51-62-63, 62-62-76-62-88, 62-101-62-107, 62-121-62-130, and enacted a new Ch. 62 as set out herein. The former Ch. 62 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 65, §§ 2, 3.1-3.7, 4.1-4.8, 5.1-5.13, 6.1-6.13, 7.1-7.4, 8.1-8.10, 6-6-60. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; community development, ch. 34; fire prevention and protection, ch. 50; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78; subdivisions, ch. 82; utilities, ch. 94; zoning, app. A. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate land use, MCL 125.581 et seq.; municipal planning, MCL 125.31 et seq. 

Sec. 62-1. - Scope, purpose and intent. 
    This chapter is adopted pursuant to the authority granted the city council under the Michigan Planning Enabling Act, Public Act 33 of 2008, MCL 125.3801, et seq., and the Michigan Zoning Enabling Act, Public Act 110 of 2006, MCL 125.3101, et seq., to establish a planning commission with the powers, duties and limitations provided by those Acts and subject to the terms and conditions of this chapter and any future amendments to this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 161, 8-15-11) 
Sec. 62-2. - Establishment. 
    The Richmond City Council hereby confirms the establishment under the Michigan Planning Enabling Act, Public Act 33 of 2008, MCL 125.3801, et seq., of the City of Richmond Planning Commission (formerly established under the Municipal Planning Act, Public Act 285 of 1931, MCL 125.31, et seq.). The City of Richmond Planning Commission shall have nine members. Members of the City of Richmond Planning Commission as of the effective date of this chapter shall continue to serve for the remainder of their existing terms so long as they continue to meet all of the eligibility requirements for planning commission membership set forth in the Michigan Planning Enabling Act, Public Act 33 of 2008, MCL 125.3801, et seq. 
(Ord. No. 161, 8-15-11) 
Sec. 62-3. - Appointments and terms. 
    The mayor, with the approval of the city council by a majority vote of the members elected and serving, shall appoint all planning commission members. 
    The planning commission members, other than an ex officio member, shall serve for terms of three years each. 
    A planning commission member shall hold office until his or her successor is appointed. Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as the original appointment. 
    Planning commission members shall be qualified electors of the city, except that one planning commission member may be an individual who is not a qualified elector of the city, provided that such member is a qualified elector of another local unit of government. The membership of the planning commission shall be representative of important segments of the community, such as the economic, governmental, educational, and social development of the city, in accordance with the major interests as they exist in the city, such as agriculture, natural resources, recreation, education, public health, government, transportation, industry, and commerce. The membership shall also be representative of the entire geography of the city to the extent practicable. 
    The mayor and the city manager shall be appointed to the planning commission as ex officio members. 
    An ex officio member has full voting rights. The mayor's term on the planning commission shall correspond to his or her term as the mayor. The city manager's term on the planning commission shall expire with the term of the mayor who appointed him or her manager, or the termination of the manager's employment by the city, whichever shall occur first. 
    No other elected officer or employee of the city is eligible to be a member of the planning commission. 
(Ord. No. 161, 8-15-11) 
Sec. 62-4. - Removal. 
    The city council may remove a member of the planning commission for misfeasance, malfeasance, or nonfeasance in office upon written charges and after notice and opportunity to be heard, which may be in a public or closed session at the choice of the affected member. 
(Ord. No. 161, 8-15-11) 
Sec. 62-5. - Conflict of interest. 
    Before casting a vote on a matter on which a planning commission member may reasonably be considered to have a conflict of interest, the member shall disclose the potential conflict of interest to the planning commission. Failure of a member to disclose a potential conflict of interest as required by this ordinance constitutes malfeasance in office. 
    For the purposes of this section, conflict of interest is defined as, and a planning commission member shall declare a conflict of interest and abstain from participating in planning commission deliberations and voting on a request, when: 
(a)  An immediate family member is involved in any request for which the planning commission is asked to make a decision. "Immediate family member" is defined as a spouse, mother, father, sister, brother, son, or daughter, including an adopted child. An individual's father, mother, son, daughter, brother, sister, and spouse and a relative of any degree residing in the same household as that individual. 
(b)  The planning commission member has a business or financial interest in the property involved in the request or has a business or financial interest in the applicant's company, agency or association; 
(c)  The planning commission member owns or has a financial interest in neighboring property; 
(d)  There is a reasonable appearance of a conflict of interest, as determined by a majority vote of the remaining members of the planning commission. 
(Ord. No. 161, 8-15-11) 
Sec. 62-6. - Compensation. 
    All members of the planning commission shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 161, 8-15-11) 
Sec. 62-7. - Officers and committees. 
    The planning commission shall elect a chairperson and a secretary from its members, and may create and fill other offices as it considers advisable. An ex officio member of the planning commission is not eligible to serve as chairperson. The term of chairperson and secretary shall be one year, with opportunity for reelection as specified in the planning commission bylaws. 
    The planning commission may also appoint advisory committees whose members are not members of the planning commission. 
(Ord. No. 161, 8-15-11) 
Sec. 62-8. - Bylaws, meetings and records. 
    The planning commission shall adopt bylaws for the transaction of business. 
    The planning commission shall hold at least 4 regular meetings each year, and shall by resolution determine the time and place of the meetings. 
    Unless otherwise provided in the planning commission's bylaws, a special meeting of the planning commission may be called by the chairperson or by 2 other members, upon written request to the secretary. Unless the bylaws otherwise provide, the secretary shall send written notice of a special meeting to planning commission members at least 48 hours before the meeting. 
    The business that the planning commission may perform shall be conducted at a public meeting held in compliance with the Open Meetings Act, Public Act 267 of 1976, MCL 15.261, et seq. 
    The planning commission shall keep a public record of its resolutions, transactions, findings, and determinations. A writing prepared, owned, used, in the possession of, or retained by a planning commission in the performance of an official function shall be made available to the public in compliance with the Freedom of Information Act, Public Act 442 of 1976, MCL 15.231, et seq. 
(Ord. No. 161, 8-15-11) 
Sec. 62-9. - Annual report. 
    The planning commission shall make an annual written report to the city council concerning its operations and the status of the planning activities, including recommendations regarding actions by the city council related to planning and development. 
(Ord. No. 161, 8-15-11) 
Sec. 62-10. - Authority to make master plan. 
    Under the authority of the Michigan Planning Enabling Act, Public Act 33 of 2008, MCL 125.3801, et seq., and other applicable planning statutes, the planning commission shall make a master plan as a guide for development within the city's planning jurisdiction. 
    Final authority to approve a master plan or any amendments thereto shall rest with the planning commission unless the city council passes a resolution asserting the right to approve or reject the master plan. 
    Unless rescinded by the city, any plan adopted or amended under the Municipal Planning Act, Public Act 285 of 1931, MCL 125.31, et seq. need not be readopted under the Michigan Planning Enabling Act, Public Act 33 of 2008, MCL 125.3801, et seq. 
(Ord. No. 161, 8-15-11) 
Sec. 62-11. - Zoning powers. 
    The city council hereby confirms the transfer of all powers, duties, and responsibilities provided for zoning boards or zoning commissions by the former city and Village Zoning Act, Public Act 207 of 1921, MCL 125.581 to 125.600; the Michigan Zoning Enabling Act, Public Act 110 of 2006, MCL 125.3101, et seq.; or other applicable zoning statutes to the City of Richmond Planning Commission formerly established under the Municipal Planning Act, Public Act 285 of 1931, MCL 125.31, et seq. 
    Any existing zoning ordinance shall remain in full force and effect except as otherwise amended or repealed by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 161, 8-15-11) 
Sec. 62-12. - Capital improvements program. 
    To further the desirable future development of the City of Richmond under the master plan, the city council, after the master plan is adopted, shall prepare or cause to be prepared by the city manager, a capital improvements program of public structures and improvements, showing those structures and improvements in general order of their priority, for the following six-year period. The prepared capital improvements program shall be subject to final approval by the city council. The planning commission is hereby exempted from preparing a capital improvements plan. 
(Ord. No. 161, 8-15-11) 
Sec. 62-13. - Subdivision and land division recommendations. 
    The planning commission may recommend to the city council provisions of an ordinance or rules governing the subdivision of land. Before recommending such an ordinance or rule, the planning commission shall hold a public hearing on the proposed ordinance or rule. The planning commission shall give notice of the time and place of the public hearing not less than 15 days before the hearing by publication in a newspaper of general circulation within the city. 
    The planning commission shall review and make recommendation on a proposed plat before action thereon by the city council under the Land Division Act, Public Act 288 of 1967, MCL 560.101, et seq. Before making its recommendation, the planning commission shall hold a public hearing on the proposed plat. A plat submitted to the planning commission shall contain the name and address of the proprietor or other person to whom notice of a hearing shall be sent. Not less than 15 days before the date of the hearing, notice of the date, time and place of the hearing shall be sent to that person at that address by mail and shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. Similar notice shall be mailed to the owners of land immediately adjoining the proposed platted land. 
(Ord. No. 161, 8-15-11) 
Sec. 62-14. - Severability. 
    The provisions of this ordinance are hereby declared to be severable, and if any part is declared invalid for any reason by a court of competent jurisdiction, it shall not affect the remainder of the ordinance, which shall continue in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 161, 8-15-11) 
Sec. 62-15. - Repeal. 
    All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with this chapter are hereby repealed. The resolution or ordinance establishing the City of Richmond Planning Commission under the Municipal Planning Act, Public Act 285 of 1931, MCL 125.31, et seq. is hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 161, 8-15-11) 
Sec. 62-16. - Effective date. 
    This ordinance shall take effect on the date of its publication. 
(Ord. No. 161, 8-15-11) 
Chapter 64 - PURCHASING 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 64-1. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to establish policies and procedures for public purchasing pursuant to the requirements of Section 14.1 of the Charter of the City of Richmond that promote the fair and equitable treatment of all persons maintaining an interest in the public purchasing activities of the city; maximize the purchasing value of public funds in procurement of city property, supplies, materials, equipment, and services; and establish safeguards for maintaining a procurement system of quality and integrity. This chapter shall not be construed to prevent any public agency from complying with the terms and conditions of any grant, gift, bequest, donation, or other funding source when such terms and conditions are otherwise consistent with law. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-2. - Application of chapter. 
    This chapter shall apply to the procurement of all property, supplies, materials, equipment, and services by the City of Richmond, unless an exemption is provided herein. The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the expenditure of all public funds for procurement purposes, regardless of the source of those public funds. When any procurement involves the expenditure of federal or state assistance or contract funds, such procurement shall be conducted in accordance with applicable laws and regulations governing such funds in addition to the policies and procedures set forth herein, and, to the extent that federal or state laws conflict with the provisions of this chapter, the federal or state laws or regulations shall govern. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-3. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Comparative prices and comparative pricing: shall mean price quotations for property, supplies, materials, equipment, or services obtained through such informal means as telephone contact, facsimile transmittal, electronic mail, or other informal methods. 
    Contract: shall mean any arrangement or agreement pursuant to which any material, service, or other thing of value is to be furnished to the city for a valuable consideration to be paid by the city or sold or transferred by the city, except the furnishing of personal services as an officer or employee of the city. 
    Contractor: shall mean any person, firm, or corporation having a contract with the City of Richmond. 
    Local bidder: shall mean any person, firm, or corporation that maintains a permanent business office or business facility within the corporate limits of the City of Richmond for the purpose of supplying the product or providing the service for which a bid was submitted. 
    Procurement: shall mean the purchasing, renting, leasing, or otherwise acquiring for monetary consideration any property, supplies, materials, equipment, or services for the city. 
    Professional services: shall mean those services provided by a person, firm, or corporation which require specific technical training, expertise, certification, or licensure to perform, including but not limited to architectural, engineering, accountancy, consulting, appraising, auditing, risk assessment, urban planning, and legal services. 
    Purchase order: shall mean a document or instrument used as written notice to initiate and contract for the procurement of property, supplies, materials, equipment, or services and is a formal notice to a vendor to furnish such items. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-4. - Contract authority vested in city council. 
    The authority to contract on behalf of the city is vested in the city council and shall be exercised in accordance with the provisions of law, provided that purchases and sales may be made by the city manager subject to the provisions of section 14.1 of the City Charter and this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-5. - Purchasing agent. 
    In accordance with section 14.1(a) of the City Charter, the city manager shall serve as the purchasing agent of the city and shall be responsible for the purchase and sale of all city property and shall serve as the purchasing agent of the city. The purchasing agent shall promote and encourage to the extent reasonably possible full, open, and fair competition in the procurement and sale of city property, supplies, materials, equipment, and services; shall act to procure for the city the highest quality of products and services as cost effectively as possible; shall prescribe, maintain, and furnish such procurement forms as may be necessary to administer the purchasing policies of the city; and shall provide such reports to the city council as may from time to time be required by this chapter, the city council, or applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-6. - Written evidence of purchases and sales. 
    In accordance with section 14.1(f) of the City Charter, all purchases and sales by the city shall be evidenced by written contract or purchase order. The standard form and content of such written contracts or purchase orders shall be as prescribed from time to time by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-7. - Purchase, sale, or lease of real estate or public utilities-Restrictions. 
(a)  Approval by city council required. The city shall not purchase, sell, or lease any real estate or any interest therein except by the affirmative vote of four or more members of the city council. In the case of the sale of real property, such sale shall not be authorized at the same meeting of the city council at which the resolution for such sale is introduced. 
(b)  Referendum. Any agreement or contract for the renting or leasing of public property to any person for a period longer than three years shall be subject to the same referendum procedure as is provided in the case of ordinances passed by the city council. Any petition for such referendum must be filed within thirty days after publication of the proceedings of the meeting of the city council at which such agreement or contract is authorized. The transfer or assignment of any agreement or contract for such renting or leasing of public property may be made only upon approval of the city council, but approval of such transfer shall not be subject to referendum. Rentals and leases, and renewals thereof, shall be for a fair consideration as determined by the city council. 
(c)  Public utilities. Unless approved by the affirmative vote of three-fifths of the electors voting thereon at a regular or special election, the city shall not sell, exchange, lease, or in any way dispose of any property, easements, equipment, privilege, or asset belonging to and appertaining to any municipally owned public utility which is needed to continue operating such utility. All contracts, negotiations, licenses, grants, leases, or other forms of transfer in violation of this section or City Charter shall be voidable at the city's option. The restrictions of this section shall not apply to: 
(1)  The sale or exchange of any articles of machinery or equipment of any city-owned public utility which are worn out or useless or which have been, or could with advantage to the service, be replaced by new and improved machinery or equipment; 
(2)  The leasing of property not necessary for the operation of the utility; or 
(3)  The exchange of property or easements for other needed property or easements. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-8. - Financial interest prohibited. 
(a)  Financial interest defined. No contract or purchase involving an amount in excess of one hundred dollars shall be made by the city in which any member of the city council, the city manager, the purchasing agent of the city, or any member of his or her family has any financial interest, direct or indirect except as otherwise permitted by this section. A city officer shall be deemed to have a financial interest in a contract if he or she or any member of his or her family is an employee, partner, officer, director, or sales representative of the person, firm, or corporation with which such contract is made or of a sales representative of such person, firm, or corporation. For purposes of this section, "family member" shall mean only the spouse, child, father, or mother, including any such relationship legally created by marriage, of a city officer and the spouse of any of them. Ownership, individually or in a fiduciary capacity, by an officer or member of his or her family of securities or of any beneficial interest in securities, of any corporation with which a contract is made or which is a sales representative of any person, firm, or corporation with which such contract is made shall not be deemed to create a financial interest in such contract unless the aggregate amount of such securities, or interest in such securities, so owned by such officer and the members of his or her family shall amount to ten percent of any class of the securities of such corporation then outstanding. Any officer who knowingly permits the city to enter into any contract in which he or she has a financial interest without disclosing such interest to the city council prior to the action of the city council in authorizing such contract shall be guilty of misconduct in office in accordance with section 4.18(d) of the City Charter. 
(b)  Waiver of prohibition by city council. A contract in which an officer or member of his or her family has a financial interest may be made by the city if the members of the city council in office at the time having no such interest shall unanimously determine that the best interests of the city will be served by the making of such contract and if either such contract is made after comparative prices are obtained or if the members of the city council having no interest shall unanimously determine that the obtaining of comparative prices is not feasible in such particular case. 
(c)  Determination by city council of no financial interest. Except in the instances specified in subsection (b), the unanimous determination of all members of the city council that in a particular case an officer or member of his or her family will not have a financial interest in any contract or purchase to be entered into by the city shall be final and conclusive in the absence of fraud or misrepresentation. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-9. - Persons in default to city-Ineligibility as city vendor or competent bidder. 
    The city shall not accept a comparative price quotation or bid from any person, firm, or corporation who is in default to the city on the payment of taxes, licenses, or other monies due and owing to the city, nor shall any purchase or sale transaction be executed by the city with any such defaulting person, firm, or corporation. Any such person, firm, or corporation shall be ineligible to be a vendor or competent bidder for any transaction with the city during any period of default. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-10. - Review of purchases or sales by city attorney and city treasurer. 
(a)  Review by city attorney. In accordance with section 14.2 of the City Charter, the city attorney shall and give his or her opinion on the form and legality of any contract or agreement in an amount of five hundred dollars or more made with form or terms other than the standard city purchase order, with a copy of all contracts or agreements requiring such opinion to be filed with the office of the city clerk together with a copy of the opinion. 
(b)  Certification of appropriation by city treasurer. In accordance with section 14.2(d) of the City Charter, before any contract, agreement, or purchase order obligating the city to pay an amount of $500.00 or more is executed, the city treasurer, acting as the accounting officer of the city, shall first have certified that an appropriation has been made for the payment thereof or that sufficient funds will be available if it be for a purpose being financed by the issuance of bonds or by special assessments or for some other purpose not chargeable to a budget appropriation. In the case of a contract or agreement obligating the city for periodic payments in future fiscal years, such certificate need not cover those payments which will be due in future fiscal years, but his or her exceptions shall not apply to a contract for the purchase or construction of a public improvement. Certification by the city treasurer shall be endorsed on each contract, agreement, or purchase order requiring the same or shall be filed as an attachment thereto. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-11. - Circumvention of dollar limitations prohibited. 
    No contract or purchase order shall be subdivided for the purpose of circumventing the dollar value limitations contained in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-12. - Amendments to contracts-Council approval required. 
    No contract shall be amended after the same has been made except upon the authority of the city council, provided that the city manager may amend contracts for those purchases and sales made by him under the authority of the City Charter and this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-13. - Individual employment agreements-Exemption. 
    An individual agreement of employment shall not be deemed a contract requiring opinion by the city attorney or certification by the city treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Secs. 64-14-64-29. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PURCHASES OR SALES UNDER $5,000.00 

Sec. 64-30. - Purchasing authority of city manager. 
    Unless otherwise restricted or prohibited by this chapter or by the City Charter, the city manager shall have the authority to undertake without city council approval the purchase or sale of city property, supplies, materials, equipment, public improvements, and services when such purchase or sale is less than $5,000.00. Comparative prices shall be obtained for such purchase or sale, except that comparative prices shall not be required for the contracting or employment of professional services or for those purchases or sales which the city manager shall determine that no advantage to the city would result from obtaining comparative prices. Comparative prices obtained shall be documented in writing and shall be placed on file for reference and inspection in accordance with the city's adopted records retention and disposal schedule. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Secs. 64-31-64-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PURCHASES OR SALES OF $5,000.00 OR MORE 

Sec. 64-40. - City council approval required. 
    Any purchase or sale of city property, supplies, materials, equipment, or services in the amount of $5,000.00 or more shall be approved by the city council prior to undertaking such purchase or sale. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-41. - Competitive bidding required. 
    Any purchase or sale of city property, supplies, materials, equipment, or services in the amount of $5,000.00 or more, except for professional services, shall be made only after obtaining formal sealed, competitive bids and approval of a contract based on such bids has been granted by the city council, unless the city council, by unanimous vote of those present at the meeting based upon the written recommendation of the city manager, determines that no advantage to the city would result from competitive bidding. However, the city council may authorize any public improvements or other city work to be performed by any city agency without competitive bidding. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-42. - Bid specifications-Preparation; public notice. 
    The city manager, acting as purchasing agent, shall prepare, or cause to be prepared, bid specifications for the property, supplies, materials, equipment, or services to be purchased or sold and shall advertise at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city a public notice in such form and content prescribed from time to time by the city manager inviting the tender of bids in writing for the furnishing of such products or services. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-43. - Bid submission and opening procedures. 
    Bids shall be sealed in an envelope and submitted to the office of the city clerk by the deadline specified in the public notice inviting bids. Each sealed envelope shall be clearly labeled or marked to identify the nature of the bid and, if required, shall be accompanied by the bid security in the form of a cashier's check, certified check, cash, or surety bond in such amount as prescribed in the public notice inviting bids. All bids shall be opened in public and in the presence of the city clerk or a designated representative on the date, time, and place stated in the public notice inviting bids. Each bid, together with the name of the bidder, shall be recorded, and the tabulation of all bids received shall be available for public inspection in the office of the city clerk. Any bid received after the deadline for submission, as advertised in the public notice inviting bids, shall not be opened nor considered. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-44. - Statement of bidder qualifications; determination of competent bidder; notice of rejection. 
    Any officer, board, commission, committee or department of the city authorized to receive bids for the purchase of any city property, supplies, materials, equipment, or services may require that any person, firm, or corporation proposing to bid on any such project submit a sworn statement at least ten days before bids are opened on such standard form and in such detail and at such time as may be deemed necessary by said officer, board, commission, committee or department, setting forth his or her qualifications to satisfactorily carry out the work to be performed within the time specified for such performance. Such statement of qualifications, filed with said officer, board, commission, committee or department of the city, shall be deemed to be confidential and shall not be imparted to any other person, firm or corporation without the consent of the prospective bidder. Said qualifications may be judged by said officer, board, commission, committee or department upon the basis of the proposed bidder's past performance on work of a similar nature, his or her financial resources and his or her equipment and facilities which he or she proposes to use on the project advertised as disclosed by such sworn statement and any other available information and a determination made whether or not the proposed bidder is a suitable and competent person, firm, or corporation to bid on the work. Any person, firm, or corporation determined not to be a suitable person, firm, or corporation to bid on any proposed work shall be notified in writing five days before bids are opened of such determination. Should the prospective bidder fail to file the statement of qualifications as required by said officer, board, commission, committee or department of the city within the time specified, or should he or she, in the judgment of said officer, board, commission, committee or department be not qualified to bid on the work duly advertised, such officer, board, commission, committee or department may refuse to furnish such person, firm, or corporation with plans, specifications, and proposals and may reject any bid made by him. Any person, firm, or corporation feeling himself aggrieved by the determination of his or her competence as a bidder shall have the right to appeal such determination to the city council in addition to any other rights of appeal provided under state law. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-45. - Award of contracts. 
    Each contract submitted to the city council for approval shall be accompanied by a tabulation of all bids received, together with the recommendation of the city manager. All bids, deposits of cash, certified checks, or cashier's checks shall be retained by the city until a contract is awarded and executed. Award of contracts for purchases shall be made from the lowest competent bidder meeting specifications unless the city council shall determine that the public interest will be better served by accepting a higher bid, in which case the city council shall place on the meeting record the reasons for such determination. Award of contracts for sales shall be made to the bidder whose bid is most advantageous to the city. If any successful bidder fails or refuses to execute the contract after its award, the bid security submitted with the bid shall be forfeited by the bidder, and the city council may award the contract to the next lowest competent bidder or may reject all bids and invite new bids. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-46. - Tie bidders. 
    If more than one competent bidder shall submit a bid for the same amount and each such bidder is equally qualified under the criteria for competent bidders set forth in this article, then the contract shall be awarded to the local bidder, if any; or to one of the tie bidders by drawing lots in public; or, with the approval of the city council, the city manager may purchase or sell the product or service on the open market whenever such action shall serve the public interest, provided that the price of a purchase in the open market shall not exceed the lowest bid price submitted by a competent bidder for the same product or service nor shall the price of a sale in the open market be less than the highest bid price submitted by a competent bidder for the same product or service. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-47. - Right of city to accept or reject bids or waive irregularities. 
    The city shall reserve the right to accept or reject any or all bids, to waive irregularities in bidding, and to accept bids which do not conform in every respect to the bidding requirements. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-48. - Bid securities and bonds. 
    Bid securities, performance bonds, and payment bonds may be required to be furnished to the city conditioned upon the faithful performance of the contract and saving the city harmless for all losses or damages incurred by any person or property by reason of any carelessness or negligence by the contractor and from all expenses of inspection, engineering, and otherwise caused by the delay in the completion of any required performance under the contract and further conditioned upon the faithful payment by the contractor to all claimants furnishing labor or material to the contractor in the prosecution of the work required by the contract. When required, bid securities, performance bonds, and payment bonds shall be prescribed in the bid specifications, together with the deadline for furnishing the same, and bidders shall furnish such bid securities or bonds by such deadline as a prerequisite for contract eligibility. Bid securities, performance bonds, and payment bonds shall be filed with the office of the city clerk and shall meet the following requirements, with failure to comply constituting ineligibility as a competent bidder: 
(1)  Bid securities: 
a.  Shall be bonds furnished by a surety company authorized to do business in the State of Michigan, or shall be the equivalent amount in cash, cashier's check, or certified check, and shall be made payable to the City of Richmond, to secure the proper and faithful execution of the contract for which the bid was submitted. 
b.  Shall be in an amount equal to five percent of the total amount of the bid, or $50.00, whichever is greater. 
c.  Shall be forfeited by the successful bidder upon failure on the bidder's part to enter into a contract after the award of the contract within the time specified in the bid specifications. 
(2)  Performance bonds: 
a.  Shall be delivered to the city at the time of, or prior to, the execution by the city of the contract. 
b.  Shall be a bond furnished by a surety company authorized to do business in the State of Michigan, or shall be the equivalent amount in cash, cashier's check, or certified check, and shall be made payable to the City of Richmond, to secure payment for the proper and faithful performance of the contractor in accordance with plans, specifications and terms of the work or services required under the contract. 
c.  Shall be in an amount of not less than 25 percent of the total amount of the bid. 
(3)  Payment bonds: 
a.  Shall be a bond furnished by a surety company authorized to do business in the State of Michigan, or shall be the equivalent amount in cash, cashier's check, or certified check, and shall be made payable to the City of Richmond, for the protection of claimants supplying labor, materials, services, and other things of value to the principal contractor in performance of the work required under the contract. 
b.  Shall be in an amount of not less than 25 percent of the total amount of the bid. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-49. - Bid securities and bonds-Enforcement of claims; notice of supplier to principal contractor or city; payment to subcontractor. 
    A claimant who has furnished labor or material in the prosecution of the work provided for in such contract in respect of which payment bond is furnished, and who has not been paid in full therefor before the expiration of a period of 90 days after the day on which the last of the work was done or performed by him or material was furnished or supplied by him for which claim is made, may sue on the payment bond for the amount, or the balance thereof, unpaid at the time of institution of the civil action, prosecute such action to final judgment for the sum justly due him and have execution thereon. A claimant not having a direct contractual relationship with the principal contractor shall not have a right of action upon the payment bond unless (a) he or she has within 30 days after furnishing the first of such material or performing the first of such labor, served on the principal contractor and the city a written notice, which shall inform the principal contractor and the city of the nature of the materials being furnished or to be furnished, or labor being performed or to be performed and identifying the party contracting for such labor or materials and the site for the performance of such labor or the delivery of such materials, and (b) he or she has given written notice to the principal contractor and the city within 90 days from the date on which the claimant performed the last of the labor or furnished or supplied the last of the material for which the claim is made, stating with substantial accuracy the amount claimed and the name of the party to whom the material was furnished or supplied or for whom the labor was done or performed. The principal contractor shall not be required to make payment to a subcontractor of sums due from the subcontractor to parties performing labor or furnishing materials or supplies, except upon the receipt of the written orders of such parties to pay to the subcontractor the sums due such parties. If the principal contractor shall contest the eligibility under this chapter for right of action upon the payment bond of a claimant not having a contractual relationship with the principal contractor, and if there are no contractual provisions between the principal contractor and its subcontractors providing for the method of resolution of such claims, the principal contractor shall notify the claimant and the city in writing of such contest within 30 days of receipt of a notice of the claimant and the dispute shall be submitted to an alternative dispute resolution agency selected by the city to arbitrate such eligibility. Each notice required under this section shall be served by mailing the same by certified mail, postage prepaid, in an envelope addressed to the principal contractor and to the city at any place at which said parties maintain a business or residence. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-50. - Copies of bonds and contracts; fees. 
    The city clerk shall furnish to anyone making application therefor who submits an affidavit that he or she has supplied labor or materials for such work and payment therefor has not been made, or that he or she is being sued on any such bond, or that it is the surety thereon, a certified copy of the bond and the contract for which it was given, which copy shall be prima facie evidence of the contents, execution, and delivery of the original. An applicant shall pay such reasonable fees for such certified copies as the city clerk fixes in accordance with the Michigan Freedom of Information Act to cover the actual cost of preparation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-51. - Contracts filed with city clerk. 
    A copy of each contract executed by the city shall be filed in the office of the city clerk and shall be available for public inspection and copying in accordance with the Michigan Freedom of Information Act. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-52. - Extra compensation to contractors. 
    Any additional compensation to any contractor in excess of the amount approved under such contract shall only be paid after approval by the city council of a contract change order in such form and content as may be prescribed from time to time by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-53. - Contracts not requiring competitive bidding. 
    The city council, upon the recommendation of the city manager, may authorize the execution of a contract without competitive sealed bids if: 
(a)  The material, product, or service is available from only one vendor (sole-source supplier); or 
(b)  A public emergency exists in accordance with the emergency purchasing section of this article; or 
(c)  After solicitation of a number of sources, competition is determined to be inadequate; or 
(d)  The city could obtain an advantage or benefit not otherwise obtainable if competitive bidding procedures were followed; or 
(e)  The contract involves a purchase under the cooperative purchasing section of this article. 
(f)  The city council or city manager is exercising authority granted under the City Charter or applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-54. - Cooperative purchasing. 
    When the city council approves by unanimous vote upon the recommendation of the city manager that no advantage to the city could result from competitive bidding as a result of cooperative purchasing, the city shall have the authority to join with other units of government or public authorities at the local, state, or federal level in cooperative purchasing plans or procedures when the best interest of the city would be served thereby. If, in the opinion of the city manager, the best interest of the city would be served by entering into cooperative purchasing with other units of government, the purchasing services of the city may be made available without charge to any other unit of government or public authority. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-55. - Emergency purchases. 
    The city manager shall have the authority to temporarily suspend the competitive bidding requirements of this article in the event of an emergency which poses threats to the public health, safety, or welfare of the city or its citizens and which requires immediate purchases of property, supplies, materials, equipment, or services. The city manager is authorized to make such purchases in the open market. A written report detailing the circumstances of an emergency purchase, together with a recommendation that a determination of no advantage to the city would result from competitive bidding, shall be filed by the city manager with the city council through the office of the city clerk as soon as is practicable after undertaking the emergency purchase. The city council act upon such report and recommendation at its next regular meeting subsequent to receipt of the report. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Sec. 64-56. - Professional services. 
    Unless otherwise provided by federal or state law or City Charter, a professional service which is expected to exceed $25,000.00 in cost shall be secured through an evaluation and negotiation process administered by the city manager. This process shall be initiated by a request for proposals and distributed to appropriate persons, firms, and corporations in such form and content as may be prescribed from time to time by the city manager. The request for proposals shall include at a minimum the following information: 
(1)  A full description of the service to be contracted and the proposed duration of such contract, if such proposal is for ongoing professional services; 
(2)  The specific criteria that will be used in evaluating proposals; and 
(3)  The deadline for submitting proposals, the responsible city contact person to whom questions should be addressed, the address to which proposals must be mailed or delivered, and other relevant information necessary to permit interested parties to submit comprehensive and complete proposals. 
The city manager shall recommend to the city council for approval the award of a contract with the firm which, in the city manager's opinion, will provide the most efficient, cost effective, reliable, comprehensive, or highest quality professional service within the amounts appropriated in the budget by the city council for the professional service. The city manager may consider in his recommendation such criteria as cost, professional qualifications, level or extent of successful previous performance of similar work for the city or others, availability of staff labor to perform the work, location of the firm, and any other criteria determined by the city manager to be relevant to the selection of a firm for provision of the professional service. 
(Ord. No. 155, § 1, 1-19-04) 
Chapter 66 - SECONDHAND GOODS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22. 
State Law reference- Junkyard near highways, MCL 252.201 et seq.; licensing of pawnbrokers, MCL 445.471 et seq., 446.201 et seq., 19.740(1) et seq.; licensing of secondhand and junk dealers, MCL 445.401 et seq., 445.471 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 66-1-66-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - GARAGE AND YARD SALES 

Sec. 66-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Garage or yard sale means a sale of used household effects, appliances, clothing, china, glassware and other such items by a person from his residence by means of a display of such items in the yard, garage, patio, parking area or other like place in, around or near such residence. It shall not mean the sale of a single automobile by means of a for sale sign in the window of such vehicle parked near a residence. 
    Salesmen's or free samples means items which were packaged and designed to introduce products to consumers and which were distributed by salesmen or otherwise without charge. 
    Wholesale means sales in bulk or individually to dealers or persons who intend to resell such items. 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 66-27. - Purpose and intent of article. 
    It is the intent of this article to regulate and control the holding of garage and yard sales, as they may become nuisances and safety hazards if not so regulated, and so that residential areas do not become commercialized through a proliferation of such sales and similar commercial activity. 
Sec. 66-28. - Restriction on number, duration. 
(a)  No person shall have more than two garage or yard sales at any residence during a consecutive 12-month period without the express approval of the village planning commission. 
(b)  No garage or yard sale may last more than 72 hours. 
Sec. 66-29. - Sales limitations. 
(a)  No wholesale sales shall be made at any garage or yard sale. 
(b)  No salesmen's or free samples or the like shall be sold at any garage or yard sale. 
Sec. 66-30. - Hours; parking; noise. 
(a)  No garage or yard sale shall continue later than one-half hour after sunset nor begin prior to 9:00 a.m. 
(b)  No garage or yard sale shall be situated so as to obstruct traffic, nor shall any sale patrons park their vehicles so as to obstruct traffic. 
(c)  Excessive noise emanating from the area of any garage or yard sale is prohibited. 
ARTICLE III. DEALERS IN PRECIOUS METALS AND GEMS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Precious metal and gem dealer act, MCL 445.481 et seq. 

Sec. 66-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Agent or employee means a person who, for compensation or valuable consideration, is employed either directly or indirectly by a dealer. 
    Dealer means any person that, in whole or in part, engages in the ordinary course of repeated and recurrent transactions of buying or receiving precious items from the public in the city. 
    Gold means elemental gold having an atomic weight of 196.967 and the chemical element symbol of Au, whether found by itself or in combination with its alloys or any other metal or substance. 
    Jewelry means an ornamental item made of a material that includes a precious gem. 
    Platinum means elemental platinum having an atomic weight of 195.09 and the chemical element symbol of Pt, whether found by itself or in combination with its alloys or any other metal. 
    Precious gem means diamond, alexandrite, ruby, sapphire, opal, amethyst, emerald, aquamarine, morganite, garnet, jadeite, topaz, tourmaline, turquoise or pearl. 
    Precious item means jewelry, a precious gem, or an item containing gold, silver, or platinum. Precious item does not include the following: 
(1)  Coins, commemorative medals, and tokens struck by, or in behalf of, a government or private mint; 
(2)  Bullion bars and discs of the type traded by banks and commodity exchanges; 
(3)  Items at the time they are purchased directly from a dealer registered under this article, a manufacturer, or a wholesaler who purchased them directly from a manufacturer; 
(4)  Industrial machinery or equipment; 
(5)  An item being returned to or exchanged by the dealer from whom the item was purchased and which is accompanied by a valid sales receipt; 
(6)  An item which is received for alteration, redesign, or repair in a manner that does not substantially change its use and returned directly to the customer; 
(7)  An item which does not have a jeweler's identifying mark or a serial mark and which the dealer purchases for less than $5.00; 
(8)  Scrap metal which contains incidental traces of gold, silver, or platinum which are recoverable as a byproduct; 
(9)  Jewelry which a customer trades for other jewelry having a greater value, and which difference in value is paid by the customer. 
    Silver means elemental silver having an atomic weight of 107.869 and the chemical element symbol of Ag, whether found by itself or in combination with its alloys or any other metal. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 445.482 
Sec. 66-32 - Registration. 
(a)  A dealer shall not conduct business in the city unless the dealer has first obtained a certificate of registration from the chief of police. 
(b)  A dealer shall apply to the chief of police for a certificate of registration by paying a fee in the sum of $50.00 to cover the reasonable cost of processing and issuing the certificate and by completing an application form, disclosing the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and thumbprint of the applicant. 
(2)  The name and address under which the applicant does business. 
(3)  The name, address, and thumbprint of all agents or employees of the dealer. Within 24 hours after hiring a new employee, the dealer shall forward to the police department the name, address, and thumbprint of the new employee. 
(c)  Upon receipt of the certificate of registration fee and an application complying with the requirements of subsection (b) of this section, and after processing the application in accordance with the requirements of the city Code and Public Act No. 95 of 1981 (MCL 445.481 et seq.), the chief of police shall issue the dealer a certificate of registration. 
(d)  Upon receipt of the certificate of registration from the chief of police, the dealer shall post it in a conspicuous place in the dealer's place of business. 
(e)  Not less than ten days before a dealer changes the name or address under which the dealer does business, the dealer shall notify the chief of police of the change. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1; § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- Certificate of registration, MCL 445.483. 
Sec. 66-33. - Expiration and renewal of certificate of registration. 
    All certificates of registration shall expire on December 31 next following their issuance. Unrevoked certificates of registration may be renewed upon expiration without further application or additional fees, unless there is a change of ownership, in which case the certificate of registration shall be treated as an application for a new certificate under section 66-32 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
Sec. 66-34. - Revocation of certificate of registration. 
    The chief of police shall, upon ten days written notice to the dealer, sent by first class mail to the business address listed on the application, revoke the certificate of registration issued under the provisions of this article when the dealer has been convicted, under section 535 of Public Act No. 328 of 1931 (MCL 750.535), of a misdemeanor within one year of the date of revocation or of a felony within five years of the date of revocation. In cases where an agent or employee of a dealer has been so convicted, the chief of police shall notify the dealer in writing, sent by first class mail to the dealer's business address. The dealer shall not permit an agent or employee who has been so convicted to operate as a dealer in the dealer's business. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
Sec. 66-35. - Permanent record of each transaction. 
(a)  A dealer shall maintain a permanent record of each transaction, on record of transaction forms provided for in subsection (F) of this section, legibly written in ink in the English language. Each record of transaction form shall be filled out in quad-duplicate by the dealer or agent or employee of the dealer. One copy of the form shall go to the chief of police pursuant to subsection (c) of this section; one copy shall go to the customer; and one copy shall be retained by the dealer pursuant to subsection (e) of this section. At the time a dealer receives or purchases a precious item, the dealer or the agent or employee of the dealer shall ensure that the following information is recorded accurately on a record of transaction form: 
(1)  The dealer certificate of registration number. 
(2)  A general description of the precious item or precious items received or purchased, including the type of metal or precious gem. In the case of watches, the description shall contain the name of the maker and the number of both the works and the case. In the case of jewelry, all letters and marks inscribed on the jewelry shall be included in the description. 
(3)  The date of the transaction. 
(4)  The name of the person conducting the transaction. 
(5)  The name, date of birth, driver's license number or state personal identification card number, and street and house number of the customer, together with a legible imprint of the right thumb of the customer, or if that is not possible, of the left thumb or a finger of the customer. However, the thumb print or fingerprint shall only be required on the record of transaction form retained by the dealer. The thumb print or fingerprint shall be made available to a police agency during the course of a police investigation involving a precious item or items described on the record of transaction. After a period of one year from the date of the record of transaction, if a police investigation concerning a precious item or items described on the record of transaction has not occurred, the dealer and any police agency holding a copy of the record of transaction shall destroy, and not keep a permanent record of, the record of transaction. A dealer who goes out of business or changes his business address to another local jurisdiction either within or out of this state shall transmit the records of all transactions made by the dealer within one year before his closing or moving, to the police department. 
(6)  The price to be paid by the dealer for the precious item or precious items. 
(7)  The form of payment made to the customer: check, money order, bank draft, or cash. If the payment is by check, money order, or bank draft, the dealer shall indicate the number of the check, money order, or bank draft. 
(8)  The customer's signature. 
(b)  The record of each transaction shall be numbered consecutively, commencing with the number "I" and the calendar year. 
(c)  Every licensee, owner, and employee, shall keep a record of all persons and/or entities with whom business has transacted and all property coming into their possession. Reports must be electronically transmitted to the chief of police or his designee. Within 48 hours, a report must be transmitted by means of electronic transmission through a modem, or similar device in a format that the data is capable or direct electronic entry into the Richmond Police Department's computerized system, as approved by the chief of police, or his designee for identifying property coming into the possession of a licensor, including but not limited to all pawn property, all transactions in which used goods have been received the preceding day by pawn, trade, purchase, or consignment and items received by junk dealers. A transaction report by electronic transmission under this sub-section shall not be reported on paper forms, unless the chief of police, or his designee so requires. 
Dealers not complying with this article shall have their city license to operate such business revoked. The licensee, following such revocation, shall not be permitted to carry on such business in the city for a period of one year. 
(d)  The record of transaction forms of a dealer and each precious item received shall be open to an inspection by the county prosecuting attorney, the city police department, the police agency or sheriff's department of the local governmental unit in which the customer resides, and the state police, at all times during the ordinary business hours of the dealer. As a condition of doing business, a dealer is considered to have given consent to the inspection prescribed by this subsection. The record of transaction forms of a dealer shall not be open to inspection by the general public. 
(e)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, each record of a transaction shall be retained by the dealer for not less than one year after the transaction to which the record pertains. 
(f)  The form of the record of transaction shall have an 8 1/2 by 11-inch size and shall be as follows: 
Record of Transaction Dealer Certificate # # (printed on the form) # (Transaction number printed on the form) (1) Description of Property (2) (Date), 20___ (3) (Name of Dealer/Employee) (4) (Name of Customer) (Date of Birth), ___ (Driver's license No./MI Personal ID Number) (Street Address) (City & State) (Zip) (5) (Price Paid) (County of Residence) (Check No., Bank Draft No., (6) Money Order No., or Cash (Name of Police Agency or City, Village, or Township in which customer resides.) Thumb-print (Signature of Customer)  
(g)  As used in this section, the term "customer" means the person from whom the dealer or the agent or employee of the dealer receives or purchases a precious item. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 445.484. 
Sec. 66-36. - Retaining precious item for nine calendar days; alteration. 
    A precious item received by a dealer shall be retained by the dealer for nine calendar days after it was received, without any form of alteration other than that required to make an accurate appraisal of its value. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 445.485. 
Sec. 66-37. - Prohibited conduct. 
    A dealer or an agent or employee of a dealer shall not: 
(1)  Knowingly receive or purchase a precious item from any person who is less than 18 years of age or any person known by the dealer or agent or employee of the dealer to have been convicted of theft or receipt of stolen property within the preceding five years, whether the person is acting in his own behalf or as the agent of another. 
(2)  Knowingly receive or purchase a precious item from a person unless that person presents a valid driver's license or a valid state personal identification card. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 445.486. 
ARTICLE IV. - PAWNBROKERS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Pawnbrokers licensing, MCL 446.201 et seq., 445.471 et seq. 

Sec. 66-38. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Ancillary means an auxiliary or subordinate operation that aids another business considered as principle and shall in no instance amount for greater than 50 percent of the business' gross revenues. 
    Category means a general class to which a good belongs including, by way of example but not limited to: jewelry, clocks, guns, art work, sports equipment, garments, musical instruments, appliances, audio and visual equipment, computer equipment, books, furniture, etc. 
    Gross revenues means the total amount of compensation (money or value of other considerations received) from selling goods or from performing services in the operation of the pawnbroker's principal business. 
    Pawnbroker means any person, corporation, or member or members of a copartnership or firm, who loans money on deposit or pledge of personal property, or other valuable thing, other than securities or printed evidence of indebtedness, or who deals in the purchasing of personal property or other valuable thing on condition of selling the same back again at a stipulated price. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
Sec. 66-39. - Intent and purpose of article. 
    The intent and purpose of this article is to regulate pawnbrokers as necessary to advance the public welfare, health, and safety; to limit the licensing of pawnbrokers to those persons who already have an established business within the corporate limits of the city other than as a pawnbroker; to limit the operation of a pawnbroker to accepting for pawn one category of goods sold in the course of business so that such service shall always be ancillary to the existing established business; to provide for the taking of fingerprints and the making of reports to enforcement officers; and to prescribe penalties for the violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
Sec. 66-40. - License required. 
(a)  No person shall engage in the business of a pawnbroker, within the corporate limits of the city, without having first obtained a license therefor. 
(b)  This license shall be for the period of one year from the date of issuance, unless sooner revoked for cause, and shall not be transferrable. 
(c)  This license shall designate the following: 
(1)  The particular place in the city where such person shall carry on the pawnbroker business. 
(2)  The name of the primary business established and operated by the person. 
(3)  The one category of goods to be accepted for pawn. 
(d)  No such license shall be granted without the approval of the mayor or his designee, which for purposes of this chapter shall be the chief of police, nor until the applicant has complied with such of the following requirements of this article as are applicable to him or her. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- Licenses, MCL 446.202. 
Sec. 66-41. - Requirements for license. 
    Every applicant shall: 
(1)  Obtain a certificate of registration from the chief of police. 
(2)  Furnish proof of an established primary business within the corporate limits of the city other than pawnbroker. 
(3)  Pay to the treasurer a nonrefundable annual license fee of $50.00. 
(4)  Post a bond to the city in its corporate name, for the faithful performance of the duties and obligations pertaining to the business and for the payment of all costs and damages incurred by any violation of this article, in the penal sum of $3,000.00, with at least two sureties, which bond shall be approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
Sec. 66-42. - Requirements for license renewal. 
(a)  At the time a pawnbroker shall seek renewal of the license, each pawnbroker shall, in a timely fashion, sign and submit an affidavit to the city council stating that his pawn shop operation was limited to one classification of goods and it did not exceed 50 percent of the gross revenues of the principal business operation. 
(b)  The city council reserves the right to require financial records for its review as it may deem necessary to verify the pawnbroker's affidavit. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
Sec. 66-43. - Record of property received. 
(a)  At the time a pawnbroker shall receive any article of personal property, or other valuable thing by way of pledge or pawn, he shall keep a book, written in English, which shall include the following: 
(1)  A description of such article, a sequential transaction number, any amount of money loaned thereon; and
