(2)  The name, residence, general description and driver license number, official state personal identification card number, or government identification number of the person from whom the article was received, and the day and hour when such property was received. 
The record, the place where such business is carried on, and all articles of property in that place of business are subject to examination at any time by the city attorney, city police department, the county prosecuting attorney, or the department of state police. 
(b)  Upon the receipt of any article by way of pawn or pledge, the pawnbroker shall make a permanent record of the transaction on a form provided by the pawnbroker that substantially complies with the form described in state law, MCL 446.205(4). Each record of transaction shall be completed in duplicate by the pawnbroker, legibly in the English language, and shall contain all applicable information required to complete the record of transaction form referenced herein. 
The pawnbroker shall retain a record of each transaction, and within 48 hours, a copy of the record of transaction report must be transmitted to the Richmond Police Department by means of electronic transmission through a modem, or similar device in a format that the data is capable or direct electronic entry into the Richmond Police Department's computerized system, as approved by the chief of police, or his designee for identifying property coming into the possession of a licensor. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.205. 
Sec. 66-44. - Fingerprints of seller. 
    At the same time any pawnbroker shall receive any article of personal property or other valuable thing by way of pledge or pawn, he shall take in duplicate the legible imprint of the right thumb of the person from whom such property was received, or if that is not possible, of the left thumb or some other finger of such person. Such fingerprint shall be taken under such rules and regulations as prescribed by the commissioner of the state police. One copy shall be forwarded within 48 hours, together with a statement of the nature of the property received, to the chief of police. The second copy shall be forwarded within 48 hours, together with a statement of the nature of the property received, to the commissioner of the state police in East Lansing. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 445.472. 
Sec. 66-45. - Statement to police of property received. 
    Every such pawnbroker shall make daily a sworn statement of his transactions, describing the goods or pledge received, and setting forth the name, residence and description of the person from whom the goods or pledge were received, a copy of which shall be provided to the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.206. 
Sec. 66-46 - Purchaser's memorandum of pawn. 
    A pawnbroker, at the time of such loan, shall deliver to the person pawning or pledging any goods, article or thing a memorandum or note signed by him, containing the substance of the entry required to be made by him pursuant to section 40-126. No charge shall be made or received by any pawnbroker for any such entry, memorandum or note. The memorandum or note shall be consecutively numbered and upon its back shall be printed in English, the following: "If interest or charges in excess of three percent per month, plus storage charges hereinafter provided, are asked or received, this loan is void and of no effect; and the borrower cannot be made to pay back the money loaned or any interest, or any charges or any part thereof, and the pawnbroker loses all right to the possession of the goods, article or thing pawned, and shall surrender the same to the borrower or pawner upon due demand therefor." 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.208. 
Sec. 66-47. - Interest on loans. 
    A licensed pawnbroker may charge upon any loan a rate of interest not to exceed three percent per month and is not required to accept any interest less than $0.50 on a single loan. A pawnbroker may also charge $1.00 per month or fraction of a month for the storage of property under any single pledge or pawn. A pawnbroker or the pawnbroker's agent or employee shall not charge or receive interest on the loan in excess of the amounts provided for herein or by state law. Interest on any loan is not payable in advance and shall be computed on unpaid monthly balances without compounding. A pawnbroker is not entitled to any examination fee and shall not make any charge in excess of the amounts provided for in this article by state law. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.209. 
Sec. 66-48. - Vesting of title to item pledged or pawned. 
    Title to the item pledged or pawned vests in the pawnbroker upon the expiration of three months or of any period beyond three months agreed upon by the parties if the borrower has not paid the debt, interest and charges on the item pledged or pawned. A pawnbroker shall not sell any pawn or pledge until the item has remained in his possession for at least three months. Thereafter, disposition of such item pawned or pledged shall be pursuant to applicable state law. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.210. 
Sec. 66-49. - Tender of debt and costs before sale. 
    If, at any time before the disposition of the item pledged or pawned, the borrower pays or tenders to the pawnbroker the debt and interests and charges on the item, that payment or tender reinvests the pawner with the title and right of possession to the property pledged. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.211. 
Sec. 66-50. - Destruction or defacing pawned property. 
    No pawnbroker shall deface, scratch, obliterate, melt, separate or break into parts any particle or thing received by him in pawn or otherwise, or in any manner do, cause or suffer to be done by others, anything which shall destroy or tend to destroy the identity of such article or render the identification thereof more difficult. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.213. 
Sec. 66-51. - Acceptance of property from minor. 
    A pawnbroker shall not receive for pawn any article from any person under 18 years of age or a person the pawnbroker suspects as having stolen the article to be pawned. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.214. 
Sec. 66-52. - Business on Sunday. 
    No person shall conduct or engage in the business of a pawnbroker in the city on the first day of each week, commonly called Sunday. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.217. 
Sec. 66-53. - Action on pawnbroker's bond. 
    If any person shall be aggrieved by the conduct of any such licensed pawnbroker, and shall recover judgment against him therefore, such person may, after the return unsatisfied, either in whole or in part, of any execution issued upon said judgment, maintain an action in his own name upon the bond of the said pawnbroker in any court having jurisdiction of the amount of said judgment remaining unsatisfied. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.204. 
Sec. 66-54. - Violation. 
    Any person who shall be convicted of a violation of this article shall have his license revoked by the city council and no part of the license fee paid shall be returned to him, and no further license as a pawnbroker shall be granted to the person for the period of one year from the date of such revocation. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 446.219. 
Sec. 66-55. - Applicability of state law. 
    A pawnbroker licensed under this article shall be subject to any further applicable state law regulations and is hereby put on notice of the existence of same as found in MCL 445.471 et seq. and MCL 446.201 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
ARTICLE V. JUNK AND SECONDHAND DEALERS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Licensing of secondhand and junk dealers, MCL 445.401 et seq., 445.471 et seq. 

Sec. 66-56. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dealer in secondhand goods means any person who deals in, buys, sells, or receives secondhand goods, except those described in the definition of "junk dealer" of this section; provided, however, that nothing contained in this article shall apply to persons engaged in the business of buying, selling, or exchanging secondhand motor vehicles. 
    Junk dealer means any person who buys, sells, or receives at a fixed location within the city what is commonly called junk, such as rags, paper, old rope, bags, bagging, iron, brass, copper, tin, zinc, aluminum, scrap or discarded metal, bottles or other articles whether manufactured or in process of manufacture, or raw material, whether old or new. 
    Junk gatherer means any person not a licensed junk dealer and not in the exclusive employ of a licensed junk dealer, who buys, sells, receives or picks up the articles mentioned in the definition of "junk dealer" in this section with a cart, wagon or other vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
Sec. 66-57. - Licenses required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of a junk dealer, junk gatherer or dealer in secondhand goods and merchandise, within the corporate limits of the city, without first having obtained a license therefor. No such license shall be granted without the approval of the mayor or his or her designee, which for purposes of this article shall be the chief of police, nor until the applicant has complied with such of the following requirements of this article as are applicable to him or her. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- License required, MCL 445.401. 
Sec. 66-58. - Requirements for licenses. 
    Every applicant shall: 
(1)  Obtain a certification of registration from the chief of police. 
(2)  Applicants for a junk gatherer's license shall furnish a recent photograph and their fingerprints for the noncriminal files of the police department. 
(3)  Applicants for a junk dealer's license whose business is to be conducted on a vacant lot or in a partially enclosed structure shall enclose such property with a properly painted tight board fence at least six feet high and erected in such a manner as to obliterate the premises from view, which fence shall at all times be properly maintained by the licensee. 
(4)  Every applicant shall execute a statement that the certificate of registration issued to him or her may be suspended or revoked by the chief of police for a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
Sec. 66-59. - Location of business. 
    Each license issued under this article, except a junk gatherer's license, shall designate the particular place in said city where such business may be conducted, and it shall be unlawful for any licensee to engage in such business at any place other than that designated in such license. No person, except the licensee, directly or indirectly shall do business or be permitted to do business under said license. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
Sec. 66-60. - Junk gatherer's license. 
    The junk gatherer's license shall be in such form as to contain the photographs, signatures and fingerprints of the licensee and a blank space upon which may be entered a record of any arrests and convictions against him. It shall be unlawful for such licensee to remove, deface or obliterate anything contained in such license. Such licensee shall affix to either side of his vehicle the license plates which shall be furnished free of charge by the city clerk. Such license plates shall be made of some durable material of a design to be changed each year, and shall contain the number of the license, the year issued and the words "licensed junk gatherer." 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
Sec. 66-61. - License revocation. 
    Certificates of registration issued under the provisions of this article shall be revocable by the chief of police at any time for a violation of any law of the state, of any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
Sec. 66-62. - Lending money. 
    No licensee shall receive in the course of his business any article by way of pledge or pawn, nor shall he loan or advance any sum of money on the security of any article or thing. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
Sec. 66-63. - Fingerprints of seller; copies to municipal and state police. 
    At the time any licensee shall acquire or purchase any article of personal property, or other valuable thing, except new articles, wares, or merchandise purchased at wholesale from manufacturers, wholesale distributors or jobbers for retail sale to customers, except also motor vehicles, old rags, wastepaper, books, magazines, tapestries, antiques and household furniture, he shall take in duplicate the legible imprint of the right thumb of the person from whom such property was received, or if that is not possible, or the left thumb or some other finger of such person. Such fingerprint shall be taken under such rules and regulations as prescribed by the director of the state police and that copy shall be forwarded within 48 hours, together with a statement of the nature of the property received, to the director of the state police. 
    The second copy shall be forwarded, within 48 hours, and must be transmitted by means of electronic transmission through a modem, or similar device in a format that the data is capable or direct electronic entry into the Richmond Police Department's computerized system, as approved by the chief of police, or his designee together with a statement reporting the nature of the property received, as well as information of the persons and/or entities with whom business was transacted, to the chief of police or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 445.472. 
Sec. 66-64. - Records. 
    Each licensee shall keep a book in which shall be written in ink and in the English language the day, hour, name, age, and address of each person buying, selling or leaving any article, including a complete description of all articles received and/or disposed of that can be readily identified by a trade name or by a number. No entry in such book shall be erased, obliterated, altered or defaced. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 445.404. 
Sec. 66-65. - Goods purchased; retention, tagging, record; exceptions. 
    Articles, purchased or exchanged by a licensee, shall be retained by the purchaser thereof, for at least 15 days before disposing of them, in an accessible place in the building where such articles are purchased and received. A tag shall be attached to such articles in some visible and convenient place, with the number written thereupon, to correspond with the entry number in such book. Such purchaser shall prepare and deliver on Monday of each week to the chief of police, before 12:00 noon, a legible and correct copy written in the English language from such book, containing a description of each article purchased or received during the preceding week, the hour and day when the purchase was made, and the description of the person from whom it was purchased. Such statement shall be verified by the affidavit of the person subscribing his name thereto. This section shall not apply to old rags, wastepaper and household goods except radios, televisions, record players and electrical appliances. Nothing herein contained shall make it necessary for the purchaser to retain articles purchased from individuals, firms or corporations having a fixed place of business after said articles shall have been reported. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 445.405. 
Sec. 66-66. - Person without business place; retention of goods; record for police. 
    If the purchaser or receiver is a peddler or goes about with a wagon to purchase or obtain, by exchange or otherwise, any articles, and does not have a place of business in a building, he need not retain such articles for 15 days before selling them, provided that on Monday of each week he files with the chief of police a report showing the place of business of the person to whom such sale was made; a copy of the record required by such section to be kept in a separate book of the articles purchased or received during the preceding week, including a description of such articles sold; to whom sold; and his place of business. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 445.406. 
Sec. 66-67. - Prohibited purchases. 
    No holder of a certificate of registration shall purchase, receive or take any article mentioned in this chapter from any person under the age of 18 years, from an intoxicated person, or from any person the holder of the certificate of registration has reason to suspect has received stolen property. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 445.407. 
Sec. 66-68. - Encroachment on street. 
    No licensee shall make use of any street, sidewalk, or other part of the highway, or any other property not in his possession, or under his control, for the storage or display of junk or other secondhand goods. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
Sec. 66-69. - Access to premises. 
    The chief of police and the members of the police force shall at all times have free access to all parts of the premises, for which a license has been granted, and refusal to give such access by any person on such premises shall be a sufficient cause to work a forfeiture of said license. 
(Ord. No. 159, § 1, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 159-1, § 1, 11-4-13) 
Chapter 70 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 50. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 70-1-70-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 

Sec. 70-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bags means plastic sacks designed for refuse with sufficient wall strength to maintain physical integrity when lifted by the top; securely tied at the top for collection with a capacity not to exceed 32 gallons and a loaded weight not to exceed 50 pounds. 
    Bulky waste means over-sized household items (box springs, white goods, furntiure, etc.). 
    Bundle means yard and garden trimmings or newspaper and magazines securely tied together forming an easily handled package not exceeding three feet in length or 50 pounds in weight. 
    Construction debris means waste building materials resulting from construction, remodeling, repair or demolition operations. 
    Garbage means the putrescible animal or vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking, serving or consumption of food and including food containers. 
    Hazardous waste means waste designated as hazardous or containing hazardous substances in amounts or concentrations of regulatory concern by the United States Environmental Protection Agency or appropriate state agency. 
    Recyclable material means newsprint, metal, glass, plastic (#1, #2, and #3), and yard wastes for composting. 
    Rubbish means non-putrescible solid wastes consisting of combustibles and non-combustible materials, being the miscellaneous waste material resulting from housekeeping and ordinary mercantile enterprises, trades, manufacturers, offices and stores, including ashes, cartons, tin cans, metal, small packing boxes and waste papers, excluding discarded materials from building construction or repair or refuse from industrial plants. Rubbish does not include hazardous waste, as defined above. 
    Supervisor means the designated representative(s) of the city. 
(Ord. No. 79, art. I, 3-13-67; Ord. No. 79-1(2), § 1, 5-17-04) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 70-27. - Purpose and intent of article. 
    It is the intent of the city council that this article be liberally construed for the purpose of providing a sanitary and satisfactory method of collecting and disposing of municipal wastes. The supervisor is authorized to make such rules and regulations as from time to time appear to him to be necessary to carry out this intent; provided, however, that such rules do not conflict with this or other ordinances of the city or state or federal law. 
(Ord. No. 79, art. II, 3-13-67; Ord. No. 79-1(2), § 1, 5-17-04) 
Sec. 70-28. - Collection of garbage and rubbish generally. 
    Garbage and rubbish shall be collected by city-approved contractors at such times and pursuant to rules and regulations established by the supervisor. Such rules and regulations shall be published in a newspaper in general circulation in the city at least once before such rules and regulations become effective, and as often as the supervisor shall deem necessary. 
(Ord. No. 79, art. III, 3-13-67; Ord. No. 79-1(2), § 1, 5-17-04) 
Sec. 70-29. - Required containers and collection procedures. 
(a)  Containers for garbage and rubbish required. The owner, occupant or lessor, or any agent thereof, of every premises where garbage and rubbish accumulate, shall cause to be provided for the premises sufficient and proper containers as prescribed in this section. Containers that are broken, without handles, or which otherwise fail to comply with the requirements of this article, may be classed as rubbish and, after due notice to the user, may be collected as rubbish. 
(b)  Placement and accessibility of garbage container. The container for garbage shall be kept on the premises in the rear thereof within an approved distance of the rear entrance to the dwelling or premises. Containers shall be placed at the curb on pickup days and readily accessible to the collectors. Where approved bags are used, it will only be necessary to place the bag and contents at the curb securely bound at the top. 
(c)  Construction and capacity of garbage container. Garbage containers shall be of substantial, approved construction, free of holes, with proper handles and tightfitting cover, and shall have a capacity of not less than ten gallons nor more than 32 gallons, and no single container shall weigh more than 50 pounds when full. Garbage containers shall be adequate in size and number to hold one week's accumulation. All garbage containers shall be maintained in a sanitary condition. 
(d)  Construction and capacity of rubbish containers. Rubbish containers shall be metal or durable polyvinyl with handles, in good condition, and shall have a capacity of not less than ten gallons nor more than 32 gallons, and no single container shall weigh more than 50 pounds when full. Rubbish containers, other than metal or durable polyvinyl with handles in good condition, as specified in this section, may be collected as rubbish without notice, except that garbage containers may be used as rubbish containers. 
(e)  Construction and capacity of yard waste containers. Yard waste containers shall be metal or durable polyvinyl with handles, in good condition, and shall have a capacity of not less than ten gallons nor more than 32 gallons, and no single container shall weigh more than 50 pounds when full. Yard waste containers shall have the approved decal for yard waste affixed to it. Where approved recycling bags are used, it will only be necessary to place the recycling bag and contents at the curb. 
(f)  Recycling bins. Recycling bins shall be as supplied to the city residents by the solid waste contractor. Recycling bins are used for newsprint, metal, glass and plastic. 
(g)  Accumulations of rubbish and yard waste larger than container. Accumulations of rubbish larger than can be contained in a receptacle shall be securely tied in compact bundles not to exceed 50 pounds in weight and placed in a location designated by the supervisor. Brush and tree limbs will be picked up provided they are securely tied in bundles not over three feet in length, nor over 50 pounds in weight. Crhistmas trees do not have to be bundled and will be picked up following Christmas. 
(h)  Bulky waste. Collection of bulky wastes will be made upon request of the municipality and/or a resident. Setting the bulky waste at the roadside constituents a request. Residential units are entitled to one bulky item per week. 
(i)  Empty containers. Empty containers shall not be left at the curb more than 24 hours. 
(j)  Ashes. Ashes will be removed only when placed in rubbish containers as specified in this section. 
(k)  Disturbing container contents prohibited. No person shall disturb the contents of any garbage or rubbish container or bundle, or leave the container or contents in a condition other than this article provides. 
(l)  Fixed or stationary containers. Fixed or stationary garbage or rubbish containers may be used only upon the approval by the supervisor as to size, location and construction. 
(Ord. No. 79, art. IV, 3-13-67; Ord. No. 79-1(2), § 1, 5-17-04) 
Sec. 70-30. - Disposal and removal of industrial and building construction waste. 
(a)  Collection and disposal of industrial waste from manufacturing plants shall be the responsibility of between the owner or operator of such plants. 
(b)  Collection and disposal of waste materials resulting from building construction, remodeling, repairs or demolition operations shall be the responsibility of the contractor or owner performing said work. 
(Ord. No. 79, art. V, 3-13-67; Ord. No. 79-1(2), § 1, 5-17-04) 
Sec. 70-31. - Burying; burning; depositing of garbage and rubbish on public or private property. 
(a)  No person shall bury or burn any garbage, or deposit garbage or rubbish upon any public way or upon any property owned by another or in any body of water within the city, nor shall any person deposit or place any garbage upon any premises owned or occupied by him, unless the garbage is enclosed in a suitable container as required in section 70-29. 
(b)  No waste material shall be burned within the city. 
(Ord. No. 79, art. VI, 3-13-67; Ord. No. 79-1(2), § 1, 5-17-04) 
Sec. 70-32. - Duty of owners and occupants to provide for collection. 
    Every owner, occupant or lessor, or any agent thereof of any single-family, duplex, triplex or quadplex residential building where garbage or rubbish accumulate, shall arrange with the supervisor for garbage and rubbish collection. Every owner, occupant or lessor, or any agent thereof of any multiple-family building greater than four units and any commercial or industrial building where garbage or rubbish accumulate, shall make their own arrangements for garbage and rubbish collection. 
(Ord. No. 79, art. VII, 3-13-67; Ord. No. 79-1(2), § 1, 5-17-04) 
Sec. 70-33. - Garbage and rubbish container racks. 
(a)  For every single-family home which abuts on an alley, each multiple dwelling, and every business establishment where garbage is collected, the owner, lessor, or agent of every building must provide the garbage container rack. 
(b)  In each classification listed in subsection (a) of this section all garbage containers shall be placed on a rack not less than 12 inches and not more than 24 inches above the ground, with a clear space under the rack for cleaning out spilled waste matter. Container covers shall be chained or securely tied with a two-foot length of chain or rope fastened to the rack. Containers shall not be chained or tied to the rack. A diagram of how to build the rack is available at the sanitation department. 
(c)  All racks shall be located on private property. In alley collection areas the rack shall be located as near as possible to the alley line, but not in any alley, street or other public property, except where it has been deemed impractical by the supervisor. 
(Ord. No. 79, art. VIII, 3-13-67) 
Sec. 70-34. - Rates and charges. 
(a)  Established by council. The rates for garbage and rubbish collection shall be established by council resolution and amended at such times as deemed necessary by the city council to defray the cost of collection. 
(b)  Collection fees. Collection fees for solid waste pick up shall be placed on the July property tax statement. Fees for solid waste pick up are to be billed each year on the July tax statement for the period of July 1 of that year through June 30 of the following year. 
(c)  Payment due dates; collection fee. All charges for garbage and rubbish services shall be payable on or before the due date shown on the property tax statement. If any garbage or rubbish charges shall not be paid on or before the due date shown on the statement, there shall be added to the amount shown on such statement a collection fee of ten percent. 
(d)  Delinquency; lien. The charges for garbage and rubbish service are hereby made a lien on all premises served thereby. 
(Ord. No. 79, art. IX, 3-13-67; Ord. No. 79-1(1), art. 1, 8-15-96; Ord. No. 79-1(2), § 1, 5-17-04; Ord. No. 79-2, § 1, 3-4-2013) 
Sec. 70-35. - Penalty for violations of article. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to the penalties prescribed in section 1-13. 
(Ord. No. 79, art. X, 3-13-67) 
Chapter 74 - SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78; subdivisions, ch. 82; taxation, ch. 86; vegetation, ch. 98. 
State Law reference- Powers re assessments, MCL 117.4a, 117.4b, 117.4d, 117.5; special assessment notices and hearings, MCL 211.741 et seq.; deferment of special assessments for older persons, MCL 211.761 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 74-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cost means the expense of survey, spreading of roll, notice, advertising, printing, financing, legal, engineering, construction, condemnation and all other costs incidental to the making of the improvement or the abatement of the hazard or nuisance. 
    Improvement means any public betterment. 
    Lot or parcel of land means any subdivision lot or portion thereof as officially platted or any unplatted parcel of land as may be described on any official record. 
    Owner means the last recorded title holder of any lot or parcel of land. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 2, 2-13-67) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 74-2-74-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADVISORY PETITIONS 

Sec. 74-26. - Response to council request. 
    The council, in order to ascertain whether or not a reasonable number of property owners to be assessed desires any particular improvement to be made, may request and receive a petition therefor, or may receive such a petition voluntarily presented; but in either event, such petition shall be advisory only and shall not be jurisdictional. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 3.1, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-27. - Contents. 
    All advisory petitions shall be addressed to the council and contain a brief description of the improvement sought to be made or the nuisance or hazard sought to be abated and shall be signed by property owners only, whose signatures shall be followed by a brief description of the property owned by them. The signatures on such petitions shall be verified by the oath of one or more of the circulators of such petition before filing. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 3.2, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-28. - Filing. 
    Advisory petitions shall be filed with the clerk who shall check them for signatures and correctness and if they are found to be in order, he shall refer them to the manager who shall present them to the council at its next regular or special meeting called for that purpose, together with his recommendations. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 3.3, 2-13-67) 
Secs. 74-29-74-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 74-51. - Initiatory resolution. 
    When, by the provisions of the city Charter and the laws of the state, the council shall have power to make a public improvement by special assessment, it shall by resolution set forth the improvement intended to be made and direct the manager to prepare a report with the assistance of the engineer containing any information it may request concerning such improvement. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 4.1, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-52. - Plans and specifications. 
    The manager shall request the engineer to prepare or cause to be prepared plans and specifications of the improvement to be made, an estimate of the life of the improvement and of the cost thereof, and plats of the lands affected thereby, and such other information as the council may have requested. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 4.2, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-53. - Report of manager. 
    The manager shall prepare his report and include in it a schedule of all property affected by the proposed improvement, listing the assessed valuation, tax delinquencies, whether land is vacant or improved, and pertinent information on such parcels as are owned by public authorities and such other information as the council may have requested. He shall present it together with his recommendation as to what proportion of the cost should be paid by special assessment and what part, if any, should be a general obligation of the city, the number of installments in which the assessment should be spread and the lands which should be included in the special assessment district. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 4.3, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-54. - Notice of hearing; contents. 
(a)  After the filing of the report and plans and specifications above referred to, the council shall by resolution order the same filed with the clerk and provide for a public hearing before it on the improvement to be made, which hearing shall be not less than one week after notice thereof has been given by first class mail to the owner of each lot or parcel of land affected thereby at his address or the address shown on the last tax roll of the city and by publication at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, to be designated by the council, or by posting notices thereof for the same length of time in three public places within the city. 
(b)  The notice shall include a statement that appearance and protest at the hearing in the special assessment proceedings is required in order to appeal the amount of the special assessment to the state tax tribunal, and that an owner or party in interest, or his agent, may appear in person at the hearing to protest the special assessment or may file his appearance or protest by letter and his personal appearance shall not be required. The notice shall further include a statement that the owner or any party having an interest in the real property may file a written appeal of the special assessment with the state tax tribunal within 30 days after the confirmation of the special assessment role if that special assessment was protested at the hearing held for the purpose of confirming the role. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 4.4, 2-13-67) 
State Law reference- Special assessment notices and hearings, MCL 211.741 et seq. 
Sec. 74-55. - Public hearing; objections and changes. 
    At the time and place specified in such notice for the public hearing, the council shall meet and hear any person to be affected by the proposed public improvement. The hearing may be adjourned from time to time by the council, and the council may make any changes in the proposed work or assessment which shall seem reasonable or proper in view of any objections, or for any other reason which may appear to be for the best interests of the city, provided that if the improvements intended to be made are enlarged upon or additions made to the district to be assessed, the improvements shall not be done until after another hearing is held pursuant to the notice as required for the original hearing. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 4.5, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-56. - Resolution of determination. 
    After the public hearing, the council may, by resolution, determine to make the improvement and defray the whole or any part of the cost of the improvement by special assessment upon the property especially benefitted in proportion to the benefits derived, or to be derived and designated whether it is to be assessed according to frontage or other basis. By such resolution, the council shall approve the plans and specifications for the improvements, determine the number of installments in which assessments may be paid, determine the rate of interest to be charged on installments not to exceed six percent per annum, designate the district or land and premises upon which special assessments shall be levied, direct the assessor to prepare a special assessment roll in accordance with the council's determination and designate the name by which the assessment roll shall be known and referred to. Notwithstanding the provisions of the previous sentence, in instances where the city will be issuing obligations in anticipation of special assessments, the interest rate to be charged shall be governed by the provisions of the Municipal Finance Act, specifically 1973 PA 70, being MCL 133.9. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 4.6, 2-13-67; Ord. No. 78-1, art. 1, 9-5-00) 
Sec. 74-57. - Special assessment roll. 
    The assessor shall thereupon prepare a special assessment roll including all lots and parcels of land within the special assessment district designated by the council, and shall assess to each such lot or parcel of land such relative portion of the whole sum to be levied against all the lands in the special assessment district as the benefit to such lot or parcel of land bears to the total benefits to all lands in such district. There shall also be entered upon such roll the amount which has been assessed to the city at large. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 4.7, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-58. - Certificate of assessor. 
    When the assessor shall have completed such assessment roll, he shall attach thereto or endorse thereon his certificate to the effect that the roll has been made by him pursuant to a resolution of the council (giving the date of adoption of the resolution) and that in making the assessments he has, as near as may be according to his best judgement, conformed in all respects to the directions contained in such resolution and the city Charter and the provisions of this article. Thereupon, he shall file the special assessment roll with the clerk who shall present the special assessment roll to the council. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 4.8, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-59. - Notice of hearing on roll. 
    Upon receipt of such special assessment roll the council shall order it filed in the office of the clerk for public examination, and shall by resolution fix the time and place when the council will meet and review such roll, which meeting shall be held not less than one week after a notice specifying the purpose, time and place of such meeting has been given by first class mail to the owner of each lot or parcel of land affected thereby at his address or the address shown on the last tax roll of the city, and by publication at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city to be designated by the council, or by posting notice thereof for the same length of time in three public places within the city. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 4.9, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-60. - Written objections. 
    Any person deeming himself aggrieved by the special assessment roll may file his objections thereto in writing with the clerk prior to the close of the hearing, which written objections shall specify in what respect he deems himself aggrieved. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 4.10, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-61. - Hearing on objections. 
    The council shall meet and review the special assessment roll at the time and place appointed or at an adjourned date therefor and shall consider any written objections thereto. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 4.11, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-62. - Objection to improvement. 
    If, at or prior to final confirmation of any special assessment, more than 50 percent of the number of owners of privately owned real property to be assessed for any improvement or in case of paving or similar improvements more than 50 percent of the number of owners of frontage to be assessed for any such improvement shall object in writing to the proposed improvement, the improvement shall not be made by proceedings authorized by this article without a five-sevenths vote of the members of the council, provided that this section shall not apply to sidewalk construction. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 4.12, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-63. - Corrections and changes. 
    The council may correct the roll as to any assessment or description of any lot or parcel of land or other errors appearing therein. Any changes made in such roll shall be noted in the council minutes. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 4.13, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-64. - Confirmation or rejection of roll. 
    After such hearing and review, the council may confirm such special assessment roll with such corrections as may have been made, if any, or may refer it back to the assessor for revision or may annul it and any proceedings in connection therewith. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 4.14, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-65. - Certificate of confirmation. 
    The clerk shall endorse the date of confirmation upon each special assessment roll and, upon confirmation, such roll shall be final and conclusive. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 4.15, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-66. - Contractual provisions. 
    If all persons or property owners to be affected by any proposed improvement agree that such proposed improvement be made and that a special assessment be levied in connection therewith, the city may in lieu of the foregoing procedure enter into a written contract with all of the persons or property owners affected thereby, which contract when properly approved and executed shall operate as a complete special assessment procedure and the assessment shall be made in accordance with the contract. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 4.16, 2-13-67) 
Secs. 74-67-74-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - HAZARD OR NUISANCE ABATEMENT 

Sec. 74-86. - Resolution and notice. 
    When any lot, parcel of land, building or structure within the city, because of accumulation of refuse or debris, the uncontrolled growing of noxious weeds, or age or dilapidation, or because of any other condition or happening becomes, in the opinion of the council, a public hazard or nuisance which is dangerous to the health, safety or welfare of the inhabitants of the city or of those residing or habitually going near such lot, parcel of land, building or structure, the council may, after investigation, by resolution determine that a hazard or nuisance exists, prescribe a form of notice and direct the clerk to give such notice by first class mail addressed to the owners of the land upon which such nuisance exists or to the owner of the building or structure itself at his address or the address shown on the last tax roll of the city and by publication at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, to be designated by the council, to abate such nuisance or remove such hazard. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 5.1, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-87. - Contents of notice. 
    The notice to abate or remove the hazard or nuisance shall specify the nature of the hazard or nuisance, describe the property on which the hazard or nuisance is located, require the owner to abate or remove the hazard or nuisance promptly and shall designate a time within which the hazard or nuisance shall be abated or removed which shall be commensurate with the nature of the hazard or nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 5.2, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-88. - Removal by city. 
    If, at the expiration of the time limit specified in the notice to abate or remove the hazard or nuisance, the owner has not complied with the requirements thereof or in any case where the owner of the land or of the building or structure itself is not known, the council may by resolution order such hazard removed or nuisance abated under the direction of the manager by the proper department or agency of the city, or may cause the work to be done by contract or by hire. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 5.3, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-89. - Manager's duties. 
    The manager shall take all steps necessary to carry out the directions of the council in removing a hazard or abating a nuisance, shall keep or cause to be kept an accurate record of all expenses in connection therewith, and upon completion of the work to be performed shall submit a report of the work done and all expense in connection therewith to the council. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 5.4, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-90. - Assessment of costs. 
    The council shall by resolution, after examination of the manager's report, determine what amount or part of each such expense shall be charged and the person, if known, against whom the premises upon which the amount shall be levied as a special assessment and shall require notice of all amounts so reported and determined to be given by the clerk by first class mail to the owner of each lot or parcel of land at his address or the address shown on the last tax roll of the city, and by publication at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, to be designated by the council. Such notice shall state the basis of the assessment, the cost thereof, and shall give a reasonable time which shall not be less than 30 days in which payment shall be made. In all cases where payment is not made within the time limit, the same shall be reported by the clerk to the assessor who shall spread such amounts against the several persons on descriptions of real property chargeable therewith on the next roll for the collection of city taxes. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 5.5, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-91. - Certificates of assessor. 
    When the assessor shall have completed such assessment roll, he shall attach thereto and endorse thereon his certificate to the effect that the roll has been made by him pursuant to a resolution of the council, giving the date of adoption of the roll, and that in making the assessments therein he has, as near as may be according to his best judgement, conformed in all respects to the directions contained in such resolution and the city Charter and thereupon file such special assessment roll with the clerk. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 5.6, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-92. - Corrections and confirmation of roll. 
    The council may correct the roll as to any assessment or description of any lot or parcel of land or other errors appearing therein. Any changes made in the roll shall be noted in the council minutes. The council shall thereupon confirm such special assessment roll with such corrections as may have been made and the clerk shall endorse the date of confirmation thereon. Upon confirmation, such roll shall be final and conclusive. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 5.7, 2-13-67) 
Secs. 74-93-74-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SIDEWALK AND DRIVEWAY APPROACHES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Sidewalks, § 78-26 et seq. 

Sec. 74-116. - Construction. 
    Sidewalks, except crosswalks, and driveway approaches shall be built and maintained by the owners of platted lands in the public streets adjacent to and abutting upon such lots and premises according to plans and specifications approved by the city engineer, provided that in any case when the main purpose of sidewalk is to provide travel convenient to and from a school, factory, or other institution, public or private, and not for the benefit of the property in a district except incidentally, the city shall pay not less than one-half of cost of such sidewalk. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 6.1, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-117. - Initiatory resolution. 
    When in the opinion of the council any sidewalk or driveway approach needs to be constructed, rebuilt or repaired, they shall by resolution direct the manager to prepare a report with the assistance of the engineer containing any information they may request concerning such work. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 6.2, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-118. - Plans and specifications. 
    The manager shall request the engineer to prepare or cause to be prepared plans and specifications of the work to be done, a schedule of the lands affected and such other information as the council may have requested. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 6.3, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-119. - Report of manager. 
    The manager shall prepare his report and include in it a schedule of all property affected by the work proposed to be done and pertinent information on such parcels as are owned by public authorities, and such other information as the council may have requested, and shall present it to the council along with the plans and specifications of the engineer together with his recommendation as to what part, if any, should be general obligation of the city, the number of installments in which the assessment should be spread and the lands which should be included in the special assessment district. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 6.4, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-120. - Alternate procedure. 
    When, in the opinion of the manager, any sidewalk or driveway approach needs to be constructed, rebuilt or repaired, he may request the engineer to prepare or cause to be prepared plans and specifications of the work needed to be done and a schedule of the lands affected. The manager shall submit the information along with his report and recommendations to the council in the same manner as though the council had requested it. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 6.5, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-121. - Resolution of determination. 
    After reviewing the plans and specifications and the report of the manager, the council shall if it so desires determine by resolution that the work be done, setting forth the details concerning it, prescribe a form of notice and direct the clerk to give such notice by first class mail to the owner of each lot or parcel of land affected thereby at his address or the address shown on the last tax roll of the city and by publication at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city to be designated by the council. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 6.6, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-122. - Contents of notice. 
    The notice shall specify the extent of the work to be done, describe the property affected by the work and require the owner to perform the work promptly in accordance with the plans and specifications of the engineer and designate a time within which the work shall be done. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 6.7, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-123. - Work done by city. 
    If at the expiration of the time limit specified in the notice within which the work must be done the owner has not complied with the requirements thereof, the council shall by resolution order such sidewalk or driveway approach to be constructed, rebuilt or repaired under the direction of the manager by the proper department or agency of the city, or may do the work by contract or by hire. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 6.8, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-124. - Manager's duties. 
    The manager shall take all steps necessary to carry out the direction of the council in performing the work ordered, shall keep or cause to be kept an accurate record of all expense in connection therewith, and upon completion of the work to be performed shall submit a report of the work done and of all expense in connection therewith to the council. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 6.9, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-125. - Assessment of costs. 
    The council shall, by resolution, after examination of the manager's report, determine what amount or part of each such expense shall be charged and the person against whom and the premises upon which the same shall be levied as a special assessment. By such resolution, the council shall determine the number of installments in which the assessment may be paid, determine the rate of interest to be charged on installments, not to exceed six percent per annum, designate the district of land and premises upon which special assessments shall be levied, direct the assessor to prepare a special assessment roll in accordance with the council's determination and designate the name by which the assessment roll shall be known and referred to. Notwithstanding the provisions of the previous sentence, in instances where the city will be issuing obligations in anticipation of special assessments, the interest rate to be charged shall be governed by the provisions of the Municipal Finance Act, specifically 1973 PA 70, being MCL 133.9. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 6.10, 2-13-67; Ord. No. 78-1, art. 2, 9-5-00) 
Sec. 74-126. - Special assessment roll. 
    The assessor shall thereupon prepare a special assessment roll including all lots and parcels of land within the special assessment district designated by the council and shall assess to each such lot or parcel of land such sums as may have been directed by the council. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 6.11, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-127. - Certificate of assessor. 
    When the assessor shall have completed such a roll, he shall attach thereto and endorse thereon his certificate to the effect that the roll has been made by him pursuant to a resolution of the council (giving the date of adoption of the roll) and that in making the assessments therein he has, as near as may be according to his best judgment, conformed in all respects to the directions contained in such resolution, the city Charter and the provisions of this article. Thereupon, he shall file the special assessment roll with the clerk who shall present the roll to the council. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 6.12, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-128. - Notice of hearing on roll; contents. 
(a)  Upon receipt of such special assessment roll, the council shall order it filed in the office of the clerk for public examination and shall by resolution fix the time and place when the council will meet and review such roll, which meeting shall be held not less than one week after notice thereof, specifying the purpose, time and place of such meeting, has been given by first class mail to the owner of each lot or parcel of land affected thereby at his address or the address shown on the last tax roll of the city, and by publication at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city to be designated by the council or by posting notice thereof for the same length of time in three public places within the city. 
(b)  The notice shall include a statement that appearance and protest at the hearing in the special assessment proceedings is required in order to appeal the amount of the special assessment to the state tax tribunal, and that an owner or party in interest, or his agent, may appear in person at the hearing to protest the special assessment or may file his appearance or protest by letter and his personal appearance shall not be required. The notice shall further include a statement that the owner or any party having an interest in the real property may file a written appeal of the special assessment with the state tax tribunal within 30 days after the confirmation of the special assessment role if that special assessment was protested at the hearing held for the purpose of confirming the role. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 6.13, 2-13-67) 
State Law reference- Special assessment notices and hearings, MCL 211.741 et seq. 
Sec. 74-129. - Hearing on objections. 
    The council shall meet and review the special assessment roll at the time and place appointed or at an adjourned date therefor and shall consider any written objections thereto. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 6.14, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-130. - Corrections and changes. 
    The council may correct the roll as to any assessment or description of any lot or parcel of land or other errors appearing therein. Any changes made in such roll shall be noted in the council minutes. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 6.15, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-131. - Confirmation of roll. 
    After such hearing, the council shall confirm such special assessment roll with such corrections as may have been made and the clerk shall endorse the date of confirmation thereon and upon confirmation such roll shall be final and conclusive. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 6.16, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-132. - Alternate proceedings under improvement procedure. 
    The council may disregard the proceedings under this article and proceed entirely under the improvement procedure provided in this chapter, either as an individual improvement program or in conjunction with any other improvement program. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 6.17, 2-13-67) 
Secs. 74-133-74-155. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SINGLE LOTS 

Sec. 74-156. - Report of manager. 
    When any expense shall have been incurred by the city upon or in respect to any single lot or parcel of land and the owner thereof, by any city Charter provision or ordinance of the city or the laws of the state, and is not of that class required to be prorated among several lots or parcels of land in a special assessment district, the amount of labor and material or any other expense or service for which such expense was incurred with a description of the lot or parcel of land upon or in respect to which the expense was incurred and the name of the owner, if known, shall be reported by the manager to the council. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 7.1, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-157. - Resolution of determination. 
    After reviewing the report of the manager, the council may determine by resolution what amount or part of each such expense shall be charged and the person, if known, against whom and the premises upon which the expense shall be levied as a special assessment. By such resolution the council shall determine the number of installments in which the assessment may be paid, determine the rate of interest to be charged on installments, not to exceed six percent per annum, designate the land and premises upon which the special assessment roll shall be levied, direct the assessor to prepare a special assessment roll in accordance with the council's determination, and designate the name by which the assessment roll shall be known and referred to, and as often as the council shall deem expedient require notice of the several amounts so reported and determined to be given by the clerk by first class mail sent to the last known address of the owner as shown on the assessment roll of the city and by publication. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 7.2, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-158. - Special assessment roll. 
    The assessor shall thereupon prepare a special assessment roll with the description of the lot or parcel of land within the special assessment district designated by the council, and shall assess the lot or parcel of land such sums as may have been directed by the council. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 7.3, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-159. - Certificate of assessor. 
    When the assessor shall have completed such assessment roll, he shall attach thereto and endorse thereon his certificate to the effect that the roll has been made by him pursuant to a resolution of the council, giving the date of adoption of the roll, and that in making the assessments therein he has, as near as may be according to his best judgment, conformed in all respects to the directions contained in such resolution and the city Charter and the provisions of this article. Thereupon, he shall file the special assessment roll with the clerk who shall present the roll to the council. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 7.4, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-160. - Notice of hearing on roll; contents. 
(a)  Upon receipt of such special assessment roll, the council shall order it filed in the office of the clerk for public examination and shall by resolution fix the time and place when the council will meet and review such roll, which meeting shall be held not less than one week after the notice thereof specifying the purpose, time and place has been given by first class mail to the owner of the lot or parcel of land affected thereby at his address or the address shown on the last tax roll of the city, by publication at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city to be designated by the council or by posting notice thereof for the same length of time in three public places within the city. 
(b)  The notice shall include a statement that appearance and protest at the hearing in the special assessment proceedings is required in order to appeal the amount of the special assessment to the state tax tribunal, and that an owner or party in interest, or his agent, may appear in person at the hearing to protest the special assessment or may file his appearance or protest by letter and his personal appearance shall not be required. The notice shall further include a statement that the owner or any party having an interest in the real property may file a written appeal of the special assessment with the state tax tribunal within 30 days after the confirmation of the special assessment role if that special assessment was protested at the hearing held for the purpose of confirming the role. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 7.5, 2-13-67) 
State Law reference- Special assessment notices and hearings, MCL 211.741 et seq. 
Sec. 74-161. - Hearing on objections. 
    The council shall meet and review the special assessment roll at the time and place appointed or at an adjourned date therefor and shall consider any written objections thereto. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 7.6, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-162. - Corrections and changes. 
    The council may correct the roll as to any assessment or description of the lot or parcel of land or other errors appearing therein. Any changes made in such roll shall be noted in the council minutes. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 7.7, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-163. - Confirmation of roll. 
    After such hearing, the council shall confirm such special assessment roll with such corrections as may have been made and the clerk shall endorse the date of confirmation thereon, and upon confirmation such roll shall be final and conclusive. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 7.8, 2-13-67) 
Secs. 74-164-74-185. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - LIEN 

Sec. 74-186. - Established. 
    Special assessments and all interest and charges thereon from the date of confirmation of the roll shall be and remain a lien upon the property assessed of the same character and effect as the lien created by general law for state and county taxes or by the city Charter for city taxes, until paid. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 8.1, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-187. - Character. 
    All liens referred to in section 74-186 shall be of the same character and effect as the lien created by the city Charter for taxes and shall include accrued interest and penalties. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 8.2, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-188. - Destruction or impairment. 
    No judgment or decree, nor any action of the council vacating a special assessment shall destroy or impair the lien of the city upon the premises assessed for such amount of the assessment as may be equitably charged against the premises, or as by a regular mode of proceeding, might have been lawfully assessed thereon. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 8.3, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-189. - Failure to receive notice. 
    Failure of any owner to receive any notice required to be sent under the provisions of the city Charter and this article shall not invalidate any special assessment or special assessment roll. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 8.4, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-190. - Personal liability of owner. 
    In addition to the property tax lien created pursuant to this article, any special assessment levied by the city shall constitute a debt owed to the city from the owner of the lot or parcel of land assessed and may be collected in the same manner as any contracted debt, or in the same manner as provided by law for the collection of personal property taxes. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 8.5, 2-13-67) 
Secs. 74-191-74-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - INSTALLMENT PAYMENTS; NOTICE OF CONTENT 

Sec. 74-211. - Installments. 
    Annual installments shall not exceed 30 in number, as the council may determine at the time of confirmation of the roll, and if a division of the assessment operates to make any installment less than $10.00, the assessor shall reduce the number of installments so that each installment shall be above and as near to $10.00 as possible. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 9.1, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-212. - Due date. 
    All special assessments levied pursuant to this article shall become due upon confirmation of the special assessment roll, and, if in annual installments, the council shall determine the first installment to be due upon confirmation of the roll, and deferred installments to be due annually thereafter or in the discretion of the council they may be spread upon and made a part of each annual city tax roll thereafter until all are paid. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 9.2, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-213. - First installment spread. 
    The first installment of any special assessment shall be spread upon a special city tax roll in a column headed special assessment or upon the next annual tax roll and may be paid any time within three months from the date of confirmation without penalties, and if unpaid on or before the three months' period, it shall be added to and made a part of the following July 1 tax roll, together with interest as provided thereon. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 9.3, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-214. - Annual installment spread. 
    Annual installments shall be spread thereafter either on a special assessment roll or on the annual city tax roll, as may have been directed by the council, in the same manner and subject to the same provisions as provided for first installments. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 9.4, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-215. - Publication of notice to pay. 
    The assessment roll shall be transmitted by the clerk to the treasurer for collection immediately after confirmation and, if it is not a part of the annual tax roll, the treasurer shall give notice by publication at least once in a newspaper of general circulation that the special assessment roll (describing it) has been filed in the treasurer's office and specify when and where payments may be made thereon. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 9.5, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-216. - Notice by mail. 
    The treasurer may mail statements of the several assessments to the respective owners as indicated by the records of the assessor of the several lots or parcels of land assessed, stating the amount of the assessment and the manner in which it may be paid; provided, however, that failure to mail any such statement shall not invalidate the assessment or entitle the owner to an extension of time within which to pay the assessment. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 9.6, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-217. - Collection fees and penalties. 
    After the confirmation of any special assessment roll, the same collection fees shall be collected on delinquent special assessments and upon delinquent installments of such special assessments beginning on the first day of the fourth month following the due date, as are provided by the city Charter for the collection of delinquent city taxes. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 9.7, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-218. - Contested assessments. 
    Except and unless notice is given to the council in writing of an intention to contest or enjoin the collection of any special assessment for the construction of any pavement, sewer, or other public improvement, the construction of any sidewalk, or the removal or abatement of any public hazard or nuisance, within 30 days after the confirmation of the special assessment roll, which notice shall state the grounds in which the proceedings are to be contested, no suit or action of any kind shall be instituted or maintained for the purpose of contesting or enjoining the collection of such special assessments, and regardless of whether or not any public improvement is completed in any special assessment district, no owner of real property located in such district shall be entitled to commence any suit or action for the purpose of contesting or enjoining the collection of any such special assessments after he has received the benefits from the substantial completion of that portion of such public improvement for which he is assessed. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 9.8, 2-13-67) 
Secs. 74-219-74-240. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - REBATES; REASSESSMENTS; ADDITIONAL ASSESSMENTS 

Sec. 74-241. - Certification. 
    The manager shall within 60 days after the completion of each local or special public improvement compile the actual cost thereof and certify the cost to the assessor who shall adjust the special assessment roll to correspond therewith. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 10.1, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-242. - Additional assessments. 
    When any special assessment roll shall prove insufficient to pay the cost of the improvement for which it was made, the council may make an additional pro rata assessment, but the total amount assessed against any one parcel of land shall not exceed the value benefits received by the lot or parcel of land. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 10.2, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-243. - Assessment refunds. 
    Should the assessment prove larger than necessary by five percent or less, the excess shall be reported to the council which may place the excess in the city treasury or make a refund thereof pro rata according to assessment. If the assessment exceeds the amount necessary by more than five percent, the entire excess shall be credited to owners of property as shown by the city assessment roll upon which the assessment has been levied pro rata according to assessment. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 10.3, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-244. - Refund procedure on installments. 
    Any excess refund where payment in full has not been received shall be made by credit against future unpaid installments in the inverse order in which they are payable to the extent such installments exist, and the balance of such refund shall be made in cash. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 10.4, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-245. - Restriction against refund. 
    No refunds of special assessments may be made which impair or contravene the provisions of any outstanding obligation or bond secured in whole or in part by such special assessment. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 10.5, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-246. - Illegal or invalid assessments. 
    Whenever the council shall deem that any special assessment is invalid or defective for any reason whatsoever or if any court of competent jurisdiction shall have adjudged such assessment to be illegal for any reason whatsoever in whole or in part, the council shall have power to cause a new assessment to be made for the same purpose for which the former assessment was made, whether the improvement or any part thereof has been completed or not and whether any part of the assessment has been collected or not. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 10.6, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-247. - Proceedings on reassessment. 
    All proceedings on reassessments and for the collection thereof shall be made in the same manner as provided in an original assessment and if any portion of the original assessment shall have been collected and not refunded, it shall be applied upon the reassessment and the reassessment shall to that extent be deemed satisfied. If more than the amount reassessed shall have been collected, the balance shall be refunded to the persons making such payments. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 10.7, 2-13-67) 
Secs. 74-248-74-270. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - RESTRICTIONS OR ASSESSMENTS 

Sec. 74-271. - Assessment limited to value of benefits. 
    The total amount assessed against any lot or parcel of land shall not exceed the value of the benefits received from the improvement. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 11.1, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-272. - Special fund. 
    Except as otherwise provided in the city Charter and this article, monies raised by special assessments to pay the cost of any local improvement shall be held in a special fund to pay such cost or to repay any monies borrowed therefor. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 11.2, 2-13-67) 
Sec. 74-273. - Restricted use of funds. 
    Each special assessment account must be used only for the improvement project for which the assessment was levied, except as otherwise provided in chapter 12 of the city Charter. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 11.3, 2-13-67) 
Secs. 74-274-74-295. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - ALTERNATIVE PAYMENT 

Sec. 74-296. - Petition for relief; city as mortgagee. 
    Any person who by reason of poverty is unable to contribute toward the cost of the making of a public improvement by special assessment may petition the council for relief, and upon approval by the council may execute a real estate mortgage naming the city as mortgagee on all or any part of the real property owned by him and benefited by the public improvement, upon such terms as the city council may determine and provide. The mortgage shall be recorded with the county register of deeds for the county and shall not be discharged until the terms thereof have been met in full. 
(Ord. No. 78, § 12.1, 2-13-67) 
Chapter 78 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Alcoholic liquors, ch. 6; consumption of alcoholic liquors in public, § 6-5; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; cable communications, ch. 26; planning, ch. 62; special assessments, ch. 74; subdivisions, ch. 82; traffic and vehicles, ch. 90; utilities, ch. 94; zoning, app. A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 78-1-78-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SIDEWALKS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 14-3, § XV, adopted February 4, 2002, specifically repealed Ord. No. 14-2, the provisions of which had been codified herein as ch. 78, art. II, §§ 78-26-78-38. Sections I-XIV of Ord. No. 14-3 have replaced the former provisions with a new art. II, §§ 78-26-78-39 as set out herein. Former art. II pertained to similar subject matter. 
Cross reference- Sidewalks and driveway approaches, § 74-116 et seq. 

Sec. 78-26. - Definitions. 
    Approaches, for the purpose of this article, includes sidewalks built between the street and the sidewalk line nearest the street. 
    Collection, for the purpose of this article, is the recovery by direct billing and/or special assessments of city expenditures. 
    Driveway, for the purposes of this article, is the designated space used for access by a vehicle to any lot or parcel of ground from a street. 
    Driveway apron, for the purpose of this article, is that portion of a driveway located between the gutter line of the street and the sidewalk line nearest such gutter line. 
    Hard surfaced, for the purpose of this article, shall mean constructed of either concrete pavement, bituminous asphalt pavement or brick paver in accordance with the specifications section of this article. 
    Maintenance, for the purpose of this article, shall mean the keeping of sidewalks free from obstructions, snow, ice, filth, and other nuisances that may create an unsafe condition to the general public. 
    Sidewalk, for the purpose of this article, is the walkway located in the public street rights-of-way, or easement located adjacent to a public street rights-of-way, intended for use by the general public. 
(Ord. No. 14-3, § I, 2-4-02) 
Sec. 78-27. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The director of public service shall have the supervision and care of the sidewalks, approaches and driveway aprons within or adjacent to the public street rights-of-way of said city and of the construction, reconstruction and repair of the same and it shall be his duty to see that the provisions of this article are complied with and report all violations thereof to the city manager who shall report them to the city council. He shall further make such additional inspection of sidewalks as the city manager may direct. 
(b)  The director of public service shall have the supervision of the construction, reconstruction and repair of driveways on properties adjacent to or abutting public street rights-of-way and it shall be his duty to see that the provisions of this article are complied with and report all violations thereto to the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 14-3, § II, 2-4-02) 
Sec. 78-28. - Duty. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every owner, agent or occupant of any lot or parcel of ground situated within the city to keep and maintain in good condition, all existing sidewalks and driveway aprons along all public streets and avenues in front of or adjacent thereto. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of every owner, agent or occupant of any lot or parcel of ground adjacent to or abutting any sidewalk to keep the sidewalk free from snow, ice, filth and all obstructions, encroachments, encumbrances or other nuisances. Snow, ice, filth and all obstructions, encroachments, encumbrances or other nuisances shall be removed from the public sidewalks adjoining the property within 24 hours of the accumulation or placement of snow, ice, filth and all obstructions, encroachments, encumbrances or other nuisances on the sidewalks. 
(1)  Owners, agents and occupants of any lot or parcel of land, or individuals hired by them, are prohibited from shoveling, pushing or blowing snow from sidewalks and/or driveways into a public street. The snow may be placed in the public median (between sidewalk and street) in a manner which does not block a sidewalk, obstruct vision or create a hazard for vehicles. 
(2)  Owners, agents and occupants, or individuals hired by them, of any lot or parcel of land zoned office, business or industrial, and any lot or parcel of land zoned multiple dwelling which has on site parking lots, parking areas, drive thru or service areas, etc., are prohibited form placing snow from these areas into or on a public street right-of-way. 
(3)  Any person determined by the Building Official to be in violation of this section shall be given notice of the violation and ordered to abate the violation, as follows: 
a.  Service of notice and order. The notice and order may be served by any one of the following means: 
(1)  In writing, by first-class mail, addressed to the owner of the property at the last known address as shown by city tax records. The notice and order shall at the same time also be mailed to the occupants of the property, if different than the owner. If the notice and order are served by mail, they shall be deemed received by the addressee two mail delivery days after deposit in the United States mail. 
(2)  In writing, posted at the property. The notice and order shall be deemed to have been served to the owner and/or occupant, as applicable, at the time the notice and order is posted at the property.
