(3)  By providing the notice and order orally, either in person or by telephone. The oral notice and order shall be deemed to have served to the owner and/or occupant, as applicable, at the time the oral notice and order are given. A written confirmation of the oral notice and order shall be mailed by the city to the person served within five days of the oral notice and order, provided that the failure to do so shall not affect the person's obligation to comply with the oral notice and order and shall not constitute a defense to a violation of this section. 
b.  Contents of notice and order. To the extent known by the city, and as applicable under the circumstances, a notice and order under this section shall include: 
(1)  The date and time the notice was served. 
(2)  The name and address of the person (or persons) responsible for the violation. 
(3)  A description of the nature and location of the violation and the provisions of this section violated. 
(4)  The minimum corrective actions required to abate the violation. 
(5)  An order to abate the violation by the time specified in the order (which shall be 48 hours from the time notice and order are deemed to have been received as provided by this section). 
(6)  The applicable fines or other consequences for failure to abate the violation by time specified in the notice and order. 
(7)  A statement indicating that if the violation is not abated as ordered, then the city may unilaterally act to abate the violation; that the costs to the city of any action by the city to abate the violation, plus an administrative fee and any applicable fines, shall be a personal debt of the person to the city, which may be assessed by the city as a lien against the property until paid; and that the refusal to allow the city to abate an uncorrected violation shall constitute a separate and additional violation of this section. 
c.  Abatement required. Any person served with a notice and order as provided by this section shall abate the violation as specified by the order. 
(4)  Noncompliance with order; abatement by city. 
a.  Abatement by city. If a person served with a notice and order fails or refuses to abate the violation as required by the order under this section within 48 hours of being notified of the violation, the city or its authorized representatives may enter the property and take any reasonable actions necessary to remove the ice and snow from the sidewalks and abate the violation. 
b.  Costs of abatement; delinquent payments; lien. The costs, including an administrative fee of $25.00, as incurred by the city in abating the violation shall be immediately due and payable to the city by the owner of the property where the violation occurred. The city shall notify the property owner that the costs are due and owing by certified mail (return receipt requested), addressed to the property owner's last known address as shown by city tax records. If the costs are not paid in full within 30 days of mailing the notification, they shall be delinquent. The amount of the costs, plus any administrative fee, shall be certified by the treasurer to the assessor for inclusion upon the next city tax roll, and the assessor shall include the same in the city tax roll. The amount included in the city tax roll shall be a lien against the property that may be enforced and discharged by the city in the same manner as a tax lien. The costs of abatement, if any, recovered by the city shall be in addition to any civil fines, damages, expenses or costs payable to the city as a result of a violation. 
c.  Abatement by city not defense to violation. The abatement by the city of a violation of this section, and subsequent recovery of abatement costs incurred by the city, shall not be a defense to any action by the city against any person for the violation, including, without limitations, any action by the city to collect civil fines, damages, expenses or costs as authorized by law. 
(1)  Municipal civil infraction. A person who violates any provision of this section, including, without limitation, the failure or refusal to abate a violation following service of a notice and order, is responsible for a municipal civil infraction, subject to payment of a civil fine which shall be not less than $25.00 for the first offense, not less than $100.00 for any offense which is a first repeat offense, and not less than $250.00 for any offense for which is a second repeat offense or any subsequent repeat offense, plus, in all cases, the costs and other sanctions allowed by law or ordinance. Each day on which a violation of any provision of this section occurs shall constitute a separate violation and subject the violator to the payment of the civil fine as provided herein for each day that a violation occurs. The [police department/zoning enforcement officer/building official] is hereby designated as the authorized city official to issue municipal civil infraction citations directing alleged violators to appear in court for violations under this section, as provided in the code of ordinances of the City of Richmond. 
(2)  Nuisance per se; injunctive relief. A violation of this section is deemed to be a nuisance per se. In addition to any other remedy available at law, the city may bring an action for an injunction or other process against a person, to restrain, prevent or abate any violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 14-4, § 1, 2-21-11) 
Sec. 78-29. - Who may repair or construct. 
(a)  Sidewalks, approaches, driveways and driveway aprons may be constructed or repaired by the following: 
(1)  The department of public works; 
(2)  A state-licensed builder/contractor; or 
(3)  The owner of a lot or parcel of land in front of or adjacent to which a sidewalk, approach, driveway or driveway apron is to be constructed, reconstructed or repaired. 
(Ord. No. 14-3, § IV, 2-4-02) 
Sec. 78-30. - Specifications. 
(a)  All sidewalks, approaches, driveways and driveway aprons hereafter constructed or reconstructed within the city, pursuant to the requirements of this article, shall be upon such grade and line as shall be established by the director of public service. It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or reconstruct or cause to be constructed or reconstructed any sidewalk, approach, driveway or driveway apron on any line or grade except as given by the director of public service. 
(b)  All sidewalk, approach, driveway and driveway apron forms for the placement of concrete shall be inspected before the placement of the concrete. All asphalt driveways and driveway aprons shall be inspected after all subgrading preparations are completed and before the laying of the asphalt. 
(c)  All concrete used for the construction, reconstruction or repair of sidewalks, approaches, driveways and driveway aprons shall be class A (6 sack) concrete with a compressive strength at 28 days of 3,500 psi minimum. Cement shall be air-entraining cement. 
(d)  All sidewalks and approaches shall be built according to the following specifications: 
(1)  No less than four inches thick except at driveway crossings where the minimum thickness shall be six inches thick. 
(2)  All sidewalks and approaches shall be placed on a one-inch cushion of compacted sand. 
(3)  All sod shall be removed from the area directly beneath the location of the sidewalk and approach. 
(4)  All sidewalks shall extend from property line to property line. 
(5)  All sidewalks shall be located one foot from the rights-of-way line on the street side, unless some other location is determined by the city to be more appropriate for the existing conditions. 
(6)  Sidewalks and approaches shall not be less than four feet in width, (five feet in newly platted subdivisions) provided however, that whenever an existing sidewalk or approach of more than four feet in width is reconstructed, repaired, or replaced such reconstruction, repair or replacement shall be of the same width as the existing sidewalk or approach. 
(7)  Walks shall be divided into blocks approximately square, finished with a light broomed finish and edged and covered with an approved curing compound. 
(8)  One half-inch expansion joint material shall be placed at 50-foot intervals and between adjacent structures and the new work. 
(e)  All driveways and driveway aprons shall be built according to the following specifications: 
(1)  Driveways may be constructed of brick paver material, concrete or bituminous asphalt pavement not less than ten feet in width. 
a.  Brick paver driveways shall be constructed on a compacted subbase of washed gravel or washed crushed limestone. 
b.  Bituminous asphalt pavement driveways shall be constructed of not less than two and three-fourths inches of bituminous asphalt pavement on a six-inch thick compacted gravel, limestone or crushed concrete base. 
c.  Concrete driveways shall be constructed of not less than four inches of class A (6 sack) concrete on a thoroughly compacted subgrade of sand, gravel or limestone. 
(2)  Driveway aprons shall be constructed of either concrete or bituminous asphalt pavement. Brick paver material is specifically prohibited. 
(3)  Driveway aprons shall be suitable for the width of the driveway, with the street end of the driveway apron at least three feet wider than the sidewalk end. No ribbon driveway aprons shall be permitted. 
(4)  Concrete driveway aprons shall be constructed of at least six inches of class A (6 sack) concrete on a thoroughly compacted subgrade of sand, gravel or limestone. Bituminous asphalt driveway aprons shall consist of a sub-base of at least six inches of compacted gravel or crushed limestone, and the bituminous asphalt applied thereon shall be at least three inches thick. 
(5)  Driveway aprons, when constructed of concrete, shall contain expansion joint material one-half-inch thick which shall be placed at each end of the apron next to the sidewalk and next to the curb, if a curb exists at the location. 
(6)  The elevation of the driveway and the driveway apron where they abut the sidewalk shall be the same elevation as the area of sidewalk they abut. 
(Ord. No. 14-3, § V, 2-4-02) 
Sec. 78-31. - Permit requirements. 
    No sidewalk, approach, driveway or driveway apron shall be built, reconstructed or repaired without a permit therefore being first obtained from the city. The cost of the permit, if any, shall be set by council resolution. All sidewalks, approaches, driveways and driveway aprons shall be built in accordance with the specifications of this article. The director of public service shall, upon application therefore, issue such permits. 
(Ord. No. 14-3, § VI, 2-4-02) 
Sec. 78-32. - Reporting of defects. 
    Whenever any sidewalk or any portion of any sidewalk because of defects, want of repair or for any other reason becomes dangerous or unsafe to persons passing along and upon the same, it shall be the duty of the director of public service to inform the city manager of such condition as soon as practicable after the director becomes aware of the unsafe condition. 
(Ord. No. 14-3, § VII, 2-4-02) 
Sec. 78-33. - Power of council. 
    The city council may at any time by resolution order a sidewalk or driveway apron constructed, reconstructed, or repaired when it becomes in the opinion of the council a public nuisance or hazard which is dangerous to the health, safety, or welfare of the residents or inhabitants of the city. 
(Ord. No. 14-3, § VIII, 2-4-02) 
Sec. 78-34. - Notice. 
    The city council shall, by an authorized agent of the city, give to the owner, agent, or occupant of any parcel or lot of land in front of or adjacent to which a sidewalk or driveway apron is ordered constructed, reconstructed or repaired a notice to construct, reconstruct or repair the same as the case may be, within a time to be determined by the city council but in no event less than 30 days from service of the notice to said owner, agent or occupant of such lot or parcel of land. Such notice may be by personal service, or by registered or certified mail addressed to the address set forth in the current records of the assessor, specifying the nature of the nuisance or hazard and requiring the owner or occupant to construct, reconstruct or repair the sidewalk or driveway apron within a time to be specified by the council. The notice shall be substantially in the following form: 
NOTICE TO CONSTRUCT, RECONSTRUCT OR REPAIR 
SIDEWALK AND/OR DRIVEWAY APRON 
TO: ___________, owner of Lot/Parcel # ________ 
City of Richmond, Michigan. 
By resolution of the City Council passed ________, 20___ You are hereby notified to _____ , the _____(Construct, reconstruct, repair) (Sidewalk, Driveway Apron) adjoining said premises located at ___________ within ___ Days from the date of issuance of this notice, in accordance with specifications prescribed by this article. _____
Date of Issuance _____
City Clerk  
(Ord. No. 14-3, § IX, 2-4-02) 
Sec. 78-35. - Completion and certification. 
    If the owner, agent or occupant shall neglect to construct, reconstruct or repair such sidewalk and/or driveway apron within the time specified in the notice herein before required to be given, weather permitting, the director of public service may construct, reconstruct or repair the same, or cause it to be done. Immediately after the construction, reconstruction or repair of the sidewalk and/or driveway apron the director of public service shall make a certification setting forth the name(s) of the owner, agent or occupant with the description of the premises, the amount of sidewalk and/or driveway apron constructed, reconstructed or repaired and its cost and expense of the same plus an overhead charge as authorized in the city fee schedule resolution or $200.00, whichever is less, and shall file it with the city treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 14-3, § X, 2-4-02) 
Sec. 78-36. - Cost of construction, reconstruction or repair. 
    It shall be the duty of the city treasurer to collect from each lot or parcel owner, whose sidewalk and/or driveway apron was constructed, reconstructed or repaired, the cost of the construction, reconstruction or repair as such cost was certified to the treasurer by the director of public service. The cost of such work may be placed on the tax roll as a lien against the lot or parcel. 
(Ord. No. 14-3, § XI, 2-4-02) 
Sec. 78-37. - Sidewalk improvements by special assessment. 
    The city council, having the authority to order the construction, reconstruction or repair of sidewalks and defraying the cost by special assessment to the property owners of the abutting lots or parcels of land, shall follow the provisions as set forth in "the City of Richmond Special Assessment Ordinance". Notwithstanding the provisions of this section or any other provision of any other ordinance, the city council, in its discretion may adopt and modify a policy establishing a fund out of general fund monies to assist owners or occupants of lots or parcels adjacent to sidewalks in the construction, reconstruction and repair of same. Said policy shall include the amount of assistance the city is willing to provide said owners or occupants and the procedures for determining who is entitled to such assistance and the method of disbursing monies from said fund. 
(Ord. No. 14-3, § XII, 2-4-02) 
Sec. 78-38. - Penalties for violations. 
    Any person, firm, or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, upon convicting thereof, may be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00 dollars for each violation and imprisonment for a period of up to 90 days or by both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court, together with the costs of such prosecution. 
    Each day upon which a violation of the provisions of this article shall occur shall be deemed a separate and additional violation for the purpose of this article. 
(Ord. No. 14-3, § XIII, 2-4-02) 
Sec. 78-39. - Severability. 
    This article and each of the various parts, sections, subsections, sentences, phrases and clauses hereof are hereby declared to be severable. If any part, section, subsection, sentences, phrases, or clause is determined to be invalid or unenforceable for any reason by a court of competent jurisdiction, it is hereby provided that the remainder of this article shall not be affected thereby and shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 14-3, § XIV, 2-4-02) 
Secs. 78-40-78-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DRIVEWAY CULVERTS 

Sec. 78-61. - Installation and maintenance of metal culvert required; specifications. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or maintain a driveway approach or other obstruction leading from any street to a lot or parcel of land abutting thereon which may in any way obstruct or interfere with the free and continuous flow or passage of water in, through or along any public gutter, watercourse or drain in such street without first placing in the bottom of such gutter, watercourse or drain a metal culvert pipe as provided in this section and maintaining the metal culvert pipe safe and unobstructed. The responsibility of keeping any such culvert pipe open and free of dirt or obstruction shall be upon the property owner. 
(b)  Any culvert pipe installed in any public street shall be approved by the department of public works and shall be of cast iron, steel, or iron or steel alloy not less than eight inches in internal diameter, or larger if required by the department of public works, shall have continuous length of not less than 14 feet nor more than 42 feet, shall be installed in a manner approved by the department of public works in a location, at a grade and at such elevation that it will not obstruct or interfere with the free and continuous flow or passage of water in the direction which is designated by the established grade of gutter, watercourse or drain and shall be covered with material of the same character as the traveled portion of the roadway adjacent or other approved material suitable for the use intended, provided that the department of public works may grant special permission to install a metal culvert pipe less than 14 feet in length if, in its judgment, conditions justify installation of such lesser length. 
(Ord. No. 108, § I, 3-26-81) 
Sec. 78-62. - Application for permit; option to have work performed by the city; payment. 
    Whenever any person shall desire to construct a driveway approach or obstruction in a gutter of the character mentioned in section 78-61, he shall make application to the department of public works for a permit for such installation, therein indicating the nature and full description of such proposed construction. The department of public works shall review all such applications for compliance with this article. If the department of public works shall approve the application, the department of public works will issue a permit for the installation in the manner provided in section 78-61 and shall make a record of such permit. Should the applicant desire to have the work done by the city, he will be required to make application for the work to be performed to the department of public works and pay to the city treasurer a sum equal to the cost of materials, labor, supervision and administration, as determined by the department of public works. Upon payment to the city treasurer of such sum, the city will, as soon thereafter as convenient and practical, install such pipe and cover the pipe with some material suitable for the use intended. The material used in the construction of all driveways or culverts built by the city shall remain the property of the city. If at any time the character of any street is changed so that a driveway or culvert is no longer required, then all material used in such driveway or culvert constructed by the city shall be salvaged by it, and all material shall be removed from the site by the city. 
(Ord. No. 108, § II, 3-26-81) 
Sec. 78-63. - Service of notice upon owner or agent of owner. 
    Whenever any street, land or alley in the city has been graveled or paved without curbs, it shall be the duty of the director of public service to serve or cause to be served a written notice upon the owner or agent of the owner of any lot or parcel of land abutting the street which has a driveway approach or other obstruction leading from the lot or parcel of land to the traveled portion of the street, requiring him or them to install pipes in all such driveways, approaches or obstructions in accordance with sections 78-61 and 78-62 within ten days after the completion of the work or graveling or paving any such street. It shall further be the duty of the director to serve or cause to be served the notice upon the owner or the agent of the owner of any lot or parcel of land abutting any street in the city which has been graveled or paved, who has not complied with the conditions specified in sections 78-61 and 78-62. In case the director or other authorized agent or employee shall be unable to find within the city the owner or agent of the owner of any such lot or parcel of land abutting such street, then such notice may be served by posting in some conspicuous place on the lot and premises. 
(Ord. No. 108, § III, 3-26-81) 
Sec. 78-64. - Installation by city and assessment of costs of installation for failure to comply with article. 
    In case the owner or agent of the owner of any lot or parcel of land, when ordered by the director of public service, shall refuse or neglect to install pipes within the time requirements provided for in section 78-63, the city council may cause such driveway approach or obstruction to be constructed and installed and assess the cost thereof in a special assessment on the lot or parcel of land benefited. The assessment shall be made and collected in the same manner as provided for in the city Charter and applicable ordinances for the making and collecting of special assessments, and such charge shall be and remain a lien upon such lot or parcel of land until the charge is paid, the same as all other assessments. 
(Ord. No. 108, § IV, 3-26-81) 
Secs. 78-65-78-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TELECOMMUNICATIONS RIGHTS-OF-WAY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 151, adopted October 21, 2002, enacted provisions intended for use as §§ 78-100-78-122. In order to conform with the style of the Code, these provisions have been included herein as §§ 78-101-78-121, at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 78-101. - Purpose. 
    The purposes of this article are to regulate access to and ongoing use of public rights-of-way by telecommunications providers for their telecommunications facilities while protecting the public health, safety, and welfare and exercising reasonable control of the public rights-of-way in compliance with the Metropolitan Extension Telecommunications Rights-of-Way Oversight Act (Act No. 48 of the Public Acts of 2002) ("Act") and other applicable law, and to ensure that the city qualifies for distributions under the Act by modifying the fees charged to providers and complying with the Act. 
(Ord. No. 151, 10-21-02) 
Sec. 78-102. - Conflict. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed in such a manner as to conflict with the Act or other applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 151, 10-21-02) 
Sec. 78-103. - Terms defined. 
    The terms used in this article shall have the following meanings: 
    Act means the Metropolitan Extension Telecommunications Rights-of-Way Oversight Act, Act No. 48 of the Public Acts of 2002, as amended from time to time. 
    City means the City of Richmond, Michigan. 
    City council means the City Council of the City of Richmond, Michigan, or its designee. This section does not authorize delegation of any decision or function that is required by law to be made by the city council. 
    City manager means the city manager or his or her designee. 
    Permit means a non-exclusive permit issued pursuant to the Act and this article to a telecommunications provider to use the public rights-of-way in the city for its telecommunications facilities. 
    All other terms used in this article shall have the same meaning as defined or as provided in the Act, including without limitation the following: 
    Authority means the Metropolitan Extension Telecommunications Rights-of-Way Oversight Authority created pursuant to Section 3 of the Act. 
    MPSC means the Michigan Public Service Commission in the Department of Consumer and Industry Services, and shall have the same meaning as the term "commission" in the Act. 
    Person means an individual, corporation, partnership, association, governmental entity, or any other legal entity. 
    Public right-of-way means the area on, below, or above a public roadway, highway, street, alley, easement or waterway. Public right-of-way does not include a federal, state, or private right-of-way. 
    Telecommunication facilities or facilities means the equipment or personal property, such as copper and fiber cables, lines, wires, switches, conduits, pipes, and sheaths, which are used to or can generate, receive, transmit, carry, amplify, or provide telecommunication services or signals. Telecommunication facilities or facilities do not include antennas, supporting structures for antennas, equipment shelters or houses, and any ancillary equipment and miscellaneous hardware used to provide federally licensed commercial mobile service as defined in section 332(d) of part I of title III of the Communications Act of 1934, chapter 652, 48 Stat. 1064, 47 U.S.C. 332 and further defined as commercial mobile radio service in 47 CFR 20.3, and service provided by any wireless, two-way communication device. 
    Telecommunications provider, provider, and telecommunications services mean those terms as defined in Section 102 of the Michigan Telecommunications Act, 1991 PA 179, MCL 484.2102. Telecommunications provider does not include a person or an affiliate of that person when providing a federally licensed commercial mobile radio service as defined in Section 332(d) of part I of the Communications Act of 1934, chapter 652, 48 Stat. 1064, 47 U.S.C. 332 and further defined as commercial mobile radio service in 47 CFR 20.3, or service provided by any wireless, two-way communication device. For the purpose of the Act and this article only, a provider also includes all of the following: 
(1)  A cable television operator that provides a telecommunications service; 
(2)  Except as otherwise provided by the Act, a person who owns telecommunication facilities located within a public right-of-way; 
(3)  A person providing broadband internet transport access service. 
(Ord. No. 151, 10-21-02) 
Sec. 78-104. - Permit required. 
(a)  Permit required. Except as otherwise provided in the Act, a telecommunications provider using or seeking to use public rights-of-way in the city for its telecommunications facilities shall apply for and obtain a permit pursuant to this article. 
(b)  Application. Telecommunications providers shall apply for a permit on an application form approved by the MPSC in accordance with Section 6(1) of the Act. A telecommunications provider shall file one copy of the application with the city clerk, one copy with the city manager, and one copy with the director of public service. Upon receipt, the city clerk shall make and distribute copies to the city planning and zoning administrator, building official, and code compliance officer. Applications shall be complete and include all information required by the Act, including without limitation a route map showing the location of the provider's existing and proposed facilities in accordance with Section 6(5) of the Act. 
(c)  Confidential information. If a telecommunications provider claims that any portion of the route maps submitted by it as part of its application contain trade secret, proprietary, or confidential information, which is exempt from the Freedom of Information Act, 1976 PA 442, MCL 15.231 to 15.246, pursuant to Section 6(5) of the Act, the telecommunications provider shall prominently so indicate on the face of each map. 
(d)  Application fee. Except as otherwise provided by the Act, the application shall be accompanied by a one-time non-refundable application fee in the amount of $500.00. 
(e)  Additional information. The city manager may request an applicant to submit such additional information which the city manager deems reasonably necessary or relevant. The applicant shall comply with all such requests in compliance with reasonable deadlines for such additional information established by the city manager. If the city and the applicant cannot agree on the requirement of additional information requested by the city, the city or the applicant shall notify the MPSC as provided in Section 6(2) of the Act. 
(f)  Previously issued permits. Pursuant to Section 5(1) of the Act, authorizations or permits previously issued by the city under Section 251 of the Michigan Telecommunications Act, 1991 PA 179, MCL 484.2251 and authorizations or permits issued by the city to telecommunications providers prior to the 1995 enactment of Section 251 of the Michigan Telecommunications Act but after 1985 shall satisfy the permit requirements of this article. 
(g)  Existing providers. Pursuant to Section 5(3) of the Act, within 180 days from November 1, 2002, the effective date of the Act, a telecommunications provider with facilities located in a public right-of-way in the city as of such date, that has not previously obtained authorization or a permit under Section 251 of the Michigan Telecommunications Act, 1991 PA 179, MCL 484.2251, shall submit to the city an application for a permit in accordance with the requirements of this article. Pursuant to Section 5(3) of the Act, a telecommunications provider submitting an application under this subsection is not required to pay the $500.00 application fee required under subsection (d) above. A provider under this subsection shall be given up to an additional 180 days to submit the permit application if allowed by the authority, as provided in Section 5(4) of the Act. 
(Ord. No. 151, 10-21-02) 
Sec. 78-105. - Issuance of permit. 
(a)  Approval or denial. The authority to approve or deny an application for a permit is hereby delegated to the city manager. Pursuant to Section 15(3) of the Act, the city manager shall approve or deny an application for a permit within 45 days from the date a telecommunications provider files an application for a permit under section 78-104(b) of this article for access to a public right-of-way within the city. Pursuant to Section 6(6) of the Act, the city manager shall notify the MPSC when the city manager has granted or denied a permit, including information regarding the date on which the application was filed and the date on which permit was granted or denied. The city manager shall not unreasonably deny an application for a permit. 
(b)  Form of permit. If an application for permit is approved, the city manager shall issue the permit in the form approved by the MPSC, with or without additional or different permit terms, in accordance with Sections 6(1), 6(2) and 15 of the Act. 
(c)  Conditions. Pursuant to Section 15(4) of the Act, the city manager may impose conditions on the issuance of a permit, which conditions shall be limited to the telecommunications provider's access and usage of the public right-of-way. 
(d)  Bond requirement. Pursuant to Section 15(3) of the Act, and without limitation on subsection (c) above, the city manager may require that a bond be posted by the telecommunications provider as a condition of the permit. If a bond is required, it shall not exceed the reasonable cost to ensure that the public right-of-way is returned to its original condition during and after the telecommunications provider's access and use. 
(Ord. No. 151, 10-21-02) 
Sec. 78-106. - Construction/engineering permit. 
    A telecommunications provider shall not commence construction upon, over, across, or under the public rights-of-way in the city without first obtaining a construction or engineering permit as required by city code or the adopted policies, rules, or regulations of the city, as amended from time to time, for construction within the public rights-of-way. No fee shall be charged for such a construction or engineering permit. 
(Ord. No. 151, 10-21-02) 
Sec. 78-107. - Conduit or utility poles. 
    Pursuant to Section 4(3) of the Act, obtaining a permit or paying the fees required under the Act or under this article does not give a telecommunications provider a right to use conduit or utility poles. 
(Ord. No. 151, 10-21-02) 
Sec. 78-108. - Route maps. 
    Pursuant to Section 6(7) of the Act, a telecommunications provider shall, within 90 days after the substantial completion of construction of new telecommunications facilities in the city, submit route maps showing the location of the telecommunications facilities to both the MPSC and to the city. The route maps shall be in both paper and electronic format compatible with the computer hardware and software capabilities of the city unless and until the MPSC determines otherwise, in accordance with Section 6(8) of the Act. 
(Ord. No. 151, 10-21-02) 
Sec. 78-109. - Repair of damage. 
    Pursuant to Section 15(5) of the Act, a telecommunications provider undertaking an excavation or construction or installing telecommunications facilities within a public right-of-way or temporarily obstructing a public right-of-way in the city, as authorized by a permit, shall promptly repair all damage done to the street surface and all installations under, over, below, or within the public right-of-way and shall promptly restore the public right-of-way to its preexisting condition. 
(Ord. No. 151, 10-21-02) 
Sec. 78-110. - Establishment and payment of maintenance fee. 
    In addition to the non-refundable application fee paid to the city set forth in subsection 78-104(d) above, a telecommunications provider with telecommunications facilities in the city's public rights-of-way shall pay an annual maintenance fee to the authority pursuant to Section 8 of the Act. 
(Ord. No. 151, 10-21-02) 
Sec. 78-111. - Modification of existing fees. 
    In compliance with the requirements of Section 13(1) of the Act, the city hereby modifies, to the extent necessary, any fees charged to telecommunications providers after November 1, 2002, the effective date of the Act, relating to access and usage of the public rights-of-way, to an amount not exceeding the amounts of fees and charges required under the Act, which shall be paid to the authority. In compliance with the requirements of Section 13(4) of the Act, the city also hereby approves modification of the fees of providers with telecommunication facilities in public rights-of-way within the city's boundaries, so that those providers pay only those fees required under Section 8 of the Act. The city shall provide each telecommunications provider affected by the fee with a copy of this article, in compliance with the requirement of Section 13(4) of the Act. To the extent any fees are charged telecommunications providers in excess of the amounts permitted under the Act, or which are otherwise inconsistent with the Act, such imposition is hereby declared to be contrary to the city's policy and intent, and upon application by a provider or discovery by the city, shall be promptly refunded as having been charged in error. 
(Ord. No. 151, 10-21-02) 
Sec. 78-112. - Savings clause. 
    Pursuant to Section 13(5) of the Act, if Section 8 of the Act is found to be invalid or unconstitutional, the modification of fees under section 78-111 above shall be void from the date the modification was made. 
(Ord. No. 151, 10-21-02) 
Sec. 78-113. - Use of funds. 
    Pursuant to Section 10(4) of the Act, all amounts received by the city from the authority shall be used by the city solely for rights-of-way related purposes. In conformance with that requirement, all funds received by the city from the authority shall be deposited into the major street fund and/or the local street fund maintained by the city under Act No. 51 of the Public Acts of 1951. 
(Ord. No. 151, 10-21-02) 
Sec. 78-114. - Annual report. 
    Pursuant to Section 10(5) of the Act, the city manager shall file an annual report with the authority on the use and disposition of funds annually distributed by the authority. 
(Ord. No. 151, 10-21-02) 
Sec. 78-115. - Cable television operators. 
    Pursuant to Section 13(6) of the Act, the city shall not hold a cable television operator in default or seek any remedy for its failure to satisfy an obligation, if any, to pay after November 1, 2002, the effective date of this Act, a franchise fee or similar fee on that portion of gross revenues from charges the cable operator received for cable modem services provided through broadband internet transport access services. 
(Ord. No. 151, 10-21-02) 
Sec. 78-116. - Existing rights. 
    Pursuant to Section 4(2) of the Act, except as expressly provided herein with respect to fees, this article shall not affect any existing rights that a telecommunications provider or the city may have under a permit issued by the city or under a contract between the city and a telecommunications provider related to the use of the public rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 151, 10-21-02) 
Sec. 78-117. - Compliance. 
    The city hereby declares that its policy and intent in adopting this article is to fully comply with the requirements of the Act, and the provisions hereof should be construed in such a manner as to achieve that purpose. The city shall comply in all respects with the requirements of the Act, including but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Exempting certain route maps from the Freedom of Information Act, 1976 PA 442, MCL 15.231 to 15.246, as provided in section 78-104(c) of this article; 
(2)  Allowing certain previously issued permits to satisfy the permit requirements hereof, in accordance with section 78-104(f) of this article; 
(3)  Allowing existing providers additional time in which to submit an application for a permit, and excusing such providers from the $500.00 application fee, in accordance with section 78-104(g) of this article; 
(4)  Approving or denying an application for a permit within 45 days from the date a telecommunications provider files an application for a permit for access to and usage of a public right-of-way within the city, in accordance with section 78-105(a) of this article; 
(5)  Notifying the MPSC when the city has granted or denied a permit, in accordance with section 78-105(a) of this article; 
(6)  Not unreasonably denying an application for a permit, in accordance with section 78-105(a) of this article; 
(7)  Issuing a permit in the form approved by the MPSC, with or without additional or different permit terms, as provided in section 78-105(b) of this article; 
(8)  Limiting the conditions imposed on the issuance of a permit to the telecommunications provider's access and usage of the public right-of-way, in accordance with section 78-105(c) of this article; 
(9)  Not requiring a bond of a telecommunications provider which exceeds the reasonable cost to ensure that the public right-of-way is returned to its original condition during and after the telecommunication provider's access and use, in accordance with section 78-105(d) of this article; 
(10)  Not charging any telecommunications providers any additional fees for construction or engineering permits, in accordance with section 78-106 of this article; 
(11)  Providing each telecommunications provider affected by the city's right-of-way fees with a copy of this article, in accordance with section 78-111 of this article; 
(12)  Submitting an annual report to the authority, in accordance with section 78-114 of this article; and 
(13)  Not holding a cable television operator in default for a failure to pay certain franchise fees, in accordance with section 78-115 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 151, 10-21-02) 
Sec. 78-118. - Reservation of police powers. 
    Pursuant to Section 15(2) of the Act, this article shall not limit the city's right to review and approve a telecommunication provider's access to and ongoing use of a public right-of-way or limit the city's authority to ensure and protect the health, safety, and welfare of the public. 
(Ord. No. 151, 10-21-02) 
Sec. 78-119. - Severability. 
    The various parts, sentences, paragraphs, sections, and clauses of this article are hereby declared to be severable. If any part, sentence, paragraph, section, or clause of this article is adjudged unconstitutional or invalid by a court or administrative agency of competent jurisdiction, the unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect the constitutionality or validity of any remaining provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 151, 10-21-02) 
Sec. 78-120. - Authorized city officials. 
    The city manager or his or her designee is hereby designated as the authorized city official to issue code violation citations directing alleged violators to appear in court or municipal civil infraction violation notices directing alleged violators to appear at the municipal chapter violations bureau for violations under this article as provided by this Code. 
(Ord. No. 151, 10-21-02) 
Sec. 78-121. - Violation as misdemeanor. 
    A person who violates any provision of this article or the terms or conditions of a permit is responsible for a misdemeanor, and shall be subject to the penalties determined by this Code for misdemeanor violations generally. Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the remedies available to the city in the event of a violation by a person of this article or a permit. 
(Ord. No. 151, 10-21-02) 
Chapter 82 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 93-2, Art. VIII, adopted August 5, 2002, specifically repealed the provisions of Ord. Nos. 93 and 93-1, which were codified herein as §§ 82-1-82-417. These provisions have been replaced by the provisions of Arts. I-VI of Ord. No. 93-2. Art. XV of this chapter, which does not derive from Ord. Nos. 93 and 93-2, is unaffected by this amendment. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; fire prevention and protection, ch. 50; planning, ch. 62; adoption of regulations governing the subdivision of land, § 62-85; amendment of zoning ordinance, § 62-87; special assessments, ch. 74; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78; utilities, ch. 94; zoning, app. A.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 82-1. - Purpose. 
    The purposes of this chapter are to provide for the orderly growth and harmonious development of the community; to secure adequate traffic circulation through coordinated street systems with relation to major thoroughfares, adjoining subdivisions, and public facilities; to achieve individual property lots of maximum utility and livability; to secure adequate provisions for water supply, drainage and sanitary sewerage, and other health requirements; to secure adequate provisions for recreational areas, school sites and other public facilities; and to provide logical procedures for the achievement of these purposes. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. I, 8-5-02) 
Sec. 82-2. - Interpretation. 
    The provisions of the regulations contained in this chapter shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted and necessary for the promotion and preservation of public health, safety and general welfare of the city. In the event that any of the provisions of these regulations impose a greater restriction than is imposed by existing statutes of the state, it is intended that the provisions of these regulations shall control and be deemed the minimum regulation or restriction, as the case may be. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. I, 8-5-02) 
Sec. 82-3. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the creation, use and approval of the splitting and subdivision of land within the city, including single-family detached condominium development, after the effective date of this chapter. No proposed development or lot split shall be approved by the city unless the lots within such development equal or exceed the minimum lot area and width requirements set forth in Appendix A, Zoning, Article XIII, of this Code, and unless such development or lot split fully conforms with this chapter and all other statutes of the State of Michigan. 
    These regulations shall apply to all subdivisions of land, resubdivisions, lot divisions and divisions of unplatted parcels located within the limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. I, 8-5-02) 
Sec. 82-4. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Block means that subdivided property abutting one side of a street and lying between the two nearest intersecting streets, or between the nearest such street and railroad right-of-way, unsubdivided acreage, river or live streams; or between any of the foregoing and any other barrier to the continuity of development. 
    Commission means the planning commission of the city. 
    Easement means a specific area of land over which a liberty, privilege, or advantage is granted by the owner to the public, a corporation, or some particular person or part of the public for specific uses and purposes, and which shall be designated a public or private easement, depending on the nature of the user. 
    Engineering standards mean the engineering standards and specifications adopted by the city council and contained in the city's published "Engineering Standards for Sewer, Water Main and Roadway Construction". 
    Filing date means the initial meeting date at which the plan for preliminary plat (stage 1), preliminary plat (stage 2), tentative or final, and final plat review appears on the agenda of a regular meeting of the council or the commission. 
    Improvements means grading, street surfacing, curbs and gutters, sidewalks, street trees, crosswalks, water mains, fire hydrants, sanitary sewers, storm sewers, culverts, bridges, and other additions to the natural state of land which increases its value, utility or habitability. 
    Lot means a parcel of land separated from other parcels on a preliminary or recorded plat for the purpose of sale, lease, or separate use. 
    Major streets or thoroughfare plan means the part of the master plan which sets forth the location, alignment and dimensions of existing and proposed streets and thoroughfares. 
    Master plan means the comprehensive land use plan for the municipality, including graphic and written proposals indicating the general locations recommended for the streets, parks, schools, public buildings, zoning districts, and all physical developments of the municipality including any unit or part of such plan separately adopted, and any amendment to such plan or parts thereof duly recommended by the planning commission and adopted by the council. 
    Municipal engineer or engineer means the staff engineer or consulting engineer of the municipality. 
    Municipal planner or planner means the staff planner or consulting planner of the municipality. 
    Parcel (or tract) means a continuous area or acreage of land which can be described as provided for in the subdivision act. 
    Plat means a map or chart of a subdivision of land. 
(1)  Preliminary plat (stage 1) means a map indicating the proposed layout of the subdivision in sufficient detail to provide adequate basis for review and to meet the requirements and procedures set forth in this chapter. 
(2)  Preliminary plat (stage 2) means a map showing all requisite details of a proposed subdivision submitted to an approving authority for purposes of preliminary consideration, prepared in conformance with the subdivision act. 
(3)  Final plat (stage 3) means a map on approved material of all or part of a subdivision providing substantial conformance to the approved preliminary plat (stage 2) of the subdivision prepared and certified as to its accuracy by a registered civil engineer or a registered land surveyor and prepared in conformance with the requirements of the subdivision act and this chapter and suitable for recording by the county register of deeds. 
    Proprietor means a natural person, firm, association, partnership, corporation or combination of any of them, which may hold any ownership of land, whether recorded or not. 
    Public reservation means a portion of a subdivision which is set aside for public use and made available for public use and acquisition. 
    Public utility means any person, firm or corporation, municipal department, board or commission duly authorized to furnish and furnishing under governmental regulations to the public gas, steam, electricity, sewage disposal, communication, telegraph, transportation or water. 
    Public walkway means a dedicated public right-of-way constructed of Portland cement for the purpose of pedestrian access through residential areas, and located so as to connect to two or more streets, or a street and a public land parcel. 
    Street means any street, avenue, boulevard, road, lane, parkway, viaduct or other way which is an existing state, county, or city roadway; or a street or way shown in a plat heretofore approved pursuant to law or approved by official action; or a street or way on a plat duly filed and recorded in the office of the county register of deeds. A street includes the land between the street lines, whether improved or unimproved, and comprises pavement, shoulders, gutters, sidewalks, parking areas, and lawns. Streets in all subdivisions shall be constructed of asphalt with concrete curb and gutter in accordance with Richmond engineering standards. 
(1)  Major thoroughfare means an arterial street of great continuity which is intended to serve as a large volume trafficway for both the immediate city area and region beyond, and may be designated in the city's major thoroughfare plan as a major thoroughfare, parkway, expressway, or equivalent term to identify those streets comprising the basic structure of the street plan. 
(2)  Street, boulevard means a street developed to two-lane, one-way pavements, separated by a median. 
(3)  Street, collector means a street used primarily to carry traffic from minor streets to major thoroughfares. 
(4)  Street, cul-de-sac means a minor street of short length, having one end open to traffic and being permanently terminated at the other end by a vehicular turnaround. 
(5)  Street, industrial means a street intended to serve primarily as a means of access within industrial subdivisions of industrial districts to a major thoroughfare and not intended to serve residential properties or to carry residential traffic. 
(6)  Street, marginal access means a minor street paralleling and adjacent to a major thoroughfare which provides access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic. 
(7)  Street, loop means a minor street of short length with two openings to traffic, beginning from the same street, and projecting parallel to each other and connecting at their termination by a loop. 
(8)  Street, minor means a street of limited continuity used primarily for access to abutting residential properties. 
(9)  Street, multiple-family residential means a street intended to serve primarily the greater traffic demands of multiple-family residential developments. Such streets may or may not have continuity within the overall thoroughfare plan. 
(10)  Street, trees mean trees that are required to be planted in the street right-of-way along subdivision streets. 
(11)  Street, turnaround means a short boulevard street permanently terminated by a vehicular turnaround. 
    Subdivision means the partitioning or dividing of a parcel or tract of land by the proprietor thereof or by his heirs, executors, administrators, legal representatives, successors or assigns for the purpose of sale, or lease of more than one year, or of building development that results in one or more parcels of less than 40 acres or the equivalent, and that is not exempted by the State Land Division Act (Act 288 of 1967, Sections 560.108 and 560.109). "Subdivide" or "Subdivision" does not include a property transfer between two or more adjacent parcels, if the property taken from one parcel is added to an adjacent parcel; and any resulting parcel shall not be considered a building site unless the parcel conforms to the requirements of the State Land Division Act or the requirements of this chapter. 
    Subdivision act means the subdivision control act, Act No. 288 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1967 (MCL 560.101 et seq.), as amended. 
    Zoning ordinance means the city zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. I, 8-5-02) 
Secs. 82-5-82-31. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLATS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 82-31. - Initial plat investigation. 
(a)  Prior to the preparation and filing of a stage 1: tentative preliminary plat, the proprietor may meet informally with the city manager, city planner and/or the planning commission in order that he may become familiar with the procedures and standards of this chapter and with the proposals of the master plan as they affect the area in which the proposed subdivision is located. The proprietor may present a conceptual plan for review at a planning commission meeting. The proprietor should concern himself with the following factors: 
(1)  The proprietor shall secure a copy of the zoning ordinance, subdivision regulations, engineering specifications, and other similar ordinances or controls relative to the subdivision and improvement of land so as to make himself aware of the requirements of the municipality. 
(2)  The area for the proposed subdivision shall be properly zoned for the intended use. 
(3)  An investigation of the adequacy of existing schools and the adequacy of public open spaces, including parks and playgrounds to serve the proposed subdivision shall be made by the proprietor. 
(4)  The relationship of the proposed subdivision with respect to major thoroughfares and plans for widening of thoroughfares shall be investigated by the proprietor. 
(5)  Standards for sewage disposal, water supply and drainage of the city and the health standards of the county and the state shall be investigated by the proprietor. 
(6)  The subdivision control act, Act No. 288 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1967 (MCL 560.101 et seq.), as amended, and the requirements of those county and state agencies which are required by such public act to review and approve the plat shall be reviewed by the proprietor. 
(b)  The proprietor is encouraged to submit a preliminary or initial plat (seven copies) to the county plat coordinating committee for its review and comment. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. II, 8-5-02) 
Sec. 82-32. - Three-phase approval process. 
    The preparation of a subdivision for platting shall be carried out through three phases or stages: 
(1)  Stage 1: tentative preliminary approval. 
(2)  Stage 2: final preliminary approval. 
(3)  Stage 3: final approval. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. II, 8-5-02) 
Secs. 82-33-82-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - STAGE 1: TENTATIVE PRELIMINARY PLAT 

Sec. 82-41. - Procedure for preparation and submittal. 
    The procedure under stage 1 for preparation and submittal of a tentative preliminary plat of the land area to be subdivided, shall be as follows: 
(1)  Filing 
a.  Ten copies of the tentative preliminary plat of the proposed subdivision, together with written application in triplicate, shall be submitted to the city clerk who shall forward them to the planning commission. 
b.  Submittal to the city clerk shall be at least 45 days prior to the regular planning commission meeting (which meeting shall be considered as the date of filing) at which the proprietor will be scheduled to appear. Should any of the required data be omitted, the applicant will be notified of the additional data required and commission action shall be delayed until the data is received. 
(2)  Identification and description. The stage 1: tentative preliminary plat shall include: 
a.  Proposed name of subdivision. 
b.  Location by section, town and range, or by other legal description. 
c.  Name and address of the proprietor, and an indication of the proprietor's interest in the land. 
d.  Name, address and seal of the registered land surveyor or registered professional engineer responsible for the design, layout and preparation of the plat. 
e.  Scale of plat, one inch equals 100 feet as minimum acceptable scale. 
f.  Date of preparation. 
g.  Northpoint. 
h.  Any information required by the subdivision act, or by the administrative rules of the state department of treasury, state highways, natural resources and public health and of the county drain commissioner as they relate to the act. 
(3)  Existing conditions. The stage 1: tentative preliminary plat shall include: 
a.  An overall area map at a scale of not less than one inch equals 800 feet showing the relationship of the subdivision to its surroundings such as section lines and/or major streets or collector streets and schools, parks, shopping centers, and other community facilities. The location map shall include at least that area which lies within one-half-mile of the subdivision boundary in all directions. 
b.  Boundary line of proposed subdivision, section or corporation lines within or adjacent to the tract and overall property dimensions. 
c.  Property lines of adjacent tracts of subdivided and unsubdivided land shown in relation to the tract being proposed for subdivision, including those of areas across abutting roads. 
d.  Location, widths, and names of existing or prior platted streets and private streets, and public easements within or adjacent to the tract being proposed for subdivision, including those located across abutting roads. 
e.  Location of existing sewers, water mains, storm drains and other underground facilities within or adjacent to the tract being proposed for subdivision. 
f.  Topography including natural and manmade features, vegetation and contours. All trees larger than three inches in diameter shall be identified. Contour interval shall be two feet with contours extending a minimum of 150 feet beyond the boundary of the plat. Topography to be based on USGS datum. Benchmarks for the work shall be indicated on the plat. 
g.  The school board or school board superintendent of the school district having jurisdiction in the area concerned shall be informed and made aware of the proposed tentative preliminary plat by the proprietor. A letter or document from the school board or school board superintendent indicating awareness of the proprietor's intentions, or a certified letter receipt from the applicant showing that the school board or school board superintendent was notified, shall be submitted to the planning commission as part of the tentative preliminary plat. 
(4)  Proposed conditions. The stage 1: tentative preliminary plat shall include: 
a.  Layout of streets indicating proposed street names, right-of-way width and connection with adjoining platted streets and also the widths and location of easements and public walkways. 
b.  Layout, numbers and scale dimensions of lots, including building setback lines showing dimensions. 
c.  Indication and description of parcels of land intended to be dedicated or set aside for public use or for the use of property owners in the subdivision or for future street connections to adjacent tracts or as major drainage easements when such are determined by the city engineer to be necessary. 
d.  An indication of the ownership, and existing and proposed use of any parcels identified as excepted on the preliminary plat. If the proprietor has an interest in or owns any parcel so identified as excepted, the preliminary plat shall indicate how this property could be developed in accordance with the requirements of the existing zoning district in which it is located and with an acceptable relationship to the layout of the proposed tentative preliminary plat. 
e.  An indication of system and easements proposed for sewage by a method approved by the council and the municipal engineer. 
f.  An indication of system and easement proposed for water supply by a method approved by the council and the municipal engineer. 
g.  An indication of proposed storm drainage and point of outlet at the subdivision line by a method approved by the council and the municipal engineer and, if involving county drains, the proposed drainage shall be acceptable to the county drain commissioner. 
h.  In the case where the proprietor wishes to subdivide a given area but wishes to begin with only a portion of the total area, the tentative preliminary plat shall include the proposed general layout for the entire area. The part which is proposed to be subdivided first shall be clearly superimposed upon the overall plan in order to illustrate clearly the method of development which the proprietor intends to follow. Each subsequent plat shall follow the same procedure until the entire area controlled by the proprietor is subdivided. 
i.  If the subdivisions is proposed to be developed under the subdivision open space plan, the subdivision shall meet the requirements of section 82-126. 
j.  An indication of the required underground utilities. 
k.  An indication of the land to be used for parks, playgrounds or recreational purposes. 
(5)  Stage 1: tentative preliminary plat review by planning commission. 
a.  The clerk shall receive and check for completeness the tentative preliminary plat as required by this chapter. If complete and basically in conformance with applicable municipal requirements, the clerk shall place the proposal on the agenda of the next month's regular commission meeting. 
b.  The clerk shall transmit a copy of the tentative preliminary plat to the municipal engineer and municipal planner for their technical review and recommendation. 
c.  The commission shall review all details of the proposed subdivision within the framework of the zoning ordinance, within the various elements of the master plan and within the standards of this chapter. 
d.  The commission shall approve conditionally, disapprove or approve the stage 1: tentative preliminary plat. 
(i)  Should the approval be a conditional approval, the tentative preliminary plat shall not be forwarded to the council until the conditions have been satisfied by the proprietor. 
(ii)  Should the commission disapprove the tentative preliminary plat, it shall record the reasons in the minutes of the regular meeting. A copy of the minutes shall be sent to the proprietor and the school board or school board superintendent of the school district having jurisdiction in the area concerned. 
(iii)  Should the commission find that all conditions have been satisfactorily met, it may give approval to the tentative preliminary plat. The chairman shall make a notation to that effect on each copy of the tentative preliminary plat and distribute copies as follows: 
i.  Return one copy to the proprietor; 
ii.  Retain one copy which shall become a matter of permanent record in the commission files; 
iii.  Forward one copy to the school board or school superintendent of the school district having jurisdiction in the area concerned; 
iv.  Forward the remaining four copies to the council via the clerk's office for informational purposes. 
(6)  Stage 1: tentative preliminary plat review by city council 
a.  The council will not review a tentative preliminary plat until it has received the review and recommendations of the planning commission. Following the receipt of such recommendations, the council shall consider the tentative preliminary plat at such meeting that the matter is placed on the regularly scheduled agenda. 
b.  Should the council approve the tentative preliminary plat, it shall record its approval on the plat and return one copy to the proprietor. 
c.  Tentative preliminary approval shall not constitute final preliminary plat approval. 
d.  Tentative preliminary plat approval by the council shall be effective for a period of 12 months. Should the final preliminary plat in whole or in part not be submitted for final preliminary plat approval within this time limit, the tentative preliminary plat must again be submitted to the commission for approval unless an extension is applied for by the proprietor, and such request, in writing, is granted by the council. 
e.  No installation or construction of any improvements shall be made on the basis of stage 1: tentative preliminary plat approval. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. II, 8-5-02) 
Secs. 82-42-82-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - STAGE 2: FINAL PRELIMINARY PLAT 

Sec. 82-51. - Procedure for preparation and review. 
    The procedure for the preparation and review of a stage 2: final preliminary plat requires approval as follows: 
(1)  Filing 
a.  Ten copies of a valid and complete stage 2: final preliminary plat of the proposed subdivisions, together with written application in triplicate and any other information required to be submitted under the subdivision control act shall be filed with the clerk. 
b.  Ten copies of plans and profiles, specifications, general plans and costs estimates for improvements, as specified in Section 82.171. 
c.  The final preliminary plat shall conform substantially to the stage 1: tentative preliminary plat as approved, and it may constitute only that portion of the approved tentative preliminary plat which the proprietor proposes to record and develop at the time; provided, however, that such portion conforms with the provisions of this chapter. 
d.  The clerk and/or the city manager shall check the proposed plat for completeness. Should any of the data required in the subdivision control act or this chapter be omitted, the clerk shall be directed to inform the proprietor of the data required, and that the application will be delayed until the required data is received. 
e.  The clerk shall transmit a copy of the valid and complete final preliminary plat to the municipal engineer and municipal planner for their technical review and recommendations. 
(2)  Information required. The stage 2: final preliminary plat shall include: 
a.  All information required in subsections 82-41(a), (c) and (d) for stage 1: tentative preliminary plat approval. 
b.  A certified list of all authorities required for approval in sections 560.112 to 119 of the state's Land Division Act. 
c.  All written approvals from the agencies listed in b., above. 
(3)  Stage 2: final preliminary plat review by city council. 
a.  The municipal engineer and planner shall notify the city council of their recommendations for either approval or rejection of the final preliminary plat. 
b.  If the final preliminary plat meets all conditions laid down for final tentative plat approval, the council shall give final approval to the preliminary plat. 
c.  The clerk shall promptly notify the proprietor of approval or rejection in writing; if rejected, reasons shall be given. 
d.  Stage 2: final preliminary plat approval shall be effective for a period of two years from the date of such approval. The two-year period may be extended if applied for by the proprietor and granted by the council in writing. 
e.  No installation or construction of any improvements shall be made before the final preliminary plat has received final approval of the council, engineering plans have been approved by the engineer, and any deposits required under Article V of this chapter, have been received by the city. Where improvements which are to be owned and/or maintained by the city, such as sewer connection and water distribution facilities, are to be installed prior to the recording of the final plat, acceptable easements running to the city must be filed with the clerk covering all proposed street rights-of-way and other places in which such installations are located. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. II, 8-5-02) 
Secs. 82-52-82-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - STAGE 3: FINAL PLAT 

Sec. 82-61. - Procedure for preparation and review. 
    The procedure for preparation and review of a stage 3: final plat shall be as follows: 
(1)  Filing 
a.  Five true mylar copies (or as per rules or procedures established by the state department of treasury) and three paper prints of the final plat shall be filed by the proprietor with the clerk, and the proprietor shall deposit such sums of money as may be required by ordinance. 
(2)  Information required. The proprietor shall submit the following with the final plat: 
a.  The proprietor shall submit as evidence of title an abstract of title certified to date with the written opinion of an attorney-at-law thereon, or at the option of the proprietor, a policy of title insurance for examination in order to ascertain as to whether or not the proper parties have signed the plat. 
(3)  Final plat review by city council 
a.  The final plat shall comply with the provisions of the subdivision regulations and the Subdivision Control Act, Act No. 288 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1967 (MCL 560.101 et seq.), as amended. 
b.  The final plat shall conform substantially to the stage 2: final preliminary plat as approved, and it may constitute only that portion of the approved final preliminary plat which the proprietor proposes to record and develop at the time; provided, however, that such portion conforms to this chapter. 
c.  The final plat shall be reviewed by the engineer and planner as to compliance with the approved final preliminary plat and plans for utilities and other improvements. 
d.  The engineer and planner shall notify the council of recommendations for either approval or rejection of the final plat. Notification shall be in writing and reasons shall be given when the recommendation is for rejection. 
e.  The council shall review all recommendations and take action on the final plat. 
f.  Upon the approval of the final plat by the council, the subsequent distribution shall follow the procedure set forth in subdivision control act. The three prints of the final plat shall be forwarded; one to the clerk, one to the planning commission, and one to the building department. The five true mylar copies (or, as per rules of procedure established by the state department of treasury) shall be forwarded to the clerk of the county plat board. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. II, 8-5-02) 
Secs. 82-62-82-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DESIGN LAYOUT STANDARDS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 82-71. - Conditions of approval. 
    The subdivision design layout standards set forth under this article are conditions of approval for plats. Complete plans for the construction of all streets, utilities, drainage and grading, prepared by a registered civil engineer shall be submitted with the preliminary plat. All final plans must be reviewed and approved by the council. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. III, 8-5-02) 
Secs. 82-72-82-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - STREETS 

Sec. 82-81. - Conformance requirements. 
    Streets shall conform to at least all minimum requirements of the general specifications and typical cross sections as set forth in this article, city engineering standards, and other conditions set forth by the council. 
(1)  Location and arrangements. 
a.  The proposed subdivision shall conform to the various elements of the master plan and shall be considered in relation to the existing and planned major thoroughfares and collector streets, and shall be platted in the location and width indicated on such plan. 
b.  The street layout shall provide for continuation of collector streets in adjoining subdivisions or the proper projection of streets when adjoining property is not subdivided; or shall conform to a plan for a neighborhood unit drawn up and adopted by the commission. 
c.  The street layout shall include minor streets so laid out that their use by through traffic shall be discouraged. 
d.  Should a proposed subdivision border on or contain an existing or proposed major thoroughfare, the commission may require marginal access streets, reverse frontage with an approved screen planting contained in a nonaccess reservation along the rear property line having a minimum width of 15 feet, or with side lot lines parallel to the major traffic street, or such other treatment as may be necessary for adequate protection of residential properties and to afford separation and reduction of traffic hazards. 
e.  Should a proposed subdivision border on or contain a railroad, expressway, or other limited access highway right-of-way, the commission may require the location of a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-of-way at a distance suitable for the development of an appropriate use of the intervening land such as for parks in residential districts, and may require separation treatment for the protection of pedestrians and residential properties. Such distances shall be determined with due consideration of the minimum distance required for approach grades to future grade separation. 
f.  Half streets shall be prohibited except where absolutely essential to the reasonable development of the subdivision in conformity with the other requirements of these regulations, and where the commission finds it will be practicable to require the dedication of the other half when the adjoining property is developed. Wherever there exists, adjacent to the tract to be subdivided, a dedicated or platted and recorded half street, the other half shall be platted. 
g.  Should a proposed subdivision border upon or contain an existing or proposed canal, channel or drainageway, the commission may require the location of the bridge facility suitable to permit the unimpeded flow of water and the passage of waterborne vehicles, and may require separation treatment along the canal, channel or drainageway to protect persons and property. 
h.  The council shall reject a plat which is isolated or which isolates other lands from existing public streets unless suitable access is provided. 
i.  The council shall reject a plat showing a street or road name duplicating one already in use in the city except in continuing a street or road. The council shall also reject a plat showing the name of a new street or road that is so similar to one already in existence in the city that permitting such use in the subdivision may be confusing to the public. 
j.  Maximum length for residential cul-de-sac streets shall generally be ten times the average width of lots on the street, but in no instance shall such street exceed 600 feet in length. Maximum length for industrial and other cul-de-sac streets may not exceed 500 feet; provided, however, in such cases where it can be satisfactorily demonstrated that a greater length will not endanger public health, safety or welfare, a greater length may be requested and submitted to the planning commission for its recommendation to the council for its approval. 
k.  Access to streets across all ditches shall be provided by the proprietor in a standard method approved by the council. 
(2)  Right-of-way widths. Street right-of-way widths shall conform to at least the following minimum requirements: 
Street type Right-of-way width (in feet) a. Major thoroughfare In conformance with the major thoroughfare plan of the city b. Collector streets 86 c. Industrial service streets 60 d. Multiple-family residential streets where platted 60 e. Minor (single-family residential) 60 f. Minor (mobile home park residential) streets 60 g. Marginal access streets 60 h. Turnaround (loop) streets 120 i. Cul-de-sac streets; turnarounds 1. Industrial 75-foot radius 2. Residential and others 60-foot radius  
(3)  Street grades. For adequate drainage, the minimum street grades shall not be less than five-tenths of one percent. The maximum street grade shall be five percent except that the commission may make an exception to this standard on the recommendation of the engineer. 
(4)  Street geometrics. Unless otherwise allowed by subsequently adopted resolution or standards of the city adopted by the council or specifically authorized by the council upon recommendation of the engineer, street geometrics shall be: 
a.  Minimum horizontal; the radii of centerline curvature: Major thoroughfares 700-foot radius. Collector streets 450-foot radius. Minor streets 275-foot radius. A minimum 50-foot tangent shall be introduced between reverse curves or minor streets; 100 feet on collector streets and 300 feet on major thoroughfares. 
b.  Minimum vertical visibility, measured from four and one-half-foot eye level to 18-inch taillight level: 500 feet on major thoroughfares; 300 feet on collector streets; 300 feet on minor streets; 100 feet on marginal access streets. 
c.  Minimum horizontal visibility : 300 feet on major thoroughfares, measured on centerline; 200 feet on collector streets, measured on centerline; 100 feet on minor streets, measured on centerline. 
(5)  Street intersections. Streets shall be laid out so as to intersect as nearly as possible to 90 degrees. Curved streets, intersecting with major thoroughfares and collector thoroughfares shall do so with a tangent section of centerline 50 feet in length, measured from the right-of-way line of the major or collector thoroughfare. 
(6)  Grading and centerline gradients. Per plans and profiles approved by the engineer. 
(7)  Street jogs. Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than 125 feet shall be avoided. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. III, 8-5-02) 
Secs 82-82-82-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BLOCKS 

Sec. 82-91. - Conformance standards. 
    Blocks within subdivisions shall conform to the following standards: 
(1)  Sizes 
a.  Maximum length for blocks shall not exceed 1,300 feet, except where, in the opinion of the commission, conditions may justify a greater distance. 
b.  Widths of blocks shall be determined by the condition of the layout and shall be suited to the intended layout. 
(2)  Public walkways. 
a.  Location of public walkways or crosswalks may be required by the commission to obtain satisfactory pedestrian access to public or private facilities such as, but not limited to, schools and parks. 
b.  Widths of rights-of-way for public walkways shall be at least 12 feet and shall be dedicated rights-of-way for this purpose. 
(3)  Easements 
a.  Easements for the location of underground electric, gas and cable shall be provided along the rear or side lot lines as necessary for utility lines. Easements shall give access to every lot, park or public grounds. Such easements shall be a total of not less than 12 feet wide, six feet from each parcel. 
b.  Recommendations on the proposed layout of telephone and electric company easements should be sought from all of the utility companies serving the area. It shall be the responsibility of the proprietor to submit copies of the preliminary plats to all appropriate public utility agencies. Front easement may be utilized if approved by the council.
