c.  Easements six feet in width, three feet from each parcel, shall be provided where needed along side lot lines so as to provide for street light dropouts. Prior to the approval of the stage 3: final plat for a proposed subdivision, a statement shall be obtained from the appropriate public utility indicating that easements have been provided along specific lots. A notation shall be made on the final plat indicating: "The side lot lines between lots (indicating lot numbers) are subject to streetlight dropout rights granted to the (name of utility company)." 
d.  Easements six feet in width, with the centerline being the property line, shall be provided from each rear yard drainage basis to the street right-of-way for the installation of drainage laterals in accordance with section 82-142. 
e.  Additional easements needed for storm drainage purposes shall be determined by the engineer and shall meet the requirements of the engineer. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. III, 8-5-02) 
Secs. 82-92-82-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - LOTS 

Sec. 82-101. - Standards of conformance. 
    Lots within a subdivision shall conform to the following standards: 
(1)  Sizes and shapes. 
a.  The lot size, width, depth and shape in any subdivision proposed for residential uses shall be appropriate for the location and type of development contemplated. 
b.  Lot areas and widths shall-conform to at least the minimum requirements of the zoning ordinance for the district in which the subdivision is proposed. 
c.  Building setback lines shall conform to at least the minimum requirements of the zoning ordinance. 
d.  Corner lots in residential subdivisions shall be platted at least 20 percent wider than the minimum width permitted by the zoning ordinance. 
e.  Excessive lot depth in relation to width shall be avoided. A depth-to-width ratio of three to one shall be a maximum. 
f.  Lots intended for purposes other than residential use shall be specifically designed for such purposes, and shall have adequate provision for off-street parking, setbacks, and other requirements in accordance with the zoning ordinance. 
(2)  Arrangements. 
a.  Every lot shall front or abut on a street. 
b.  Side lot lines shall be at right angles or radial to the street-lines. 
c.  Residential lots abutting major thoroughfares or collector streets, where marginal access streets are not desirable or possible to attain, shall be platted with reverse frontage lots with an approved screen planting contained in a nonaccess reservation along the rear property line having a minimum width of 15 feet, or with side lot lines parallel to the major traffic streets, or shall be platted with extra depth to permit generous distances between building and such trafficway. 
d.  Lots shall have a front-to-front relationship across all streets where possible. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. III, 8-5-02) 
Secs. 82-102-82-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - OPEN SPACES 

Sec. 82-111. - Open space plan. 
    The following requirements apply in addition to all other requirements of this article where a tentative preliminary plat is filed for approval under the subdivision open space plan section of the zoning ordinance. 
(1)  Statement of principles. Consideration by the commission and the council of proposed optional use of subdivision open space plan shall reflect the following basic principles: 
a.  The subdivision open space section of the zoning ordinance provides an optional method of subdividing property, and approval of any subdivision open space plan is subject to the discretion of the council. 
b.  Particular attention shall be given to the effect of a subdivision open space plan upon the immediate area, where the character of that area has been established by previous development. Major attention shall be given by the commission and the council to the benefits to be derived by the residents of the proposed subdivision and the municipality because of the subdivision open space plan, with minor consideration to be given to the proprietor. 
(2)  Application for plan approval; contents. The application for approval of the subdivision open space plan shall contain the following in addition to the information required by other sections of this article: 
a.  A complete description of the land proposed to be dedicated to the municipality or to the common use of lot owners (called open land in this division) shall be provided, including the following as a minimum: 
(i)  Legal description of open land. 
(ii)  Topographical survey of open land. 
(iii)  Type of soil in open land. 
(iv)  Description of natural features on open land (strands of trees or other vegetation, streams or other bodies of water, etc.) 
(v)  Other relevant factors. 
b.  The proposed plan of development of the open land shall be contained in the application and shall include the following as a minimum: 
(i)  The proposed manner in which the title to land and facilities is to be held by the owner of land in the subdivision. 
(ii)  The proposed manner of collection of maintenance costs, financing cost or assessments so that nonpayment will constitute a lien on the property, thus avoiding municipal responsibility in the future. 
(iii)  The proposed manner of regulating the use of the common facilities and areas so as to eliminate possible nuisances to other property owners and cause for enforcement by the governing unit. 
(iv)  The proposed method of notifying the municipality when any change is contemplated in plans that would affect the original specifications approved by the municipality. 
(v)  The proposed method of setting up assessments to cover contingencies, insurance against casualty and liability and payment of taxes relating to these properties. 
(vi)  The proposed uses of open land and the proposed improvements which are to be constructed by the proprietor. 
c.  The application shall contain a statement of the benefits to be realized by the residents of the proposed subdivision and the municipality by approval of the proposed subdivision open space plan, with particular reference to the objectives stated in the zoning ordinance. 
(3)  Approval. If the commission is satisfied that the proposed subdivision open space plan meets the letter and spirit of the zoning ordinance and should be approved, it shall recommend such approval to the council with the conditions upon which such approval should be based. Thereafter, the council shall take action upon such application in accordance with section 82-41. 
(4)  Disapproval. If the commission is not satisfied that the proposed subdivision open space plan meets the letter and spirit of the zoning ordinance or finds that the approval of the subdivision open space plan will be detrimental to existing development in the general area and should not be approved, it shall communicate such disapproval to the council with the reasons therefore. The proprietor shall be entitled to a hearing upon the proposal before the council upon written request therefore filed with the clerk. 
(5)  Contract. If the council gives approval to the proposed subdivision open space plan, it shall instruct the municipal attorney to prepare a contract setting forth the conditions upon which such approval is based, which contract, after approval by the council, shall be entered into between the municipality and the proprietor prior to the approval of the final preliminary plat based upon the approved tentative preliminary plat. The proprietor shall provide copies of agreements, covenants or other documents showing the manner in which areas to be reserved for the common use of residents of the subdivision are to be maintained and used. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. III, 8-5-02) 
Sec. 82-112. - Public reservations. 
    When consideration is given by the proprietor to the allocation of area suitable located and of adequate size for playgrounds, school sites, parks, and recreation facilities, as indicated in the master plan and zoning ordinance, such areas shall be provided by one of the following methods. 
(1)  Dedication to the city. 
(2)  Reservation of land for the use of property owners by deed or covenants. 
(3)  Reservation for acquisition by the city or school board within a period of two years. The reservation shall be made in such a manner as to provide for a release of the land to the proprietor if the municipality or the school board does not proceed with the purchase. 
    Due regard shall be shown for preserving outstanding natural features such as scenic spots, watercourses or exceptionally fine groves or trees. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. III, 8-5-02) 
Sec. 82-113. - Preservation of natural features. 
    The natural features and character of lands must be preserved wherever possible. Due regard must be shown for all natural features such as large trees, natural groves, watercourses and similar community assets that will add attractiveness and value to the property, if preserved. The preservation of drainage and natural stream channels must be considered by the proprietor and the dedication and provision of adequate barriers, where appropriate, shall be required. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. III, 8-5-02) 
Sec. 82-114. - Floodplains. 
    Any areas of land within the proposed subdivision which lie either wholly or in part within the floodplain of a river, stream, creek or lake, or any other areas which are subject to flooding or inundation by storm water or have inadequate drainage should not be platted for any use as may increase danger to health, life or property. The subdivider may show by way of accurately engineered plans that a change to the topography in the proposed subdivision will eliminate flooding in the area in question and shall clearly demonstrate that any such planned topographical change will not unduly aggravate the flood hazard beyond the limits of the proposed subdivision. If the city council determines that a flood problem does exist, then it shall reject all or that part of the proposed subdivision lying within the floodplain. Any areas of land lying within a floodplain shall require specific compliance with Act No. 288 of the Public Acts of Michigan (MCL 560.101 et seq.), as amended, and review by the land and water management division of the department of environmental quality. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. III, 8-5-02) 
Secs. 82-115-82-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - IMPROVEMENTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 82-131. - Acceptable standards. 
(a)  Minimum required. Improvements set forth under this section are to be considered as the minimum acceptable standard. All those improvements for which standards are not specifically set forth in this article shall have such standards set by ordinance, resolution, published rules or the city, or city engineering standards. All improvements must meet the approval of the engineer and the council. 
(b)  Deposit of funds to ensure completion. Prior to the undertaking of the installation of any improvements required by this article, the proprietor or subdivider shall deposit with the clerk cash, a certified check or irrevocable bank letter of credit running to the municipality, whichever the proprietor selects, or a corporate surety bond acceptable to the council, in an amount set by the council upon recommendation of the engineer to ensure faithful and satisfactory completion of all improvements required by this article within the time period set by the council when the final plat is approved. The council shall release funds for payment of work as it is completed, approved and accepted by the city. No building permit for any permanent structure within the subdivision shall be issued until the required deposit for the installation of all improvements has in fact been deposited with the city clerk. 
(c)  Maintenance bond. Prior to acceptance by the municipality of improvements, a three-year maintenance bond in an amount equal to 35 percent of the total cost shall be deposited by the subdivider or proprietor, provide that the council retains the right to lower the 35 percent of the total cost amount if it determines that no public benefit would be served by requiring a maintenance bond for a specifically named improvement required by this article. 
(d)  Improvements according to city standards. Improvements shall be provided by the proprietor or subdivider in accordance with the city's engineering standards and specifications as adopted by the city council, or standards and requirements established in this or any other article or any other such standards and requirements which may from time to time be established by ordinance, resolution or published rules of the city. The plans and profiles for all improvements must be approved by the engineer prior to any installation thereof. 
(e)  Soil borings. Prior to the submittal of plans to the engineer improvements, soil borings shall be obtained by the subdivider or proprietor and this information submitted with the plans. Soil boring shall be obtained by a qualified soil testing laboratory at a minimum of one per five acres of subdivision area. All costs for the repair of existing utilities, structure and/or streets damaged during the construction of improvements, as determined by the council, shall be paid for by the subdivider or proprietor. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. IV, 8-5-02) 
Secs. 82-132-82-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 82-141. - Streets. 
(a)  Materials and specifications. All streets shall be constructed of asphalt and in accordance with details and specifications approved by the engineer and council. All curbs and gutters shall be constructed of integral concrete. 
(b)  Street pavement width standards 
Street type Pavement width (Measured from back of curb to back of curb, in feet) (1) Major thoroughfare In conformance with the standards and specifications established by the council (2) Collector streets (Non-boulevard) 36 (3) Collector streets (boulevard) 38 (16-foot island) (4) Industrial streets 40 (5) Multiple-family residential streets 31 (6) Minor residential streets 31 (7) Marginal access streets 28 (8) Turnaround (loop) streets Not less than 90-foot diameter at terminating loop (9) Cul-de-sac streets; turnarounds a. Industrial 65 b. Residential and other 45  
    For subdivision site plan approval, the planning commission must be informed of planned parking arrangements on the streets. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. IV, 8-5-02) 
Sec. 82-142. - Utilities. 
(a)  Requirements for underground wiring. The proprietor shall make arrangements for all local distribution lines for telephone, electric, television and other similar services distributed by wire or cable to be placed underground entirely throughout the area subdivided for residential use, except for main supply and perimeter feed distribution lines which serve areas outside the subdivided area, and except for surface facilities related to underground service, such as aboveground closure or terminals, and such wires, conduits or cables shall be placed within private easements provided to such service companies by the proprietor or within dedicated public ways, provided that overhead local distribution lines within such residential area may be permitted upon written recommendation from the planning commission, upon advisement from the planner or engineer, and the approval of the council at the time of final plat approval where it is determined that overhead lines will not constitute a detriment to the health, safety, general welfare, plat design and character of the subdivision. All such facilities placed in dedicated public ways shall be planned so as not to conflict with other underground utilities. All such facilities shall be constructed in accordance with standards of construction approved by the state public service commission. All drainage and underground utility installations which traverse privately owned property shall be protected by easements granted by the proprietor. No underground wires shall be placed in the street rights-of-way. 
(b)  Sewage disposal. A sanitary sewer system including all appurtenances shall be required in all subdivisions which shall connect and outlet into a municipal sanitary sewer system. 
(1)  Sanitary sewer specifications. In addition to meeting all standards and specifications as published in the city's engineering manual, the sanitary sewers must meet the following specifications: 
a.  Footing drains of any structure shall not be connected to the sanitary sewer. 
b.  Sewer profile. The sewer profile shall indicate the length of run between each manhole, the type of sewer pipe, the size and slope of the sewer between manholes, and any type of special bedding required. Top elevations of all manholes and inverts shall be indicated. 
(c)  Water supply. Water mains, fire hydrants and required water system appurtenances shall be constructed in such a manner as to adequately serve all lots shown on the subdivision plat, both for domestic use and fire protection and shall be connected to a municipal water supply system. 
(1)  Water mains. In addition to meeting all standards and specifications as published in the city's engineering manual, the water supply must meet the following specifications: 
a.  Laterals. In general, lateral water mains shall be eight inches in diameter. Six-inch diameter water mains shall not have a run longer than 400 feet between connections to an eight-inch water main. Gate valves shall be located in the system such that not more than four valves need be turned off to isolate any section of water main. Moreover, sufficient valves shall be placed such that not more than 30 lots shall be serviced within such section of water main which can be so isolated. Where possible, gate valves shall be located at street intersections five feet from the intersecting street right-of-way line. 
b.  Hydrants. Hydrants shall be installed along the water main at least every 500 feet. In no case shall a house be more than 300 feet from a hydrant. In commercial or industrial districts, additional hydrants may be required. Hydrants shall be installed at the ends of all dead-end water mains. When near a street intersection, hydrants shall be located 15 feet from the intersecting street right-of-way. Hydrants shall be city standard. Location of hydrants shall be approved in writing by the fire chief. 
c.  Finished grades of hydrants and gate wells. The plans shall indicate the finished grades of all hydrants and gate wells. 
(d)  Storm drainage system. An adequate storm drainage system including necessary storm sewers, catch basins, manholes, bridges and other appurtenances shall be required in all subdivisions. 
(1)  County and state regulations. The proprietor shall design and provide storm sewers and all drainage improvements and necessary drainage in accordance with the published Rules and Regulations of the Macomb County Drain Commission, pursuant to Section 105(c) of Act No. 288 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1967 (MCL 560.101 et seq.), as amended. 
(2)  Storm sewer specifications. In addition to meeting all standards and specifications as published in the city's engineering manual, storm sewers must meet the following specifications: 
a.  Collector sewers. Storm sewers installed for the purpose of providing drainage for streets shall be located in the street right-of-way. 
b.  Submain sewers Storm sewer submains installed for the purpose of connecting collector sewers with main line sewers or county drains shall be located in a public easement as determined by the engineer. 
(i)  Field catch basins. Field catch basins shall be provided at all low points in the easement. Locate field catch basins such that not more than 300 feet of drainage runs into any catch basin from any one direction or a total of 600 feet of drainage from all directions. 
(ii)  Improved open drains. Improved open drains may be permitted by the city engineer upon special circumstances in accordance with city engineering standards. 
c.  Rear yard drainage. Positive rear yard drainage shall be provided for each lot. Adequate provision shall be made for proper drainage of storm water runoff from each lot into a catch basis. Each yard shall be self-contained to the extend that water does not run from one lot onto an adjacent lot, but rather flows into the catch basin. 
d.  Storm sewer laterals. Lateral storm sewers, not less than six inches in diameter, shall be constructed from each rear yard catch basin to the street collector storm sewer. The lateral shall also provide the outlet for the footing drain lead. The lead shall be not less than four-inch diameter pipe for gravity sewer or not less than two-inch diameter pipe for sump pump discharge. The lead shall be constructed at a minimum depth of three and one-half feet on a minimum of one percent grade. The materials and methods of construction shall be in accordance with the current city standards. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. IV, 8-5-02) 
Sec. 82-143. - Grading and site drainage. 
(a)  Soil erosion and sediment control principles. In order to provide effective soil erosion and sediment control; practical combinations of the following technical principles shall be applied to the erosion control aspect of the grading plan: 
(1)  The smallest practical area of land shall be exposed at any one time during development. 
(2)  When land is exposed during development, the exposure shall be kept to the shortest practical period of time, and in no case shall exposure occur for longer than two months. 
(3)  Temporary vegetation and/or mulching shall be used to protect critical area exposed during development. 
(4)  Sediment basins (debris basins or silt traps) shall be installed and maintained to remove sediment from runoff waters from land undergoing development. 
(5)  Provisions shall be made to effectively accommodate the increased runoff caused by changed soil and surface conditions after development. 
(6)  The permanent final vegetation and structures shall be installed as soon as practical in the development. 
(7)  The development plan shall be fitted to the topography and soil so as to create the least erosion potential. 
(8)  Wherever feasible, natural vegetation shall be retained and protected. 
(b)  Surface Drainage Standards. 
(1)  Asphalt-paved or grass-covered areas shall have a minimum general slope of one percent with specific water carrying swales having a minimum slope of four-tenths of one percent. 
(2)  Concrete paved surfaces shall have a minimum slope of four-tenths of one percent. 
(3)  All project areas shall drain stormwaters to suitable disposal structures which will prevent such storm water from flowing across adjacent private property and prevent damage to both private and public properties. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. IV, 8-5-02) 
Sec. 82-144. - Sidewalks. 
(a)  Improvement requirements. A five-foot wide concrete sidewalk located within the street right-of-way one foot from the property line on each side of the roadway shall be provided. A five-foot wide concrete sidewalk located within the street right-of-way one foot from the property line of any public roadway abutting or adjacent to the subdivision shall also be provided. The council may require sidewalks on only one side of the roadway in the case of major thoroughfares, industrial streets or marginal access streets. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. IV, 8-5-02; Ord. No. 93-3, § 1, 4-19-04) 
Sec. 82-145. - Public walkways. 
(a)  Improvement requirements. The surface of the walkways shall be concrete or asphalt and shall be at least eight feet in width, with the balance of the required 12-foot right-of-way being distributed equally on each side of the walkway and seeded or sodded according to city specifications. Planting pockets shall be provided for tree and shrub planting along the walkway. The planting plan and surface treatment shall meet the approval of the planning commission, and fences and/or other improvements may also be required if the commission and/or council determines they are necessary to protect the adjacent property owners. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. IV, 8-5-02) 
Sec. 82-146. - Street trees. 
(a)  Improvement requirements. Existing trees near street rights-of-way shall be preserved by the proprietor. Street trees at least two and one-half inches in diameter measured six inches above ground line shall be provided at least one per lot in the street right-of-way between the sidewalk and the curb. On corner lots, one street tree shall be provided for each street frontage. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. IV, 8-5-02) 
Sec. 82-147. - Street name and traffic control signs. 
(a)  Improvement requirements. Street name signs and traffic control signs shall be purchased and installed by the subdivider or proprietor. The number, location and type of signs shall be determined by the city department of public works, police department and/or engineer in accordance with current standards of the city, county road commission and/or department of state highways. All signs shall be in place prior to the issuance of a building permit. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. IV, 8-5-02) 
Sec. 82-148. - Monuments. 
(a)  Improvement requirements. Monuments shall be placed at all block corners, angle points, points of curves in streets, and at intermediate points as determined by the municipal engineer. The monuments shall be concrete cylinder not less than four inches in diameter, nor less than 30 inches in length, with a center steel rod. The monuments shall be installed to the municipal engineer's satisfaction prior to the issuance of any building permit. Property irons shall be located at all lot corners. Property irons shall be #4 re-bar, and not be less than 18 inches in length with I.D. caps. Final plat approval may be given by the council prior to the installation of monuments, provided a surety in the amount of $100.00 per monument and $70.00 per lot corner iron is given to the city clerk by the subdivider or proprietor. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. IV, 8-5-02) 
Sec. 82-149. - Streetlights. 
(a)  Improvement requirements. The proprietor or subdivider shall arrange with the Detroit Edison Company for the installation of streetlights at all street intersections and other locations deemed appropriate by the city. The cost of installation shall not be borne by the city, and all feeders or conductors for streetlights shall be placed underground. The city engineer shall approve the location of all underground feeders and conductors. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. IV, 8-5-02) 
Sec. 82-150. - Parks, playgrounds and recreation areas. 
(a)  Reservation for parks, playgrounds and recreation areas. Land may be reserved for parks, playgrounds or recreational purposes in accordance with the master plan or other local plans. While the plan may show only the general location of such proposed sites, the required reservation of such lands for recreational purposes must be specifically located and designated on the final subdivision plat. 
(b)  Method of reservation. When consideration is given by the proprietor to the allocation of land for playgrounds, parks and recreation facilities, such areas shall be provided by one of the following methods: 
(1)  Dedication to the city. 
(2)  Reservation of land for the use of property owners by deed or covenants. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. IV, 8-5-02) 
Secs. 82-151-82-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SUBMITTAL PROCEDURES 

Sec. 82-161. - Requirements and review. 
(a)  The proprietor shall submit to the city planner during stage 2: final preliminary plat, ten sets of plans and profiles, specifications, the general plan for each system for which approval is desired, and a detailed estimate of cost for the furnishing and installation of the following improvements: pavement (streets, curb and gutter, sidewalks and, where applicable, public walkways); sanitary sewers and appurtenances; storm sewers and appurtenances; and water mains and appurtenances. The proprietor shall also simultaneously furnish four sets of a detail grading plan for site drainage and erosion and sediment control. 
(b)  Upon submission of plans for improvements, the proprietor shall pay to the city clerk the deposit for the engineering review fee, as set forth in section 82-201. If substantial changes are required in improvement plans, the proprietor shall pay to the city clerk at the time of resubmitting the plans the additional deposit set forth in section 82-201. 
(c)  The engineer shall review the plans for all improvements for compatibility with overall system plans of the city, for compatibility with the particular conditions in and around the proposed subdivision, for adequacy to serve the intended uses and protected needs, and for compliance with standards and specifications set forth in this article, the city's engineering manual, or in other ordinances, resolutions of published rules or documents of the city, including any standard detail sheets furnished by the city engineer and adopted by the city. The engineer shall also review the detail cost estimates for furnishing and installing all improvements. Upon completion of the review, the engineer shall return to the city manager three complete sets of plans and information, with notes on the plans and in an attached report if necessary, of any discrepancies, in adequacies, nonconforming or incompatible elements, or recommended changes in plans, profiles, specifications and/or cost estimates, if all elements are acceptable, the engineer shall so certify such fact on each sheet of the plans and information returned to the city manager. 
(d)  If all plans, profiles, specifications and costs estimates are approved by the engineer, the city manager shall forward one set to the council for final approval, and then return on approved set to the proprietor. If any element is unacceptable to the engineer, the city manager shall return all information pertaining to that element to the proprietor, who shall make the required change and resubmit ten complete sets of revised plans and related information to the city manager. The procedural steps set forth in this section for the initial deposit, review and approval shall apply for any substantially revised plans, profiles, specifications and cost estimates. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. IV, 8-5-02) 
Secs. 82-162-82-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - IMPROVEMENT PLAN REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 82-171. - General requirements. 
(a)  Prints. Plans submitted shall be on 24-inch × 36-inch or 22-inch × 34-inch prints having blue or black lines, and shall be neatly and accurately prepared. Judgment should be exercised in the design, layout and presentation of proposed improvements. 
(b)  Project with more than one sheet of plans; specifications. For projects having more than one sheet of plans, a cover index sheet shall be provided and a general plan having a scale of one inch equals 100 feet shall be provided showing the overall project and indicating the location of all improvement shown on the detailed plans and a legal land description of the project together with a location sketch. Street names, lot lines and lot numbers shall be shown on all plans. Easements shall have a minimum width of 12 feet. Sewers in easements shall be kept at least two feet away from side or rear lot lines. Superimposed on this general plan shall be two-foot contours of the area including the area at least 100 feet outside of the project. 
(c)  Sewers. All sewers shall be shown in plan and profile. Profiles of sewer shall indicate the size, invert and slop of the sewer and shall indicate the existing ground and proposed grade along the route of the sewer. 
(d)  Elevations. Elevations shall be on USGS datum. If in a street right-of-way, show on the profile the adjacent top of curb or edge of pavement grade (existing or proposed). Two benchmarks for the work shall be indicated on each sheet of the plans. 
(e)  Finished grades. Finished grades of structures shall be indicated on the plan or profile for all structures. 
(f)  Plat. If the project is in an existing or proposed subdivision, a copy of the plat shall be attached to the plans. 
(g)  Seal. All plans submitted shall bear the seal of the registered professional engineer responsible for the design. 
(h)  As-built plan. One mylar copy of the as-built plan of the project, water and sanitary sewer shall be provided prior to acceptance of the subdivision improvements by the city. If all infrastructure improvements are not completed, individual as-built plans for separate infrastructure systems may be submitted with the approval of the city. 
(i)  Project improvement plans. Complete project improvement plans shall be submitted prior to review and approval of any portion thereof. Project improvement plans must be submitted for stage 2: final plat approval. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. IV, 8-5-02) 
Secs. 82-172-82-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - COMPLIANCE STANDARDS 

Sec. 82-181. - Approval required prior to installation. 
    The approvals required under the provisions of this chapter shall be obtained prior to the installation of any subdivision or project improvements within the city, in public streets, public rights-of-way, and public easements and/or under the ultimate jurisdiction of the city. All subdivision or project improvements within the city installed in public streets, public rights-of-way or public easements and/or under the ultimate jurisdiction of the city shall comply with all of the provisions and requirements of this chapter or any other related ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. IV, 8-5-02) 
Secs. 82-182-82-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FEES, INSURANCE AND BONDS 

Sec. 82-191. - Review and other fees. 
    Preliminary (stages 1 and 2) and final plat (stage 3) review fees, planning fees, engineering fees, inspection fees, water and sewer connection charges, required deposits, and other applicable development charges shall be paid by the proprietor according to the fee schedule periodically approved by the city council. Fees for city review and administration for conventional subdivision plats and for all other plats shall be paid to the city clerk prior to formal consideration of stage 1: tentative preliminary plat by the planning commission or the council. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. V, 8-5-02) 
Sec. 82-192. - Construction insurance. 
    Prior to construction of subdivision and project improvements, the contractor shall procure and maintain, during the life of any contract or agreement for construction, insurance protecting the city form any claim for damages, real, personal, or otherwise. Prior to acceptance by the municipality of an improvement, a three-year maintenance bond in an amount equal to 35 percent of the total cost shall be deposited by the proprietor, provided that the council may reduce the 35 percent of the total cost amount if it determines that no public benefit would be served by requiring a maintenance bond for a specifically named improvement required by this chapter. The amount of the insurance coverage and of the bond shall be established by the council by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. V, 8-5-02) 
Secs. 82-193-82-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - VARIANCE 
DIVISION 1. - VARIANCE FOR HARDSHIP 

Sec. 82-201. - Conditions for granting. 
    The council may authorize a variance from these regulations when, in its opinion, undue hardship may result from strict compliance. In granting any variance, the council shall prescribe only conditions that it deems necessary to or desirable for the public interest. In making its findings as required in this section, the council shall take into account the nature of the proposed use of land and the existing use of land in the vicinity, the number of persons to reside or work in the proposed subdivision and the probable effect of the proposed subdivision upon traffic conditions in the vicinity. No variance shall be granted unless the council finds that: 
(1)  There are special circumstances or conditions affecting the property such that the strict application of the provisions of this chapter would deprive the applicant of the reasonable use of his land. 
(2)  The variance is necessary for the preservation and enjoyment of a substantial property right of the petitioner. 
(3)  The granting of the variance will not be detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to other property in the territory in which the property is situated. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. V, 8-5-02) 
DIVISION 2. - COMPLETE NEIGHBORHOOD 

Sec. 82-211. - Required elements of proposal. 
    The council may authorize a variance from these regulations in case of a plan for a complete community or neighborhood where such development is permitted by the zoning ordinance and which, in the judgment of the council, and after a recommendation is had from the commission, provides adequate public spaces and includes provisions for efficient circulation, light and air and other needs. In making its findings as required in this section, the council shall take into account the nature of the proposed use and the existing use of land in the vicinity, the number of persons to reside or work in the proposed subdivision and the probable effect of the proposed development upon traffic conditions in the vicinity. The council shall find that: 
(1)  There is adequate acreage and population in the proposed plan so as to support at least one elementary school. 
(2)  The standards and requirements of the zoning ordinance of the city are met. 
(3)  The planning commission has reviewed the plan and recommends its approval as having met the standards and intent of the master plan of land use as it relates to facility needs. 
(4)  In granting the variance, it shall be valid only as long as the plan for the complete neighborhood is carried out as approved. Any departure from the plan shall immediately rescind any variance granted. 
(5)  The council shall establish a performance schedule to be met on the various aspects of the complete neighborhood plan. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. V, 8-5-02) 
Sec. 82-212. - Application. 
    Application for any such variance shall be submitted in writing by the proprietor at the time the stage 1: tentative preliminary plat is filed, stating fully and clearly all facts relied upon by the proprietor and shall be supplemented with maps, plans, or other additional data which may aid in the analysis of the proposed project. The plans for such developments shall include such covenants, restrictions or other legal provisions necessary to guarantee the full achievement of the plan. 
(Ord. No. 93-2, art. V, 8-5-02) 
Secs. 82-213-82-225. - Reserved. 
ARTICLES VII-XIV. - RESERVED 

Secs. 82-226-82-440. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - PARTITION OF LANDS 

Sec. 82-441. - Restrictions. 
    No lot, out lot or other parcel of land located in the city, whether in a recorded plat or otherwise, shall be further partitioned or divided unless in conformity with the provisions of this chapter; provided, however, that no lot, out lot, or other parcel of land shall be further partitioned or divided if the resulting lots, out lots, or other parcels are less than the minimum dimensions and other requirements provided for in the zoning ordinance, except as otherwise provided in this section; and provided further, that the partitioning of parcels of land shall not result in the dividing of any lot, out lot, or other parcel of land into more than four parts. 
(Ord. No. 107, § I, 9-25-80) 
Sec. 82-442. - Procedure for partitioning or dividing of lots, out lots, or other parcels of land; evidence of title; survey; recording. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to divide or partition any lot, out lot, or other parcel of land in the city except in accordance with the following procedure: The applicant shall present to the city clerk, for passage on to the city council, sufficient evidence of title to the lot, out lot, or other parcel of land sought to be divided, together with a survey prepared by a registered land surveyor, in such form as to be acceptable for recording in the register of deeds office, and in addition thereto, the applicant shall present to the city clerk a sufficient legal description presented in a form sufficient for recording in the office of the county register of deeds, provided that if the partition will result in a lot size less than the requirements of the zoning ordinance, then the applicant shall also submit in addition to the information described in this subsection a fully executed affidavit, with a sufficient legal description for recording in the register of deeds office, signed by the owners containing a statement that each affiant understands and agrees and any and all other persons or entities having or claiming a legal or equitable interest in the parcel sought to be divided, containing a statement that each affiant understands and agrees that the partition or divided lot, out lot or other parcel of land, if approved by the city council, shall not thereafter be developed or used separately, but only in conjunction with the adjoining parcel of land. 
(Ord. No. 107, § II, 9-25-80) 
Chapter 86 - TAXATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; community development, ch. 34; special assessments, ch. 74. 
State Law reference- General property tax act, MCL 211.1 et seq. 

Sec. 86-1. - Tax payment schedule. 
    Taxes for the city shall become due July 1 of each year and are payable on or before August 31 the following year, without penalty. 
(Ord. No. 97-1, § I) 
Sec. 86-2. - Delinquent taxes. 
    All city taxes unpaid after August 31 of each year shall be delinquent, and all such taxes, assessments and charges together with any collection charges and interest added thereto shall be returned to the county treasurer as to the extent and in the same manner and with like effect as provided by law for returns by township treasurers of the township, school and county taxes; and shall be and remain a lien upon the property against which they are assessed until paid. 
(Ord. No. 97-1, § II) 
Sec. 86-3. - Collection and interest charges. 
    City taxes collected by the county or city treasurer after August 31 shall have added thereto a four percent collection fee and interest on the tax at the rate of one percent per month. 
(Ord. No. 97-1, § III) 
Sec. 86-4. - County and school tax collection. 
    Taxes collected for the county and school by the city treasurer after the last day of February and before settlement with the county treasurer shall have added thereto the collection fee and interest on the tax, as established by the state statutes, with all payments treated as though collected by the county treasurer. All such fees collected by the city treasurer shall be credited to the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 97-1, § IV) 
Sec. 86-5. - Personal property. 
    If the city treasurer is apprehensive of the loss of any personal property tax assessed upon the tax roll, he may enforce his collection at any time and, if compelled to seize property or bring suit, may add four percent for the collection fee. 
(Ord. No. 97-1, § V) 
Chapter 87 - TOBACCO PRODUCTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 144, adopted May 1, 2000, and Ord. No. 145, adopted May 25, 2000, enacted provisions which were not specifically amendatory of the Code. For purposes of classification, these ordinances' provisions have been set out as Arts. I and II, respectively, of this chapter. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 87-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
    Tobacco product means a preparation of tobacco to be inhaled, chewed or placed in a person's mouth. 
    Use of a tobacco product means any of the following: 
(1)  The carrying by a person of a lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe or other lighted smoking device. 
(2)  The inhaling or chewing of a tobacco product. 
(3)  The placing of a tobacco product within a person's mouth. 
    School property means a building, facility or structure and other real estate owned, leased or otherwise controlled by a school district. 
    School district means a school district, local act school district or intermediate school district, as those terms are defined in the school code of 1976, Act No. 451 of the Public Acts of 1976, being Sections 380.1 to 380.1852 of the Michigan Compiled Laws, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 144, 5-1-00) 
Sec. 87-2. - Use or possession of a tobacco product by a minor in public. 
    A person under 18 years of age shall not possess or use a tobacco product on a public highway, street, alley, park or other lands used for public purposes, or in a public place of business or amusement. 
(Ord. No. 144, 5-1-00) 
Sec. 87-3. - Tobacco products on school property. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in subsection (b), a person shall not use a tobacco product on school property. 
(b)  Use of tobacco products shall be permissible on that part of school property consisting of outdoor areas including, but not limited to, an open-air stadium, during either of the following time periods: 
(1)  Saturdays, Sundays and other days on which there are no regularly scheduled school hours. 
(2)  After 6 p.m. on days during which there are regularly scheduled school hours. 
(Ord. No. 144, 5-1-00) 
Sec. 87-4. - Civil sanctions. 
    A person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be responsible for a civil infraction. 
(1)  The sanction for any violation of this chapter which is a municipal civil infraction shall be a civil fine up to $500.00, plus any costs, damages, expenses and other sanctions as authorized under Chapter 87 of Act No. 236 of the Public Acts of 1961, as amended, and other applicable laws. 
(2)  Officers of the Richmond City Police Department are the city officials authorized to issue citations for a violation which is a municipal civil infraction under this article. 
(Ord. No. 144, 5-1-00) 
Secs. 87-5-87-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FURNISHING TOBACCO TO MINORS 

Sec. 87-26. - Selling, giving, or furnishing tobacco products to persons under 18 prohibited. 
    A person shall not sell, give, or furnish any cigarette, cigar, chewing tobacco, tobacco snuff, or tobacco in any other form to a person under 18 years of age. A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor, punishment by imprisonment for not more than 93 days or a fine of not more than $500.00, or both such imprisonment and fine, for each offense, plus the costs of prosecution. 
(Ord. No. 145, 5-25-00) 
Sec. 87-27. - Sign to be posted. 
    Beginning 90 days after the effective date of this subsection, a person who sells tobacco products at retail shall post, in a place close to the point of sale and conspicuous to both employees and customers, a sign that includes the following statement: 
"The purchase of tobacco products by a minor under 18 years of age and the providing of tobacco products to a minor are prohibited by law. A minor unlawfully purchasing or using tobacco products is subject to civil penalties." 
(Ord. No. 145, 5-25-00) 
Sec. 87-28. - Size of sign. 
    If the sign required under section 87-2 is more than six feet from the point of sale, it shall be at least five and one-half inches by eight and one-half inches, and the statement required under section 87-2 shall be printed in at least 36-point bold face type. If the sign required under section 87-2 is six feet or less from the point of sale, it shall be at least two inches by four inches, and the statement required under section 87-2 shall be printed in at least 20-point bold face type. 
(Ord. No. 145, 5-25-00) 
Chapter 90 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 90-1-90-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MOTOR VEHICLE CODE AND UNIFORM TRAFFIC CODE[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 143, adopted April 17, 2000, set out provisions for inclusion herein as §§ 90-1-90-5, and specifically repealed former §§ 90-26-90-29, which pertained to the Uniform Traffic Code and derived from Ord. No. 104, §§ 1, 2, and 5, adopted August 23, 1979. At the editor's discretion, for purposes of classification, the new provisions have been codified herein as §§ 90-26-90-30. 
Subsequently, Ord. No. 154, § 1, adopted August 18, 2003, renamed this article, formerly titled "Michigan Vehicle Code," and enacted provisions intended for use as §§ 90-40-90-46. At the discretion of the editor, these provisions have been included herein as §§ 90-41-90-47, to preserve the style of the Code. Also, the article has been divided into two divisions pursuant to these changes. 

DIVISION 1. - MICHIGAN VEHICLE CODE 

Sec. 90-26. - Code adopted. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of Act No. 260 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1999 (MCL 117.3(k)), the Michigan Vehicle Code, Act No. 300 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1949 (MCL 257.1 to 257.923), as amended, is hereby adopted by reference. 
(Ord. No. 143, 4-17-00) 
Sec. 90-27. - References in Code. 
    References in the Michigan Vehicle Code to "local authority" shall mean the City of Richmond, Michigan. 
(Ord. No. 143, 4-17-00) 
Sec. 90-28. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this ordinance is to adopt by reference the Michigan Vehicle Code as an ordinance of the city. The Code provides for the registration, regulation, and operation of vehicles, including enforcement and penalty provisions for violations. 
(Ord. No. 143, 4-17-00) 
Sec. 90-29. - Copies. 
    A complete copy of the Michigan Vehicle Code shall be available to the public at the office of the city clerk in compliance with state law requiring that records of public bodies be made available to the general public. 
(Ord. No. 143, 4-17-00) 
Sec. 90-30. - Penalties and enforcement. 
    Penalties for violation of this ordinance shall be those set forth in the Michigan Vehicle Code. The city shall not enforce any provision of the Michigan Vehicle Code for which the maximum period of imprisonment is greater than 93 days. 
(Ord. No. 143, 4-17-00) 
Secs. 90-31-90-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - UNIFORM TRAFFIC CODE 

Sec. 90-41. - Adoption of Uniform Traffic Code. 
    The Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships, and Villages as promulgated by the Director of the Michigan Department of State Police pursuant to the Administrative Procedures Act of 1969, 1969 PA 306, MCL 24.201 to 24.328 and made effective October 30, 2002, and all future amendments and revisions to the Uniform Traffic Code when they are promulgated and effective in this state are hereby adopted and incorporated by reference. 
(Ord. No. 154, § 1, 8-18-03) 
Sec. 90-42. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this division is to adopt by reference the Michigan Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships, and Villages as an ordinance of the city to establish regulations supplemental to the Michigan Vehicle Code to regulate street or roadway traffic upon the public rights-of-way which are under the jurisdiction of the City of Richmond. 
(Ord. No. 154, § 1, 8-18-03) 
Sec. 90-43. - Supplemental definitions. 
    "Highway", "right-of-way", "roadway", or "street" shall mean the total area dedicated to the city for public use for motorized or non-motorized vehicular or pedestrian traffic, including the unimproved portions of any such area, unless otherwise defined in the Michigan Vehicle Code or the Michigan Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships, and Villages. 
(Ord. No. 154, § 1, 8-18-03) 
Sec. 90-44. - References in code. 
    References in the Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships, and Villages to a "governmental unit" shall mean the City of Richmond. 
(Ord. No. 154, § 1, 8-18-03) 
Sec. 90-45. - Conflicts. 
    Whenever a conflict in provisions shall exist between the Michigan Vehicle Code and the Michigan Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships, and Villages, the provisions of the Michigan Vehicle Code shall supersede and govern to the extent of such conflict. 
(Ord. No. 154, § 1, 8-18-03) 
Sec. 90-46. - Copies. 
    A complete copy of the Michigan Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships, and Villages shall be available to the public at the office of the city clerk in compliance with state law requiring that records of public bodies be made available to the general public. 
(Ord. No. 154, § 1, 8-18-03) 
Sec. 90-47. - Penalties. 
    The penalties provided by the Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships, and Villages for violations of the provisions of the code are hereby adopted by reference. 
(Ord. No. 154, § 1, 8-18-03) 
Secs. 90-48-90-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARKING VIOLATIONS BUREAU 

Sec. 90-51. - Established. 
    Pursuant to section 8395 of Act No. 154 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1968 (MCL 600.8395), as amended, a parking violations bureau for the purpose of handling parking violations within the city is hereby established. The parking violations bureau shall be under the supervision and control of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 86-1, § I, 8-15-88) 
Sec. 90-52. - City manager supervision. 
    The city manager shall, subject to the approval of the city council, establish a convenient location for the parking violations bureau, appoint qualified city employees to administer the bureau and adopt rules and regulations for the operation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 86, § 2, 1-27-68) 
Sec. 90-53. - Jurisdiction. 
    No violation not scheduled in section 90-56 shall be disposed of by the parking violations bureau. The fact that a particular violation is scheduled shall not entitle the alleged violator to disposition of the violation at the bureau, and in any case the person in charge of such bureau may refuse to dispose of such violation in which case any person having knowledge of the facts may make a sworn complaint before any court having jurisdiction of the offense, as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 86, § 3, 1-27-68) 
Sec. 90-54. - Procedure for settling violations. 
    No violation may be settled at the parking violations bureau except at the specific request of the alleged violator. No penalty for any violation shall be accepted from any person who denies having committed the offense, and in no case shall the person who is in charge of the bureau determine, or attempt to determine, the truth or falsity of any fact or matter relating to such alleged violation. No person shall be required to dispose of a parking violation at the parking violations bureau, and all persons shall be entitled to have any such violation processed before a court having jurisdiction thereof if they so desire. The unwillingness of any person to dispose of any violation at the parking violations bureau shall not prejudice him or in any way diminish the rights, privileges and protection accorded to him by law. 
(Ord. No. 86, § 4, 1-27-68) 
Sec. 90-55. - Parking violations tickets. 
    The issuance of a traffic ticket or notice of violation by a police officer of the city shall be deemed an allegation of a parking violation. Such traffic ticket or notice of violation shall indicate the length of time in which the person to whom the ticket or notice was issued must respond before the parking violations bureau. It shall also indicate the address of the bureau, the hours during which the bureau is open, the amount of the penalty scheduled for the offense for which the ticket was issued and advise that a warrant for the arrest of the person to whom the ticket was issued will be sought if such a person fails to respond within the time prescribed. 
(Ord. No. 86, § 5, 1-27-68) 
Sec. 90-56. - Penalties for parking violations. 
    The schedule of violations, Uniform Traffic Code cites and penalties is as follows:

Secs. 90-57-90-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SNOW AND STORM EMERGENCIES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Emergency services, ch. 42. 

Sec. 90-76. - Declaration of emergency; posting of notice. 
(a)  The city manager, chief of police, or director of public service is hereby empowered to issue orders declaring a snow or storm emergency to exist and thereby prohibit parking of motor vehicles on any highway, street, public roadway or public right-of-way located within the city during the existence of such a snow or storm emergency situation. A snow or storm emergency is defined as an emergency situation created by an excessive snowfall or other storm which significantly impairs or prevents the full and complete use of any highway, street, public roadway or public right-of-way located within the city. The city manager, chief of police, or director of public service shall cause notice of the issuance of such an order to be posted in not less than three public places within the city, and such an order shall not be effective until such notice is posted in this manner. 
(b)  Signs giving notice of this article shall be posted upon or at the entrance of all streets and roads entering the city and shall be sufficiently legible as to be seen by an ordinarily observant person. 
(Ord. No. 109, § I, 10-8-81) 
Sec. 90-77. - Parking prohibited during emergency. 
    No parking of motor vehicles shall be allowed or special parking granted on any highway, street, public roadway or public right-of-way located within the city during the existence of a snow or storm emergency created by an excessive snowfall or other storm which significantly impairs or prevents the full and complete use of any highway, street, public roadway or public right-of-way located within the city. 
(Ord. No. 109, § II, 10-8-81) 
Sec. 90-78. - Removal and storage of vehicles parked in violation; written report; notification of registered owner. 
    When any vehicle shall hereafter be parked or left standing on any highway, street, public roadway or public right-of-way during the existence of a snow or storm emergency contrary to the provisions of this article, any such vehicle may be removed by or under the direction of any member of the city police department or department of public works to a place in the city to be designated by the chief of police or the director of public service. It shall be the duty of any police officer or public works employee so removing or causing to be removed any such vehicle to make a report thereof in writing and in duplicate stating the make of such vehicle, the state license number of the vehicle and where the vehicle was removed to and to file the written report with the chief of police or any person designated by him. The city police department shall notify, by regular mail, the registered owner of the vehicle at the address indicated on the records of the secretary of state. 
(Ord. No. 109, § III, 10-8-81) 
Sec. 90-79. - Return of vehicle to owner; payment of towing and storage costs. 
    Any person owning or entitled to the possession of such a vehicle so removed, towed and/or stored may thereafter obtain possession of the vehicle by paying to the person or business towing the vehicle and, in addition thereto, by paying the total sum of all storage costs for each and every day that the vehicle is impounded or stored, such storage costs to be paid to the person or business storing the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 109, § IV, 10-8-81) 
Sec. 90-80. - Abandonment of vehicle; disposition of abandoned vehicle. 
    Any vehicle impounded pursuant to the terms and provisions of this article remaining unclaimed, as provided for in section 90-79 for a period of 60 days shall be deemed to be an abandoned vehicle and shall be disposed of in accordance with the laws of the state providing for the disposition of abandoned vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 109, § V, 10-8-81) 
Secs. 90-81-90-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - EMERGENCY RESPONSE COSTS INVOLVING ALCOHOL AND/OR CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 136, adopted Aug. 21, 1995, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 1-3 as a new art. V, §§ 90-91-90-93, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 90-91. - Declaration of purpose. 
    The city finds that a significant number of the traffic arrests and traffic accidents in the city involve drivers operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance, or a combination of both. Furthermore, the city finds that there is a greater likelihood of personal injury or property damages in accidents involving a driver operating under the influence of an intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance, or a combination of both. As a result, the city finds that a greater operational and financial burden has been placed on the city's public safety services by persons operating a motor vehicle under the influence of intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance, and that it is necessary to recover these increased emergency response costs. 
(Ord. No. 136, § 1, 8-21-95) 
Sec. 90-92. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of Sections 10.900 through 10.903, the terms listed below shall have the following meanings. 
    Costs of an emergency response shall mean all direct and reasonable costs related to an emergency response incurred by the city or by a private individual or corporation operating at the request or direction of the city. These costs shall include, but are not limited to, the costs of police, firefighting, emergency medical and rescue services; the salaries, wages, and fringe benefits of any personnel responding to the incident; the salaries, wages and fringe benefits of any personnel engaged in investigating the incident and all costs of any related reports; all costs connected with the supervision personnel responding to or investigating any incident; all costs connected with the administration and processing of chemical tests of blood, breath, or urine of the driver; and all costs related to any prosecution of the person causing the incident. 
    Emergency response shall mean providing, sending or utilizing police, fire-fighting, emergency medical or rescue personnel by the city, or by a private individual or corporation operating at the request or direction of the city, in connection with any incident involving a driver of a motor vehicle operating under the influence of intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance, or a combination of intoxicating liquor and a controlled substance. These incidents shall include, but not be limited to, any accident involving a motor vehicle where one or more of the drivers was operating the motor vehicle while under the influence of an intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance, or a combination of intoxicating liquor and a controlled substance; and any traffic stop and arrest by a police officer when the driver was operating the motor vehicle while under the influence of an intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance, or a combination of both. 
(Ord. No. 136, § 2, 8-21-95) 
Sec. 90-93. - Liability for costs of an emergency response. 
(a)  Person liable. Any person is liable for the costs of an emergency response if that person, while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance, or a combination of intoxicating liquor and a controlled substance, proximately causes any incident resulting in an emergency response. 
(b)  Presumptions. For the purpose of Sections 10.900 through 10.903, a person is under the influence of an intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance, or the combination of an intoxicating liquor and a controlled substance, when his or her physical or mental abilities are impaired to a degree that he or she no longer has the ability to operate a motor vehicle with the caution characteristic of a sober person of ordinary prudence. Further, it shall be presumed that a person was operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of an intoxicating liquor if a chemical analysis of his or her blood, urine or breath indicates that the amount of alcohol in his or her blood was in excess of 0.07%. 
(c)  Charge against person. The costs of an emergency response shall be a charge against the person liable for the costs under Sections 10.900 through 10.903. The charge constitutes a debt of that person and is collectible by the city for incurring those costs in the same manner as in the case of an obligation under a contract, expressed or implied. 
(d)  Cost recovery schedule. The city council shall from time to time adopt resolutions that set forth a schedule of the costs incurred in making an emergency response. It shall be presumed that the costs listed in this schedule are the true costs incurred by the city and represent the "costs of an emergency response." This schedule shall be available to the public from either the city clerk or the police department. 
(e)  Billing. The chief of police or the chief's agent may, within 30 days of receiving a complete list of itemized costs of an emergency response, submit a bill for these costs by first class mail or personal service to the person liable for the costs. The bill(s) shall require full payment in 30 days from the date of service. 
(f)  Failure to pay; procedure to recover costs. Any failure by the person described in Sections 10.900 through 10.903 as liable for the costs of an emergency response, to pay the bill within 30 days of service shall be considered a default. In case of default, the city may commence civil suit to recover the costs plus any additional costs or expenses allowed by law. 
(Ord. No. 136, § 3, 8-21-95) 
Secs. 90-94-90-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SKATEBOARDS AND ROLLERSKATES 

Sec. 90-106. - Title. 
    This article shall be known, referred to and cited as the Richmond Skateboard and Rollerskate Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 141, § 1, 8-5-96) 
Sec. 90-107. - Regulation of skateboards, in-line skates, or similar contrivances. 
    No person shall at any time use any skateboard, in-line skates, rollerskates, coaster, scooters, or similar contrivances for any purpose on the travel portion of the roadways of Main Street and Division Road within the city limits. All using skateboards, rollerskates, in-line skates, coasters, scooters and similar contrivances shall use crosswalks when crossing the roadways or Main or Division Road within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 141, § 2, 8-5-96) 
Sec. 90-108. - Pedestrian right-of-way. 
    Any person who shall use a skateboard, in-line skates, rollerskates, coaster, scooter, or other similar contrivance in any area where permitted within the city, shall not hinder or impede the passage and free movement of any pedestrian or vehicle. Pedestrians shall have the right-of-way upon all areas within the city. 
(Ord. No. 141, § 3, 8-5-96) 
Sec. 90-109. - No towing. 
    No person shall ride on, or in any manner, use any in-line skates, rollerskates, coaster, scooter, or any similar contrivance, which is being towed or pulled in any fashion by a motor driven vehicle within the city. No person shall intentionally tow or pull in any fashion by a motor driven vehicle, any person using a skateboard, rollerskates, in-line skates, a coaster, a scooter, or any similar contrivance. 
    All in-line skates, rollerskates, roasters, scooters, or similar contrivance when in use at nighttime shall be equipped with reflective tape or devices equivalent to a minimum of one inch by one inch reflective tape which shall be visible from distances of 600 feet to the rear when illuminated by direct lawful lower beams of headlamps from a motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 141, § 4, 8-5-96) 
Sec. 90-110. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates this article shall be responsible for a civil infraction, for which a fine not to exceed $100.00 may be imposed by the judge or magistrate having jurisdiction over such matters. 
(Ord. No. 141, § 5, 8-5-96) 
Secs. 90-111-90-299. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - GOLF CARTS 

Sec. 90-300. - Purpose. 
    These regulations are intended to secure the public peace, health and safety of the residents and property owners of the City of Richmond for the regulation of the use of golf carts on public roads within the corporate limits of the city, to provide for the issuance of decafs in connection with the registration of golf carts, and to provide penalties for the violation of these provisions. 
( Ord. No. 163, 3-5-18, eff. 5-1-18 ) 
Sec. 90-301. - Definitions. 
    Decal means the sticker displayed on the front of every registered golf cart within the city, which are obtained by completing and submitting the proper registration form to the Richmond Police Department. 
    Driver license means an operator's or chauffeur's license or permit issued to an individual by the secretary of state under Chapter III of the Michigan Vehicle Code, 1949 PA 300, MCL 257.301 to MCL 257.329, as amended, for that individual to operate a vehicle, whether or not conditions are attached to the license or permit. 
    Golf cart means a vehicle designed for transportation while playing the game of golf. 
    Maintained portion means that portion of a road improved, designated or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic. 
    Operate means to ride in or on, or be in actual physical control of the operation of the golf cart. 
    Operator means a person who operates or is in actual physical control of the operation of a golf cart. 
    Registration means the process through which every person intending to operate a motorized golf cart on roads or streets within the city must follow. 
    Street means a road, roadway, street or right-of-way within the City of Richmond street system, but does not include a private road. The terms road, roadway, street and right-of-way are interchangeable. 
    Sunset and sunrise mean that time determined by the National Weather Service on any given day. 
    Village means the City of Richmond, Counties of Macomb and St. Clair, State of Michigan. 
( Ord. No. 163, 3-5-18, eff. 5-1-18 ) 
Sec. 90-302. - Operation of golf carts on city streets. 
    A person may operate a golf cart on city streets, subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  A person shall not operate a golf cart on any street unless he or she is at least 16 years old and is licensed to operate a motor vehicle. 
(2)  The operator of a golf cart shall comply with the signal requirements of MCL 257.648, as amended, that apply to the operation of a vehicle. 
(3)  All golf carts are required to have a red reflector on the rear of the golf cart that shall be visible from all distances up to 500 feet when in front of lawful low beams of headlamps on a motor vehicle. 
(4)  The operator of a golf cart shall obey by all sections pertaining to traffic in the Michigan Vehicle Code and the Uniform Traffic Code. 
(5)  A person operating a golf cart upon a roadway shall ride as near to the right side of the roadway as practicable, exercising due care when passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction. 
(6)  A person shall not operate a golf cart on a state trunk line highway. This subsection does not prohibit a person from crossing a state trunk line highway when operating a golf cart on a street of the city, using the most direct line of crossing. 
(7)  Where a usable and designated path for golf carts is provided adjacent to a road or street, a person operating a golf cart shall be required to use that path. A golf cart shall not be operated on a sidewalk constructed for the use of pedestrians. 
(8)  A person operating a golf cart shall not pass between lines of traffic, but may pass on the left of traffic moving in his or her direction in the case of a two-way street, or on the left or right of traffic, in an unoccupied lane, in the case of a one-way street. 
(9)  A golf cart shall be operated at a speed not to exceed 15 miles per hour and shall not be operated on a roadway or street with a speed limit of more than 30 miles per hour except to cross that roadway or street. The city may designate roads or classifications of roads for use by golf carts. 
{10)  A golf cart shall not be operated on the streets of the City during the time period from one-half hour before sunset to one-half hour after sunrise. 
(11)  A person operating a golf cart or who is a passenger in a golf cart is not required to wear a crash helmet. 
(12)  A golf cart shall not be used to carry more persons at one time than the number for which it is designed and equipped. 
(13)  A golf cart operated on a street of the city is not required to be registered under this Act for purposes of Section 3101 of the Insurance Code of 1956, 1956 PA 218, MCL 500.3101, as amended. 
(14)  A golf cart shall not be operated during weather events with snow and/or ice on the ground. 
(15)  Golf carts shall not be operated on a road or street in a negligent manner, endangering any person or property, or obstructing, hindering, or impeding the lawful course of travel of any motor vehicle or the lawful use by any pedestrian of public streets, sidewalks, paths, trails, walkways or parks. 
(16)  Off-road vehicles, such as Gators, all-terrain vehicles (ATVs), a multitrack or multi-wheel drive vehicle, dune buggy, or like-vehicles are not considered golf carts. 
(17)  This section does not apply to a police officer, city officials, employees, contractors or volunteers in the performance of city duties. 
( Ord. No. 163, 3-5-18, eff. 5-1-18 ) 
Sec. 90-303. - Parking regulations. 
    The parking, stopping, and standing regulations provided in the City Code, which may be adopted by reference therein, shall also apply to golf carts operated in the city, as if they are motor vehicles under those provisions. 
( Ord. No. 163, 3-5-18, eff. 5-1-18 ) 
Sec. 90-304. - Registration and decals. 
(a)  Golf cart owners shall register each golf cart on an annual basis by making application to the Richmond Police Department. Such application shall include proof of insurance as a rider to a homeowner's or renter's policy, or in any other form of policy selected by the applicant, for coverage of personal injury or property damage resulting from operation of the subject golf cart. The minimum amount of coverage shall be no less than $300,000.00, and the City of Richmond shall be named as an additional insured. The police department shall review and approve or deny each application, and provide a list of registered golf carts to the city manager. 
(b)  There shall be no charge for the registration of a golf cart, and each approved golf cart shall be issued a registration decal. The golf cart owner shall affix each decal provided by the Richmond Police on a clearly visible place on the front of the golf cart. The decal shall be valid for one year. 
(c)  Non-residents may register their golf cart with the City as long as they have written approval from a Richmond resident that the resident will act as the host property for the non-resident's golf cart. The host resident will allow the golf cart trailer to be parked on their property so as not to take up parking public parking spaces. 
(d)  Failure to register a golf cart or renew an existing registration shall constitute a violation of this article. 
(e)  The Richmond Police Department retains the right to refuse to issue and/or revoke any registration decal from any golf cart for any reason that is felt appropriate to ensure the safety and well-being of the citizens of city. 
(f)  Any police officer may temporarily suspend any registration decal, and ban further access on any public street or public property by any golf cart, when in the opinion of that officer the golf cart is being used in a manner to cause damage to public property or members of the public. 
(g)  The city council reserves the right to waive the registration requirements of this ordinance for special events that utilize golf carts. 
( Ord. No. 163, 3-5-18, eff. 5-1-18 ) 
Sec. 90-305. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  Any person violating any provisions of this article shall be responsible for a civil infraction. The penalty for the first offense shall be $50.00, and $100.00 for the first repeat offense. For any second or subsequent repeat offense, the fine shall be no more than $250.00. 
(b)  A court may order a person who causes damage to the environment, a road, or other public property as a result of the operation of a golf cart to pay full restitution for that damage above and beyond the penalties paid for civil infractions. 
( Ord. No. 163, 3-5-18, eff. 5-1-18 ) 
Secs. 90-306-90-330. - Reserved.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 94-1-94-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER SUPPLY AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEMS 

Sec. 94-31. - Separation of systems. 
    The water supply and the sewage disposal systems of the City of Richmond, County of Macomb, State of Michigan, shall be independent systems, to be designated as the water supply system and sewage disposal system, each to be operated on a separate rate basis under the provisions of Act 94, Public Acts of Michigan, 1933, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 148, § I, 7-2-01) 
Sec. 94-32. - System components. 
    Said water supply system and sewage disposal system shall include all water mains and laterals, wells, pumping stations, sewer, sewage disposal plant and all facilities or appurtenances used or useful in connection with the supplying and distributing of water or the collection, treatment or disposal of sewage, either now in existence or hereafter acquired. Said separate water supply and sewage disposal systems are sometimes herein referred to as the "systems" or "system". 
(Ord. No. 148, § II, 7-2-01) 
Sec. 94-33. - Administration. 
(a)  The operation, repair and management of the system and authorized improvements to the system shall be under the immediate supervision and control of the city manager subject, however, to supervision and control by the city council. The city council may make such rules, orders and regulations as it deems necessary to assure the efficient management and operation of the system. 
(b)  At any point in time when the city does not have a city manager in its employment and the city council has not appointed an acting city manager, the city council shall be empowered to assume full responsibility and exercise complete authority as otherwise given to the city manager in administering and enforcing the provisions of this article. 
(c)  The city manager, or his designee, may regulate, limit or prohibit the use of water for any purpose temporarily to cover special or emergency conditions. Such regulations shall restrict less essential water uses to the extent deemed necessary to assure an adequate supply for essential domestic, commercial and industrial needs and for fire fighting. 
(d)  Whenever city water shall be used for outdoor sprinkling contrary to any limitation or prohibition imposed, such use shall be prima facie proof that it was so used, or that such use was consented to, approved or directed by the person or persons to whom such water was billed at the time of such use as appears from the records of the water department. 
(Ord. No. 148, § III, 7-2-01) 
Sec. 94-34. - Water rate. 
(a)  The rate to be charged for water services furnished to the in-city consumers of the City of Richmond shall be the sum of the water commodity charge and the water readiness-to-serve charge until otherwise provided by ordinance of the governing body. The water commodity charge shall be a rate established by resolution of the governing body per 1,000 gallons for each quarterly (three-month) period.
